column10: My favorite Total War game. Criminally underrated!

Attila Total War is not worth playing in 2024. The developers recently introduced an update to fix certain graphical issues. But they have not fixed anything. I run an RTX 4080 and my system runs Rome 2 beautifully. I will also add that Rome 2 is simply visually gorgeous on the campaign and battlefield. In Attila, however, shadows are still flickering wildly on the campaign map, frame-rates drop and rise wildly, game fonts are unreadable on 4k monitors. Online solutions do not work - so do not bother fiddling with your scripts. On older systems this game may run well. But on newer systems this is a waste of money. Update your old games, Creative Assembly, before pumping out useless titles like WH3 with its pointless and monotonous campaign where you auto-resolve everything.

This by far is the best of the Total War series.  The leveling of both generals and armies can be enjoyable and really personalizes the gameplay. I absolutely enjoy the family tree decisions and the office position aspect for your faction. It's a enjoyable part of gameplay that adds immersion to the game as well as adding dept to not just a campaign map with armies. The political aspect is pretty much the same but there are a handful of decisions when you're engaged in politics. The razing of cities is a good way to not have to deal with low population support and the hordes gameplay is new and creative. I don't understand why a lot of this games features did not carry over to following Total War titles.

NOTE: I also extremely recommend the 1212 AD MOD. It's more of a Medieval 3 theme.

Won't launch on your new machine?
I tried everything, from verify files, updates to graphic drivers and win11 etc, what finally fixed it was, I had to download Rome 2, which I am guessing installs some files missing from the Attila install. Then simply relaunch Attila and it should now work fine. Now Just refund Rome 2, you won't need it again.

Anyway, I have hundreds of hours in Attila on my old steam account, and I still love it out of all the historical TW games. The setting and the gloomy doomy atmosphere, the higher difficulty which every other game lacks, even the music, it's something that appeals to me. The battles play well, and it really is amazing (and frightful) when you're defending your first siege against 2 or 3 stacks of huns. It's a really unique game of TW still to this day with an underserved timeframe in strategy gaming. If you're new, go in blind, it's a better experience, but you'd better enjoy a good pummeling because you're gonna get it ;)

It is not a very well optimised game that is its main issue, though I am using a laptop, 3050 6gb gpu, intel i5, 16gb ram and I average about 60fps in the biggest battles with unit size and graphics on ultra.

The modding community for this game alone is why after 9 years since release, this title still draws me in. 

Total war modding has always been a staple of the TW community, but Attila takes it to another level. Likely the last truly epic historical total war, and it plays unlike any of the other total war titles. It's about survival. That alone makes this a unique one for TW. Though Shogun may feel more polished, Attila feels grim, dark, and medieval in a way few games capture. 

The Medieval mod makes this essentially Medieval Total War 3, which I love, but really for me the mod that shines is Radious. From the unit additions, to the quality of life fixes, this mod really cranks this game up to 11. Playing as the Western Roman Empire, or Eastern Roman Empire, is a game about surviving marauding hordes,  managing religious strife, trying to avoid plagues, balancing complex politics, diplomacy, as much as it is about waging war on a truly massive scale. Cavalry is king in this game, so if you like seeing heavy horsemen slamming into infantry, this game is for. If you like managing a disaster, this game is for you. If you like the sound of playing a Lord of the Rings total war game, that's right this is for you. 

Buy this, try the mods, learn the game, then try playing vanilla West Rome on Legendary at least once. It's torturous but it's a gauntlet that will make you a worthy Emperor/Empress

super fun game with a lot of features that are new to the Total War series. bigger focus on needing to build up defenses and prepare for the hordes of the Huns while also trying to expand to pay for the armies you will need just to survive. Challenging yet not to the point of being overwhelming unless you want it to be. great for new players and seasoned total war players with plenty of factions to choose from.

This, in my opinion, is my favorite of the series behind Medieval II. I think it's more polished than Rome II and definitely has the more compelling story. One of the most under-rated and under-appreciated historical total war games on release. And like the historical period it covers (4th century to 8th century), it remains under-appreciated by many in the total war community (including you Creative Assembly). 

Almost 10 years later, many veterans of the historical total war franchise only play Attila (and bit of Rome II) due to its great basic economy, battle, and climate systems for community mods. 

Thankfully, the fanbase took charge and developed Attila where CA fell short.

Attila is home to many historical total war scenario mods covering vast time periods. Attila fanbase created historical scenarios from the fall of Carthage (Ancient Empires), the fall of Western Roman Empire (5th century Fall of the Eagles), the last attempt to restore the fragmented West Roman Empire (Age of Majorian), the Last Roman reconquest of Western Rome (6th century with Belisarius and Justinian in the Eastern Roman Empire - Age of Justinian), hypothetical Roman 5th century crisis (Terminus Total War Attila), the rise of the first Islamic caliphate (Age of Emperor Heraclius and fall of the Sassanids in 7th century - the Last Persian), the rise of the last Sassanid great king (Age of Khosrow II), up until the 4th crusade in the 13th century (Medieval 1212 AD). (I might have missed a few still).

Attila Total War had a buggy launch and poor optimization. It could not live up to the polished Rome II and the huge community the former attracted and held, but it was unique in its design, fresh concept, environment, and mechanics. 

Attila Total War introduced to the total war franchise: 

-Horde (migratory tribes community) mechanics, horde is your army. But it is not only your border defences or offensive force like in past total war titles, but also "your culture's survival" with horde buildings (like a mobile settlement), faction economy, agent recruitment, army recruitment, and mere existence of a faction on the grand campaign map. 

Horde battles have thin margins of error (getting a horde or migratory tribe wiped out means your faction becomes significantly weaker, and in some cases, one battle away from defeat if your remaining horde is defeated). Every move must be calculated lest you find yourself cornered and surrounded by enemy doom army stacks in a hostile land. Balancing the ledger also isn't easy, your income often depends on how fertile the land is while your horde is migrating through.

-Razing mechanics - want to put an entire enemy settlement to the sword and leave nothing alive behind?  Well you can, by razing aka "let none live." In fact, it's the Huns factions' favourite past time. Resettlement after a raze takes ages (reflecting the slow return of the population).

-The game is harder than previous total war titles. You are given a bucket to bail out a sinking ship with most factions.

-Climate Change - your land would not be fertile enough to support your culture forever, and going on migration south into foreign empires might be your best option.

-The Hunnic Scourge (the impending doom aka abandon all hope) - for many factions, the Huns invasion (like the Mongol and Timurid Invasion) is "arrival of death" itself. Most culture's unit rosters will not have satisfactory answers to full stacks of mobile skirmishing horse archers and shock cavalry lancers (rip Vikings, gothic tribes, desert kingdoms, and to a lesser extent, WRE). The Huns are so terrifying in fact that they bring with it a huge morale penalty when fighting against it with Christian factions.

But then Eastern Roman Empire (particularly, its elite Tagmata regiments and Clibanarii shock cav regiments) be like: Yo, hold my wine and olive oil, imma go smack that Hun horse archer boi real quik. 

-Sanitation - public order is no longer dependent on taxes, absence of wars/destruction, raiding parties, and religion. Your must ensure your settlements have sufficient sanitation to keep it clean, otherwise, disease will ruin your population growth and economy. We distinguish "civilized" and "uncivilized" in Attila through smell only.

-Migration/settlement - many factions allow the player to "pack up your culture" and move elsewhere - no longer are you firmly wedded to your starting region. You can settle your people in a safe and fertile land far from your culture's ancestral land, and build an empire there, just like the Visigoth, Ostrogoth, and Vandals did historically. 

-Horse archers are incredibly useful and dangerous. Battles can be won by "feigned retreats" and "kiting" the enemy by spamming light horse archers. Heavy infantry and cavalry melee are no longer the only way to win battles. An army of horse archers skillfully "micro'd" can assassinate generals, whittle enemy infantry down to bits, and shred enemy heavy cavalry.  Lack of ammo is your only enemy.

-War Weariness - in Age of Charlemagne DLC - aka various negative faction effects from constantly being at war (and losing battles). Think twice about declaring war on everyone. 

Attila Total War was the last great European-theatre historical total war released. It shook up the decade long basic historical Total War gameplay formula, which can be summarized as "start small, build an army, build an economy, secure resources, win battles, and expand." It's difficult to steamroll in Attila Total War, especially if the huns have multiple hordes when Attila takes over.

Instead, Attila challenges you to "survive" either as crumpling empires (the Romans) with countless enemies in your heartland (such as Gothic migratory hordes), with attack on multiple fronts (Africa, Gaul, Asia Minor, and the Levant) without adequate field armies to check advances. The celebrated Roman legions of Augustus are no longer invincible on the battlefield where heavy infantry once held sway. In Attila, cavalry and mounted skirmishers have the initiative in battles. 

Rome (whether East or West) starts out on the defensive unlike past Total War games.

The migratory barbarians, the gothic tribes, start off on the offensive pillaging and plundering rich Roman lands to reach a new home somewhere deep within Roman territory (Pro Tip: Hispania has all you need). 

Others look for opportunities to profit from the weak, overstretched, and defenceless Roman empires, like Rome's historical enemy Parthia (now the Sassanid Empire), the emerging vikings, the invading Huns and White Huns, and the awakening African/Arabian kingdoms.

Every faction in Attila has its weaknesses like Medieval II (some in early game, others in late game, some permanent impairments, some temporary impairments). 

To be sure, Attila in its vanilla state is a little "barebones" when it comes to faction unit variety. The barbarian Gothic factions have similar playstyles and army rosters (almost like copy+pastes of each other). The mighty Sassanid Empire (its army roster) is oddly bland and weak considering its historical significance as the arch nemesis of Rome. The viking factions have little differences in playstyle, and the desert kingdoms feel flawed in their individual ways.  

Nonetheless, Attila TW has two excellent DLCs - The Last Roman and Age of Charlemagne. The latter come close to what "Fall of the Samurai" was to Shogun 2 in gameplay content and mechanics. The former gives every men out there a chance to restore the former and O.G. Roman Empire by subjugating the barbarians, through force ("how dare you stand where Rome Empire stood").

In conclusion, I have played Total War from Rome I. Rome I, Attila, Medieval II, Napoleon, Three Kingdoms, Shogun 2, and Empire will forever remain my top historical total war games. 

We were born too late to save the Roman Empire, but born too early to start a Roman Empire in space, so at least we can try to save the Roman Empires on our PC, and mourn the fall of Emperor Majorian (the Last Roman in the West, where men cried).

If you enjoy the macro campaigns aspect of TW over the battles, then ignore the negative reviews, they've missed the mark on this one. This may not be the most polished TW (and definitely requires at least the unofficial patch), but to date, this is the most fun I've had across any of the TW games. 

Playing either Western or Eastern Rome is one of the best strategy experiences out there as you battle hordes of barbarian invaders and fight to turn your empire around. Especially on higher difficulty settings, it's a challenge you won't find elsewhere. Playing one of the migratory tribes fleeing the huns can also be very satisfying. 

Just don't bother with any of the culture packs / add-ons, they are all for tribes that are uninteresting and not very fun to play. Hopefully one day CA gives this game another shot as they almost created a classic, but still a very good game nonetheless.

[h1]When Rome Burned, We Brought Marshmallows[/h1]

[h2]A Sack of Rome, One Turn at a Time[/h2]
In the decaying light of the Roman Empire, "Total War: Attila" thrives, offering a grand campaign that would make even the most stalwart centurion's head spin. With the horde mechanic introducing a nomadic thrill, and settlement razing that feels like you're wiping cities off the map with the swipe of Mars' own hand, Attila ups the ante on your strategic indulgences. Be warned, though: reconstructing razed lands demands resources that'd make Croesus gulp, and converting provinces is a slow, golden dance with the gods of coin and time.

[h3]Beneath the Family Tree Lies a Nest of Vipers[/h3]
The family tree is back, and it's more cutthroat than a political intrigue penned by Tacitus himself. Balancing acts of nepotism and meritocracy, you'll find yourself in a tangle of loyalties so deep it would take an oracle to sort out. Meanwhile, the tech tree now boasts both researchable and buyable advancements, ensuring that your kingdom's brain is as buff as its brawn.

[h2]The Battlefields: Where the Legions Roar[/h2]
As for the battlefield, Attila maintains its martial glory. Levelling up agents and generals feels as personal as inscribing your name on Trajan's Column, each choice a testament to your growing legend. But don't get cocky - playing on Hard is akin to facing Hannibal at Cannae without the hindsight of history. You might want to cut your teeth on Normal, lest you find your empire on the business end of a barbarian's blade.

[h3]But Not All Roads Lead to Triumph[/h3]
The journey is not without its potholes. Essential units inexplicably evolve into their higher-tier forms, leaving you nostalgic for the good old days of unit diversity. Indeed, the Sassanid Empire's military menu is sparser than a patrician's banquet after the plebs have been through it. And the AI, oh the AI - sometimes they'll sack your city and then scuttle away like scared rabbits, even when conquest is their only lifeline.

[h2]A World Both Vast and Grim[/h2]
Yet the scale of it all is truly imperial. From the forests concealing warring tribes to the deserts standing as natural fortresses, the map is a thing of beauty - a canvas where history's greatest sagas unfold. But, as the world turns, so does its fertility wane, leaving you to curse the gods as your breadbasket provinces wither like grapes under a scorching sun.

[b]Graphics:[/b] [u]8/10[/u] - The splendor of the old world is captured with a vibrancy that almost makes you forgive the occasional stutter in performance.
[b]Sound:[/b] [u]9/10[/u] - From the clash of steel to the haunting chants, the audio is a triumph worthy of the bards.
[b]Gameplay:[/b] [u]7.5/10[/u] - Strategic and deep, yet marred by the monotony of cookie-cutter settlements and an AI that could use a few more scrolls in its library.
[b]Story:[/b] [u]N/A[/u] - The fall of empires and the roar of the horde craft a tale where your actions pen history's greatest chapters. Not a story told but one that's made, with each campaign carving out its own saga.

[h2]The Verdict: A Flame in the Dark[/h2]
[b]OVERALL:[/b] [u]8.1/10[/u] - "Total War: Attila" is not just a game; it's a chronicle of survival, strategy, and burning ambition. It demands not only the might of the legions but the cunning of Caesar himself. Ready your sword, steady your heart, and may Fortuna favor your empire.

I grew up playing Total War games, the first of which was Shogun Total War and I loved that game! I played a few others since then and had great fun with them all. So when I saw this game on sale and I looked at the screenshots I was ready to have a lot of fun. I even bought the Viking DLC and was ready to set off on a raiding party.
Unfortunately I had no fun with this game at all. I played ten hours and never once saw anything resembling the screenshots posted for this game. The game felt half completed and like a broken version of Civilization or something. It didn't even feel like a Total War game.

Attila is a game that has to be appreciated compared to the earlier release of Rome 2. This game fixes a lot of the weak points from Rome 2 such as making buildings that actually require a challenging amount of food and money. Besieging cities is more realistic by causing damage to city walls over time and the ability to lower enemy morale by burning up the town during a battle. Another great feature was army integrity which means you have to actually win battles with your army or else they will mutiny against you. The only weak point in Attila is that there's slightly less unit variety than Rome 2.

Updating toward the end of 2023: So uh... I wasn't expecting this to really be the last Total War game I'd really like - and I mean REALLY like. It has some substantial issues that carried over from Rome 2, since... well, it's just a reskin with some features added. Best part is still the modding community. But holy hell has my perception of the whole series shifted lately. Just referring to Attila, though, it's alright on its own. The DLC is... excessive, for the most part. Age of Charlemagne and Last Roman are pretty good, but the faction and unit packs are just... meh. All the Germanic tribes being reskinned is meh. It's just meh. Modded, it's great. I like it so much specifically because of the mods. 1212 is amazing in particular, and it's probably the closest we're ever getting to Medieval 3.

I would very strongly recommend capping off anything in the series here. The newer historical games are a mess, and as much as I love Warhammer, they're not very good Total War games in my experience.
In case anyone from CA happens to read this: please, build your next historical game from the ground up. I know it'll take a lot of time and money, but it's necessary at this point. Reusing Rome 2's engine has just resulted in more problems than it's worth. I grew up playing these games and it deeply saddens me to see the quality slipping. I've skipped out on all historical titles since Three Kingdoms and haven't touched Warhammer 3 or the later DLC for Warhammer 2, because I could see the writing on the wall in regards to the dropping quality.
Please, do better. Innovate again. Make games with passion like you used to, and not just a DLC pipeline to siphon money off the community.

My personal favorite TW game.
Flawed at launch due to bad performance, but now most pc's will handle it well (including steam deck, with a little settings optimization).

Compared to Rome 2 and Warhammer (my most played TWs) this one feels significantly more strategic in the campaign map.  Politics and Alliances are to be considered carefully, 4 turns (and seasons) per year, betrayals, rebellions, civil wars, fertility ratings, climate change, religious conflicts...
It feels less like a "paint the map your color simulator" and more of a survival total war.

The battles are epic and brutally violent.

It's an amazing time period, often overlooked by the mainstream: the end of the Roman empire and the classical world with it, and the beginning of the dark ages that will lead to the creation of the medieval kingdoms we all know.


It's a time of crisis, of change, of chaos, of quickly shifting power, and the game portrays that very well.

Also, the main menu music is FIRE and will trigger your ancestral ptsd.

Highly recommended, if you like total war, don't miss this one.

I miss some of the things about the original RTW and M2TW but this game is amazing, I am growing to love the changes after figuring the new system out. It is definitely one of the best Total war games I have ever played.

I never played this game in the past simply because of how un-optimized and sluggish it ran. Cut to today and it runs extremely well and I'm realizing this game reminds me so much of the original Rome Total War 1 in terms of feel, and I am loving every second. It looks great, plays great, and sounds great now.

Total War: Attila delivers a mixed experience marked by strategic depth but marred by notable optimization issues that impact the overall gameplay. The ambitious portrayal of the Eastern and Western Roman Empires adds a compelling historical context, but technical shortcomings may hinder the enjoyment.

Optimization problems, unfortunately, detract from the immersive potential of Total War: Attila. The game demands a high level of hardware prowess, leading to performance issues on systems that should otherwise handle similar titles seamlessly. This can result in frustrating lag, extended load times, and occasional crashes, hampering the otherwise engaging strategic experience.

The Eastern and Western Roman campaigns offer distinct challenges, providing a nuanced representation of the Roman Empire's decline. Managing internal strife, external invasions, and dwindling resources makes for a complex and engaging strategic experience. However, the optimization problems mentioned earlier may compromise the fluidity of the gameplay, affecting the enjoyment of these historically rich campaigns.

Despite technical challenges, Total War: Attila shines in its strategic depth, with a comprehensive portrayal of the tumultuous period it covers. The game's emphasis on survival against the backdrop of Attila the Hun's relentless onslaught adds a layer of urgency to the gameplay, enhancing the overall experience for history enthusiasts.

In conclusion, Total War: Attila's commendable historical representation and strategic depth are unfortunately overshadowed by optimization issues. The Eastern and Western Roman campaigns offer compelling experiences, but the technical shortcomings may hinder the enjoyment for players, making it a somewhat polarizing entry in the Total War series.

I bought this game in 2022 just because the mod "Medieval Kingdoms" SEGA should open it eyes and see... without mods it's nothing... If they liberate the code for modding it would be a more precious game in every sense.

The best aspect of this game are battles. They are very very good. Tactics matter a lot. When to charge , when to stand your ground , how to position your archers etc. Disengaging your cavalry can be costly , getting flanked is catastrophic. Keeping the general alive is very important , just like in real life.

I like how I can burn the cities in sieges , which demoralize the defenders. Can be used as a tactic when attacking as a raiding faction , which usually have light troops that automatically go and ignite the nearest buildings. Also has custom settlements , like Constantinople and Rome.

The music is good , but not great. But it does it's job to keep you immersed. But it doesn't compare to Medieval II or Rome Total War.

The campaign is good , but can be better with mods. The only problem you might have as a beginner will be dealing with rebellions. A big thing I like is that: The AI actually tries to have armies. Good armies. Not like in Rome 2 where you can auto resolve everything. 

The only down side to this game  , after you play it for some time ,is when returning to other total war games. They will seem like a piece of cake because of how hard this game is.

Total War: Attila stands out in the Total War series. It is set in one of the darkest and most dynamic periods of history, which is greatly represented in the game. The game forces you into a survivalist mindset when playing with the two Roman Empires, or expansionist when playing with the smaller nations. It’s an adept refinement of Rome 2, offering a cleaner, better thought-out experience with more impactful decisions to make.

Most satisfying, challenging Total War game out there. This game holds a special place in my heart because it is such a unique experience to play as a veteran Total War player. If you play the Eastern Romans you are a large and powerful empire out of the gate, defending your lands and preparing for the scourge of Attila and the Huns, a good way to learn the game but not TOO challenging. The real challenge is the shattered and neglected massive Western Roman Empire, in financial, military and social ruin you are given the opportunity to try and save the nation. You must first consolidate your rule, build your financial base and deal with the dozens of enemies that already hate you at the start of the game. Then once you've managed to pull the fragments of a once great empire together, the final boss descends on your lands, Attila. This game will test your strategic ability like no other Total War and I love it so much for it. And once you've beaten back the Huns for the last time and peace remains it is a truly satisfying feeling of victory. I recommend this to new and veterans alike, there's diversity in units and strategy, replay-ability for hundreds of hours because every nation plays so differently. If you haven't picked this one up I highly encourage you to. 10/10 Bring back the good historical Total Wars CA

This game is born out of a DLC for Rome I: Barbarian Invasion. It's much more fleshed out, though, with a great deal of mechanics added.

The number one selling feature of this game is the distinct faction types. There are four: Empire (West/East Rome, Sassanids), horde (Huns, Goths), kingdom (Franks, Saxons), and border factions (Lakhamids, Garmantians). Having these four is a great way to experience some playstyles you'll never find in the other games.

I think part of the reason people kind of dislike Attila TW is because of the vibe. You are in the middle of an apocalypse. This period in European history was genuinely apocalyptic. A strong, organized government quickly fell apart, currency was out of use and bartering in, food storage was poorly managed so famine was common, and diseases were sweeping back and forth. On top of all that, migrating people pushed settled peoples farther and farther west.

The game does a great job of capturing this apocalyptic feeling. If you play as Rome, you are constantly putting out fires. Constant rebellions, mass armies at your borders. Hordes may make a peace treaty with you just so they can get deep into your territory before declaring war again, away from your frontier guards. You know that's what they are doing. But you have to make the peace so you can catch up on rebellions and infrastructure.

If you can't keep the rebellions and hordes from destroying your cities, all of your income will be ploughed into repairing structures. You could get sucked into a downward spiral.

I bought Attila years ago (it may have been on sale).  I looked at the game a lot of times and it did not interest me enough to learn a new game. I have not played Rome 2. So there was a lot different from the Total War games I have played a lot, Shogun 1 and 2, Medieval 1 and 2 and Rome 1. I like the Dark Age so even though I wasn’t hooked by the base game I bought The Age of Charlemagne.  That was a good choice. I liked the various Factions and decided to put the time in to learning it. 

In Charlemagne and the Last Roman I find that rebellions are common place even after some experience. It is very hard to keep up the food supply and build the buildings that confere public order they all use a lot of food. Some of the factions start in a state or near the state of rebellion. Some seem impossible to get in a state of control like the Avars.

CA has added a number of uninteresting unneeded complications like skills for the  Generals.  Its just boring busy work you have to do at the end of every turn. The internal politics of your factions Nobility is a boring distraction but you have to keep on topo of it. So there’s a lot of stuff the game would be better without.
In the end I’m still getting a lot of payout of the game even with is pointless and boring quirks.

This game is criminally underrated in the Total War series. Attila improved upon alot of the issues Rome II had and the battle AI especially has been much improved from that game. 

I LOVE the apocalyptic atmosphere the game conveys, like your fighting against this descent into the dark ages that immediately followed this era. The music, art design and the lighting really contribute to this. The Western Roman Empire campaign really is one of the most engaging yet challenging campaigns I've ever played and winning that campaign was one of the most satisfying experiences I've had playing Total War. 

The diplomacy in this game is also really good. Kind of an odd thing to call out maybe, but I found that alliances had quite a bit of weight in this game and generally, allies proved to be fairly reliable; the AI tends to take alot of current factors into consideration when making deals and alliances. 

The only complaints I have with the game are that it cant be played on modern Macs (PLEASE get this game a 64bit port) and that I've seen issues with late campaign saves getting corrupted. Overall, easy thumbs up from me.

Despite being a buggy, unstable mess,  Attila is one of the most unique RTS titles I've ever played.

If you've played Total War: Rome 2, then you'll be familiar with most of the systems of Attila, the only difference being that "culture" has been swapped for religion. Recruitment, replenishment, food, research, etc. all are almost unchanged. They do add a climate change mechanic to the game which will slowly lower the output of your agricultural buildings, but there are enough ways to mitigate it that it's not too important.

The biggest differences are in the campaign. Just like in the Barbarian Invasion expansion for Rome: Total War, the feature here is asymmetry. Play as the Huns, who can never settle and roam around the map as a horde, constructing tents in their armies. Play as the Ostrogoths, and die on turn 3 because you moved the wrong direction and the Huns jumped you. Play as the Vandals, and migrate to Africa where you settle in Carthage. Play as the Sassanids and instantly win the campaign because you ignore the entire sanitation mechanic. Play as the Saxons, and die because your starting military is the worst in the game. Play as the Franks, and sack England yourself after killing the Saxons. Or play as the Western Roman Empire, starting with 55+ territories and then sink in despair at how screwed you are until you learn that you can build Imperial Libraries and speedrun the tech tree.

10/10 incredibly frustrating and punishing game that makes you feel how fragile the world is while your eye twitches and you keep playing for just one more turn. Nothing else quite like it.

I've changed my stance on this game. A while ago I would not have recommended it. The modding community has done an excellent job and has changed a lot to make this a fun game. Changes to AI behavior on the campaign map, diplomacy, faction and religion trait rebalances, all make the game better. In addition, there are several overhaul mods that give a whole new gaming experience. I would now recommend it.

I will leave the rest of my original review below

First off the good. The game is pretty, gritty, but visually impressive. The political tree is there, and if you like playing a political struggle along part of managing an empire that is a factor. What you make your people do affects their traits, and rivals exist, so there is a lot of depth. The whole game has a feeling of winding down, and the world is falling apart, so you do get a feeling of fighting an inevitable decline (which I personally like). Usually with Total War games you bulid up an invincible center empire, expand using divide and conquer, and you are only really threatened at the beginning or by a multifront war, but this is quite different.

The bad. There are a lot of balance issues, cavalry is overpowered, the single player campaign is about as stable as Caligula. The visuals look very "samey" for lack of a better term. The game gets stale once Attila is half way through his lifetime (historically), because the Hunnic faction has razed most of the map and you're left fighting them over the ashes of Europe. The AI will also spam doomstacks, massive armies of top tier units the Huns get for free, and will send against your cities so you can do nothing but sit and defend. This is where it becomes unfun, and that really is a shame.

This game has one of the best battle systems in any TW game, although siege AI still sucks. The aesthetic of the game is top-notch. Lots of great flavour.

but, CA broke modding which was the life-blood of this game, and never optimised enough - only a lucky few will be able to get it to run stable. It would've been worth putting up with the frustrations before CA's bean counters started to run the franchise into the ground with WH3, Troy and Pharaoh. As it is, CA doesn't deserve your money until they realise why people play Total War games.

-Very poorly optimized

-Bugged shadows

Still a bit buggy, not very well optimized, and missing a lot of quality of life features of newer TW titles. I am not a big fan of the time period either. 
Neither am I a fan of the design of the Huns, where you have to fight against their infinitely spawning full-stack hordes until you kill Attila around 120 turns in. I get what they were going for but after you get past the surviving phase and start thriving, they are just a nuisance that don't bring any enjoyment. Eventually, I stopped attacking them unless they were in my territory and garrisoned armies at my border. They never attacked either, so it turned into a boring waiting game of waiting for Attila.
All that said, this is still the best historical TW game. Some of the issues can be modded away (modders are truly a blessing), and some have other workarounds. The ones remain, I try to tolerate. And if you add the other gigantic overhaul mods this game has and still coming (Dawnless Days please), I'd say worth it even now.

Pros: 
- Interesting new mechanics that change your play-style and how you conquer with a huge emphasis on public order and religion 
- Nice visuals that complement the gloomy and apocalyptic theme of the time 
- Cool unit rosters for factions in general 
- Siege barricades and some more interesting abilities for units in general compared to RTW2
- Not easy / AI is merciless and maintaining public order is a real challenge 
- Management choices of family members and generals holds more gravitas with more of an emphasis on loyalty and balancing power 
- Generally, feels more realistic and difficult than your average arcade-ish tw game where you're picking off provinces on the map like you're picking out maltesers from a bag
- Mods

Cons: 
- Poor optimization with regular FPS drops 
- Merciless AI will hunt you down no matter where you are and where they are which usually doesn't make sense 
- Due to public order management, you will spend most of your time clicking next turn without really doing anything -  the main purpose of your armies is to maintain public order, not invade 
- Following the previous point, factions take too long to play their turn making the wait boring as you click next turn 
- Very few factions to play as 
- AI diplomacy is trash especially when trying to form trade agreements - most factions will decline trade agreements because of the huge diplomacy debuffs you'll have just by merit of being another faction 

Verdict: Play it if you want to challenge yourself and your pc and spend alot of time micromanaging happiness, religion and sanitation otherwise if you wanna go on an invasion spree play rtw2.

This game successfully captures the essence of playing as the Western and Eastern Roman Empires. Choosing these factions, especially on the legendary difficulty, gives you a sense of once being a dominant power, an empire beyond imagination, the pinnacle of human achievement, and the envy of the world. But those glory days have long faded. The old wolf lies wounded by jackals, circled by vultures. Your economy is in shambles, and merely surviving becomes a daunting challenge. Maintaining your borders everywhere feels next to impossible because your enemies have superior numbers and stronger armies. After approximately 30 grueling turns of struggling, a glimmer of hope appears as you gain access to better troops and your economy starts stabilizing. You finally acquire the means to fend off hostile migrating tribes at your borders.

Then, Attila the scourge of God, rides with a million warriors and bringing the end of days.

Truly one of the best TOTAL WAR game out there.

Its DARK, GRITTY, And, if you like, Very fuckin Hard. Its a Historical Total war game that reminds you of those old TW games you used to play 15 years ago.

Want to destroy civilization? You can do that just like Attila did, burning your way, litterally, trough provinces and empires. want to be a barbarian invader? You can do that. Or do you want to test your might and SURVIVE against all odds? You can do that as the Romans. You will constantly need to adapt your strategy in this game, everyone is out for themselves and alliances are untrustworthy, furthermore, the UI is better than its predecessor Rome 2, gone are those ugly 2d line art esc unit and building icons, replaced with icons in the likes of Rome 1.

Graphics are fine and battles are good, no need to expand on that. The thing that makes all this worth it is that this game does not hold your hand, and will make you feel desperate, conflicted, and make you feel all that doom and gloom in one playtrough.

The only thing i got an issue with is performance, its got somekind of bug or left behind code that makes your modern hardware push itself. 

All this game needs, is a patch and new DLC, speaking of, DLC, its got a few. They are mediocre at best, BUT, provide interesting ways to play the game, for example, the last roman DLC makes you step into the shoes of ROMAN invaders, trying to get back lost territory 100 years after ROME was sacked, letting you play a Roman faction like you did when playing the Huns, adopting a nomad style playtrough, BUT also letting you do a 180° and setup your own Kingdom if you tire from the nomad style gameplay. This is probably my favorite DLC in this game. Another good one is the Age of Charlemagne DLC, it lets you play in a point in time 200~ years after the Western roman empires collapse. Its not anything special, but interesting nonetheless. 

This game is a banger, and if you sat on the fence till now, about this game, Don't, get it, its really fun!

If you are unsure of whether to buy this game or not, go ahead and buy it. This game is the most underrated Total War game in the entire franchise. I will divide my review in sections so read on if you want to learn more about this game.

Battles
The most important part of any total war game is the battles and the battles in this game are great. This is NOT a Rome 2 clone, as many people claim. In this game morale matters in battles - unit moral has been reduced across the board. Flanking and rear charges matter and can rout units. Just like in Rome 1, Medieval 2, and Shogun 2, you can kill the enemy general and rout the rest of the army with flanking and rear charges. Siege battles are awesome again. You can have barricades which you deploy in siege defense battles. Place a unit of archers/slingers/crossbows on top of the barricade and they will fire super fast and get tons of kills. The siege maps are great and allow for all kinds of creative deployments and opportunities. You can legit defeat a full stack with just 4-6 units if you play your cards right.
Cavalry is strong in this game but you still have to use them correctly in order to be effective. Don't stupidly charge headlong into spears/pikes and expect to win. In most melee situations vs melee infantry the cavalry unit will lose. With Cavalry - just like any other total war game - you are looking to make rear charges on engaged units. Even your low tier Cavalry can shred elite units if used in this manner. Horse Archers are back also and are amazing if that is your thing.
Melee infantry isn't useless! If you are coming from Troy/Warhammer/3k this game will be a breath of fresh air when it comes to Melee infantry. Your unit of swordsmen will generally defeat enemy spears and your unit of spears will defeat enemy cavalry. Light offensive focused units like axes also work really well whether fighting in the front line or used as a mobile flanking force. Just make sure these units aren't shot by the enemy archers. Pikes perform admirably in chokepoint scenarios. While spears with the superior melee defense will hold back the enemy for much longer, Pikes can easily and quickly rack up kills on a chokepoint.
Archers, Slingers, and Crossbows are very deadly. Slingers have high base damage and are cheap but don't have specialized ammo types. Archers are also cheap and have access to heavy shot, fire arrows, and whistling shot and have decent fire rate. Crossbows have the slowest fire rate but have huge damage and armor piercing damage. If used to their full extent, Crossbows can easily rack up 400-600 kills in a battle.
Also, Large Onagers using explosive rounds are very overpowered. They will be locked behind technology progression for a large part of the campaign so it doesn't destroy the battle balance. But definitely keep 2-3 of these bad boys in all your late game armies.

Campaign - Settlement Management
There are three things you have balance when you are building out your settlements(or hordes). Sanitation, Food, and Public Order (Integrity for Hordes). If any one of these things are not balance, you will be in for a bad time. Lack Sanitation? Deal with plagues spreading everywhere and especially spreading to your armies. Lack food? A local province lacking food will result in -25% income from the province and loss in public order as well. An overall empire wide food deficit will cause all your armies to attrition and none of your armies will replenish. Lack Public Order (or Integrity)? Revolts.
As the campaign progresses, climate change happens and there is less fertility across the board which results in less food across the board. Food becomes a more scarce resource as the campaign progresses so keep that in mind.
Colonizing and building up razed settlements takes a lot of time and money. If you aren't playing as the Huns you'll have to be wary of which settlements you choose to raze to the ground if you plan to come back later and have that settlement as a part of your empire.
Religion is back in this game and plays an important role. While the public order penalties for religious differences isn't massive, it is something you will need to keep an eye on. Different religions have different religion building which have different effects and the different religions have different global bonuses. Once a religion in your empire reaches 35% adherents you have the option to switch to that religion. As a migratory faction, it is somewhat easier to choose your religion, just pick your first settlements to be where that religion is dominant.

Campaign - Agents
There are three types of agents - Champions, Spies, and Priests. Champions can be embedded into armies and increase their experience. Champions are also excellent for murdering enemy agents. Spies are good for scouting ahead of an army to see whats going on in the fog of war. They also can decrease corruption in your provinces. Priests are mainly for increasing your religion in a province and are also good for increasing public order in a province that needs it.

Camapign - Family Tree
The family tree is back and it is fully operational. Unlike in Rome 2, there are 4 turns every year. What does this mean? You actually have time with your favorite generals and family members to get invested in them and enjoy them. Generally you are trying to gain influence points you can use for political actions. Influence points can be used for seeking a wife, securing loyalty, adopting someone into your family, securing loyalty, embezzling funds, rallying support of nobles/senators and more. Most situations you want Balanced control (50%). There are two ways to gain influence points: actively by winning battles or passively through governorship. 

The Horde!
Attila was the first game to introduce an in-depth horde mechanic and it is wonderfully done. You can think of your armies as essentially mobile cities. Once you go into the encamp stance you will be able to build or demolish buildings just like you can with a regular settlement. If you are short on food can also just pack up and go to a higher fertility place, for example. The Huns/White Huns - who are permanent hordes - will play differently than the great Migrators. The Huns/White Huns are only there to burn down the world and revel in the destruction. If you are playing a Migrator your eventual aim is to find a home to settle down in.

Campaign - The End Game Challenge!
You will be shocked to hear that the end game challenge is.........Attila. I know, surprising. When Attila becomes King of the Huns they essentially become super charged and tend to target the player, especially if you are anywhere in mainland Europe (except Spain). During this time if you wipe out any of their armies they will simply automatically regenerate a new one out in the steppe. Its kind of BS but this is what a late game challenge looks like. Its the ultimate historical trial by fire. There is a big satisfaction and relief once you get through this challenge.

Difficulty
This game spares no punches and wants to kick you while you are down. Don't expect to have an easy time in this game. I myself have over 1000 hours in the game and most of that is playing as the Western Roman Empire. For new players, I suggest playing as one of the barbarian factions (germanic, nordic or celt) or great migrators.

Final Thoughts
Total War Attila is the last great Total War game and I don't say this lightly. Great battles, Functional Family Tree, Fertility, Sanitation, Religion, Atmosphere, and a Tough End Game Challenge. Many people didn't give this game a fair shake due to the poor optimization and the bad taste Rome 2 left. But now its 2023 not 2015, so if you have a modern gaming computer you can play this game. This game is very difficult but it also provides you all the tools you need to succeed. If you have not played this game, play it and give a shot.

Attila was a relatively minor Total War release that was quickly forgotten by its developer. There's little that's special about it. The mechanics are wonky, the combat is nothing special, the graphics are arguably a step back from those of its predecessor, and the engine is a little buggy. The only redeeming characteristic is a couple of its mods, but even the enormous amount of work put into those can't fully redeem this title. It does succeed in portraying the desperation of the dark days surrounding the fall of the Western Roman Empire and the perpetually war-torn landscape of that age, but that's about all it does well. 

5/10.

Even though I have not sunk hundreds of hours into Attila TW, I am fair confident in saying that this might be my favorite TW game. CA clearly went for a game with a more grim feel, and it is well executed. The art direction is very similar to Rome II, but features a colour pallet that is dominated by black, red and orange, like a forest fire, a strong contrast to the typical vivid colours of a TW game. But it is not all show. The grimness also features in the game play. The RTS battles are similar to Rome II, but it arrow fire and cavalry charges are far more deadly, leading to battles with large morale swings and a more tense feel. But the doom and gloom really shines in the campaign map. Unlike other games, where you build up and are unstoppable roughly halfway through the time line, Attila is famously more of a survival game. Ability to destroy entire provinces, the creeping cold climate and constantly respawning nomadic invaders result a map that steadily shrinks, leaving the factions to fight over the land and resources that are left. This not only makes Attila probably the hardest TW game on the campaign level, but also a big change for veterans of the series. It is actually a fairly unique experience in the grand strategy genre generally. Highly recommended game: a game that age like wine and offers a unique and, especially when playing as certain factions, very challenging grand strategy experience.

A tip of the hat for cosmetics and historical accuracy.  But the difficulty level is made extremely high even when playing on "easy" level.  What makes it difficult is being constantly attacked by multiple factions before you can even get your bearings and some sort of foothold.  I've tried playing the Charlemagne campaign, played as Mercia, and as the Sassanids.  And the constant attacks just make the game tiresome.  The attrition is ridiculous and you do lose villages and settlements in these attacks.  You must respond immediately or they just keep attacking until the town is wiped out and captured.  After only 13 hours of trying this game I've lost the urge to continue with it.  Geez, give me a chance to get organized before you attack, will you?  Before I can even upgrade troops I'm losing them to attrition.  When famine hits a province some times there is nothing you can do about it.  Attrition again.   There really is no game play response to disease.  I'm willing to have patience with a strategy game, but the game play in this one is so difficult as to seem impossible.  I didn't even try the harder campaigns.  I found it irritating to make an alliance with the White Huns and then have them turn around and attack me after I did what they wanted.  The peace only lasted two turns.   I might try and play as the Romans but I have a feeling that will be just as frustrating.  Probably both factions of Huns will attack me with multiple armies at the same time.  I know they don't want to make these games easy.  But geez, give a guy a chance.

It's a wild, chaotic ride that will test your strategic skills and your sanity. Just when you think you have a handle on things, a plague breaks out, volcanoes erupt, and half your army deserts to join a circus. The AI is as unpredictable as a fire-breathing dragon with ADHD, keeping you on your toes and laughing in disbelief. So if you're up for a hilarious and challenging journey through the end of the world, grab your shield and prepare for a total "what-the-Attila" experience.

What is Total War Attila?

It is the looming Darkness from the Volga steppes. Proto-Turkic tribes led by the great Gurkhan Attila.

You, a Germanic federate in the service of Rome, ripe with liters of blood washing over the whole village. And behind this scarlet layer of pain and suffering run the nomads. Germanic and Iranian tribes burn the cities of the Empire, enslaving peoples and creating new kingdoms.

Only here will you behold the true Apocalypse and feel the horror of the Scourge of God.

Stayed away for a long time because of the so called, "performance and optimization" issues. Now I know it was never true, glad I finally bought this and can enjoy it.

This game revisits the same era as the original Barbarian Invasion DLC, but somehow it feels like a step backwards. The campaign is a drag - as usual, play hours are inflated by the need to micromanage garrison defenses which have no hope of winning, but won't inflict many casualties unless you sit there in fast-forward watching them die. Waiting for all the enemy factions to go can take upwards of a minute too. The settlement destruction penalties mechanic feels like it wasn't even quality tested, it leads to absurd situations where a victorious army that has just conquered a city gets wiped out easily by an inferior force of counter-attackers, because apparently they are just so disheartened by all the buildings they burned down. About the only thing which has improved is the AI - it's still not good, but it's mastered the art of attacking headlong without a plan, and is less likely to just sit there letting you kill it for free.

Afraid I can't in good faith suggest anyone purchase this. I personally experienced a crash to desktop immediately upon launch. I tried basically every trouble shooting option available and none worked. From a Google check, this seems to have been a consistent issue since 2021 that nobody has found a consistent fix for. Possibly getting hold of legacy drivers may solve the issue but I can't make any guarantee. I wouldn't suggest taking a chance.

[h1] [u] TLDR: [/u] [/h1]
Total War Attila is by far the greatest Historical Total War game CA has ever made. It fixes every problem players had with Rome II's multiplayer and campaign battles (Exploits like pushing through, pike stacking and camping interior settlement citadels do not exist.). Attila has amazing DLC campaigns with loads of extra factions to boot, Very diverse and unique base game factions all of which have their own religions, mechanics, faction/culture traits, unit rosters, play styles, early challenges, start positions and mid/late game crises. [b] DO NOT [/b] listen to people who say this game runs poorly, Attila is one of the best running and performing Total war titles. If you are having issues with your game I promise you the problem is on your end the game is fine (I explain further in the labeled section). If you are worried about the price; Attila and all the dlc for it go on sale multiple times every year for around $25 USD total if you want everything. I encourage you to give this title another try if you picked it up back in 2015 and got burned by the poor launch, this gem is the Total War title many have been asking for, for many years. Its so bright that you can't see it right in front of you. 

[h1] [u] My PC Specs as of this Review: [/u] [/h1]
OS: Windows 11
CPU: Intel Core Processor i9-12900K 8P/16 + 8E 3.20GHz [Turbo 5.2GHz] 30MB Cache LGA1700
GPU: GeForce RTX 3080 10GB GDDR6X (Ampere) (Single Card)
MEMORY (RAM): 32GB (16GBx2) DDR4/3200MHz Dual Channel Memory

[h1] [u] Grand Campaign: [/u] [/h1]
The Grand Campaign takes place in late antiquity starting in the year 395 AD. The theme of the game is that of this time period in history, shortly after the turn of the century the world became dark and cold forcing steppe and germanic peoples to migrate to warmer and more fertile places in the western and southern parts of Eurasia held by the fractured Western and Eastern Roman empires still recovering from The Crisis of the Third-Century. This Campaign is 4 turns per year and features amazing UI, deep family/political system, regional fertility/horde faction mechanics that act as an army and city combined and 14 playable factions within the base game, with another 14 factions being able to unlock for play in the Grand Campaign with dlc culture packs with another 13 factions included in the Campaign packs. The West and Eastern Roman Empires start with large empires both of which are underdeveloped and facing massive public order problems early on. The Western Roman empire has the feel of a classic roman faction sporting elite heavy legionaries, Calvary and crossbow units while The East has a heavy Greek and Eastern Influence on the classic units making their rosters each feel totally unique. The barbarian, hunnic and eastern factions each have their own flare and game play styles pertaining to their cultures, each toting unique units in their rosters that shape their play-styles.

[h1] [u] Mechanics & known misconceptions: [/u] [/h1]
A very common thing I see in reviews of Attila is that combat is very unbalanced and nothing like Rome 2, but it isn't and that's the point. Units all around got far less armor and more health to make battles feel faster and far less like grinding slog fests. For example high armor in Rome 2 was 80+ as where in Attila 55+ is very high armor. This in tune made arrow towers very deadly in sieges making you use your artillery to destroy the settlements fortifications instead of shooting units like a real siege would. There is a clear rock paper scissors counter system with units in this game, spears and swords still perform the same as they did in previous titles. Missile units have massive amounts of utility and counters with different ammo and weapon types ranging from crossbows, short, long and steppe bows, slings, javelins and grenade units. Cavalry feels as cav should, weighty, fast and they have devastating charges, armored melee cav can actually take on non spear melee infantry units and win, shock cav is beyond devastating to unarmored/unbraced infantry however it gets hard countered by melee cavalry. Bow and Skirmisher cav both feel amazing to use in this game and they actually shoot when strafing units with the handy benefit of them being typically faster than other cav units making them perfect for countering cav if you don't like using spears. However all cav will still fall short to armored braced inf, spears and being shot. Axes and shock infantry counter armor and shields but die to missiles and cav, and pike units are almost entirely unarmored and unshielded making them even more vulnerable to missiles than they were in Rome 2. I have heard plenty of people complain that shieldwalls are too strong in this game and this simply isn't true, they are very easily countered. Most sword and especially axe bearing infantry with the shieldwall ability lose Hard to armored tier 2 or 3 sword or axe bearing melee cavalry. You also can simply poke with pikes, shoot them with any kind of missiles (even front dumping shieldwalls is very effective), use two handed shock infantry, or use the previously mentioned axe infantry shielded or two handed it doesn't matter. Axes counter shields and Armour if there is a shieldwall use axes. If the shieldwall has axes use melee cav. Its very simple.

[h1] [u] The Fixed Exploits: [/u] [/h1]
Pulling through in Attila results in the pulled through units being slaughtered in seconds, pike stacking isn't effective anymore because if a pike unit is inside another unit it will take +80% of missile casualties fired at the stacked units. Siege battles can no longer be plagued by players camping interiors of settlements with the settlement destruction mechanics and cycling units to farm charge bonus is no longer effective with units now taking massive casualties (engaged men die) if they try to run from a unit that is engaged in melee with them. As it should be, if you turn your back to a enemy soldier you are getting a sword shoved through you, its very simple. 

[h1] [u] Performance: [/u] [/h1]
I will hit this section with the bat of bluntness. There are 4 reasons your Attila doesn't run well.
1.) Your computer simply isn't strong enough to play Total War games. You might have been able to get away with running Rome 2 on the lowest graphics settings, being that guy to make a 14 minute multiplayer siege last 40 in slow motion. But that won't work here. Attila is a very demanding Total war title I don't deny it, but it runs butter smooth on 6 year old hardware. You can't say the game is the problem when you're playing it on an electric toothbrush. There is no shame in needing to upgrade and not being able to afford it. The economy sucks I know, but my previous point still stands. The game isn't the problem.
2.) Update your graphics card drivers.
3.) Don't use 4k. Attila never got 4k support, so if you use 4k, the game will **** itself. Its not hard to understand. The game looks beautiful without it. You don't need it. Turn it off.
4.) Shadows have a massive impact on performance in Attila, if you are having slight issues, turn your shadows down/off.
If steps 2-4 didn't work and your game still runs horribly, see #1. There is your answer. I have only had Attila crash twice in the combined depressing 1200+ hours i have put into this title on this account and others. The only time I consistently get crashes is when the TW launcher doesn't work (Not Attila's fault) and when I've intentionally broke the game messing with files/mods.

the G.O.D OF TOTAL WARS

Technically this one falls into my category of games I wish there was a neutral recommendation.  This is very much a Total War that I fall into a Love/Hate relationship with and thus it is one I put on its more of a game its hard to recommend or not recommend, since it entirely comes down to the individual, which side wins out more.  This game also has a weird bug that, even after playing it on multiple different systems, it will randomly crash on start up, and you have to just brute force your way to the game successfully starting.

The base game grand campaign is one of the most controversial, between universal climate change that ruins fertility even in historic bread basket regions, way too many buildings pointlessly giving public order penalties, and not being able to share food between regions, meaning your hyper restricted in how you can successfully build each province.  Then add in the Huns faction has one of the most ridiculous cheats any AI in Total War has ever gotten of instantly respawning hordes until you can kill Attila.  Then add in that the AI is too raze happy and too slow to recolonize desolate ruins that tends to ruins the end game and makes the game have a ridiculous front loaded difficulty.  Further add in some moronic decisions like not letting you control where your capital is, which is especially bad for Horde factions where your capital can be bounced to a ruin you've recolonized, just because that is where the game assigned your original capital.  There is further some unacceptable quality control bugs such as some missing settlement slots, and certain unit trees such as the Alans being broken without using a mod.  The AI also blatantly cheats with how accurate its artillery pieces are, compared to the player's, especial above normal combat difficulty.  Further there are some units that just plain feel redundant to useless in the same faction, given they compete for the same slot, and sometimes a tier 2/3 unit actually feels weaker than a tech tree upgraded tier 1.

The game does however have some good points.  Age of Charlemagne is one of the best DLC campaigns, since Fall of the Samurai.  The family tree is interesting, even if its majorly flawed, such as people randomly disappearing from both your family and other nobles, a lack of a seek husband for female descendants, and other nobles not naturally replenishing.  Different religions actually give you different bonuses and have a choice between a public order and special effect for many religions for your building.  Compared to the Warhammer Total Wars, it is also nice having a game where cavalry can actually do something worth taking up an army slot.

I want to say some good things about this game, but I can't. Optimization is horrible. Total War games (at least since Empire) always have unreasonable results, when it comes to system requirements/performance ratio. According to the requirements, a lot of players, including myself, should play Attila not less than on high settings, with a stable high fps. This is not a thing here. Attila is on another level of bad optimization. Huns brought chaos and destruction not only to Rome, but also to common players. Add to this TW classic campaign map lag feature (even when battle fps is decent) and turn times (not bad in Attila but campaign lag + optimization made it worse).

I wish that they made a new patch. I mean, Rome II is an old game, and it received support in 2018. New DLC, patches.
Attila has many gameplay related improvements. Could have been one of my top 3 TW games. For now, just no.

I would recommend this with a word of caution to those that are still in the introductory phase with Creative Assembly games.  Attila is built a bit different from all of the other Total War titles and if you are not aware of this it could ruin your first play through.  All Total War games, for the most part, are empire building games.  Attila is an empire survival game.  AI cheats in this game are heavy, even when comparing to other titles and it is home to what is arguably the single most difficult Total War campaign out of all the games (Western Roman Empire).  Be prepared for a different experience with this compared to other CA games.  It is by far not my favorite Total War but is in that category of "I don't care for it that much but I understand why others do."

Attila Total War is a great game that captures the bleakness and hopelessness of the time period. The game can be difficult to learn, especially if it's your first Total War title. The food, sanitation/squalor system, religion system, and family tree system can be difficult to understand. The game can also get a little tedious, and there's not a profound difference between certain factions. However, the dynamic battles, strengths/weaknesses of different types of units, and the capturing of the truly bleak look of the period make up for these shortcomings. The migrations/horde mechanics and the Age of Charlemagne expansion are also great additions to the game. All in all, Attila Total War has quite a bit of replay value and is a must-play for seasoned Total War players.

My favorite Total War game. Well polished, with a simple yet deep gameplay. The extra detail put into making the political system so functional, yet uncomplicated allows for a diverse gamestyle beyond the rote "kill and conquer" style. The affects of religion, conversion, and the cultural makeup of the civilian populations works in synthesis with the diplomacy, and makes for interesting and unique playthroughs. The consistent chaos construed by the Huns puts Eastern/Central Europe in constant flux, making no two games quite the same, even if one replays the same faction. And not to forget that there are different rules for different factions, including nomadic factions with hordes (think army-cities that move around), rather than the basic city-based game of traditional Total War. I would definitely recommend for history fans and beginners of Total War alike.

After just completing the Mercian campaign (Age of Charlemagne DLC) on H/H, I would call this my most enjoyable [i]historical[/i] Total War play-through yet.  Victories in Attila, and especially the Age of Charlemagne feel deep, hard won, and more sophisticated than a simple rush to conquest.  Most starting positions are embattled, require thoughtful planning and battle mastery to preserve troops, nurture economy, forge alliances.  The art and score are beautiful.  The settings and objectives are compelling.  The war weariness feature definitely adds another enjoyable layer of immersion.  

Of note, this was my first non-"paint the map" campaign victory.  For the first time ever, it seemed like the diplomacy system actually worked: I wanted originally to take Northumbria, but they became a staunch ally, actually defending me from Norman invasions, something I've never experienced in a Total War game before. How weird is it to see an ally's full stacks march past your undefended capitol, defeat the invading army for you and then march back to York?  When they crossed the border, I thought "here we go again," meaningless Total War treaties at play, but no.  I actually felt motivated to [i]not[/i] declare war on the Franks or the Northumbrians because they had been such loyal defenders, and work my conquest around their territories, picking off mutual enemies.

Also, the Imperium system actually makes composite cultural/conquest victories possible: another first in a Total War game for me.  My final map was a patchwork of allies and owned territories that really makes you feel as though you're witnessing the birth of medieval Europe. The internal political system seemed less like a mini-game (I'm looking at you Rome II), and more an actual part of the campaign from which meaningful advantages could be derived.

Tactical battle play was as as excellent as ever.  Siege battles in particular felt like step-by-step strategic puzzles.  The AI behaves at least as well as I imagine a moderately competent historical general might.

Overall A+ gaming experience.  Attila is my favourite of the historical titles thus far.

Honestly, I'm not a guy who puts lots of time into games. I don't game all the time, nor would I consider myself "skilled" at many games. 

However, Attila, and frankly a few other Total War titles still keep me entertained from time to time. 

Cons
-Can be difficult to learn (especially if this or Rome II is your first title)
-food, sanitation/squalor system can be difficult to understand
-religion is a weird system in this game
-family tree system can be a little challenging to navigate at first (I found it markedly different from Rome II, and it seems to be exploited by the AI quite often)
-can get a little tedious
-not a profound difference between certain factions
-towards the end of the game it gets a little boring
-Attila, and his so-called "Horsemen of the Apocalypse" can be wiped out if you adequately prepare for him
-certain factions, such as the ERE, Sassannid, other Eastern Empires can be extremely OP, especially in MP
-Age of Charlemagne is a cool addition, but frankly too simple

Pros
-If you figure out how to play the "barbarian" factions (Norsemen, Migrators, Celts, Slavs, etc.), it can be a neat experience for the time period
-the idea behind simply surviving the time period as opposed to a straight-up triumph is different
-dynamic battles
-truly, the strengths/weakness of the different types of units are properly understood and exploited (e.g, you WILL wipe out a cav unit with a well-timed counter-charge and spear/pike unit)
-the capturing of the truly bleak look of the period
-migrations/horde mechanics
-Age of Charlemagne, again albeit simple, it isn't necessarily a bad addition to the game (however, I believe it should've gotten its own title altogether)
-watching your enemy's settlements get turned to total ash, and then slaughtering the defenders feels, oddly right, in this game

Review:

All in all, I think Attila is great. I personally have completed a campaign as the Picts, twice as the Geats, and as the ERE. Truly, the bleakness and hopelessness of the time period is very well captured, in that once Attila shows his face on the steppes of Eastern Europe, you feel a pit in your stomach of uncertainty, and unnerving of what is going to happen. My first Geat campaign saw me become the unchallenged Latin Christian Northern Empire, protecting the WRE and ensuring the ERE would not be destroyed in conflict with the Sassannids. My Pictish campaign was all about taking revenge on the evil Germanic raiders coming to pillage and destroy my dear Brittannia. My ERE campaign practically saw me become a true superpower, bringing Christ's Word to every corner of the world. 

I think if you can figure out how to work around the religion system, and the sanitation/squalor balance, as well as the new horde mechanics along with keeping people happy in times of despair, it could be considered a darker Rome II for seasoned Total War players. If this is your first title, have patience as the truly different playstyles of each cultural group are highlighted and exploited well in this game. As such, it has quite a bit of replay value in that you could try a replicate good-luck in a particular campaign. 

Summary:
The new mechanics combined with the overall challenging nature of the game really capture the hoplessness of the time period. All in all, with a few neat mechanics and nice systems that are added to the series, Attila isn't as bad as everyone thought it was. Stands to be a really interesting game if you allow yourself to be immersed in the play.

بس الحين لا نظرتي اختلفت بعد تجربتي الجادة لها، بالعكس المعارك يا فيها من التكتيكات والإستراتيجيات لدرجة ممكن بكتائب قليلة جداً تنهي جيش كامل بل وممكن تنتصر في معركة حصار لقلعة بعدد قليل!!

وفيها من التاريخ العربي الكثير مثل الأنباط وسبأ وحمير وتنوخ واللخميون وتدمر ومصر وكوش وقرطاج وإمارة قرطبة ونوميديا للبربر،
 البعض في توتال وار أتيلا والبعض في روم 2.

بالنسبة لأتيلا، الجزء هذا يتميز بالجرافيكس الحلو، المباني واضحة رسوماتها وملونة، رسومات الوحدات قريبة للواقع وملونة (على عكس روم 2)، حقبة جميلة، فيها إمارة قرطبة وحمير والمناذرة وتنوخ والحروب القوية بين الساسان والرومان والروم منقسمة بين بيزنطة الشرقية وروما الغربية وفيه الفايكنق وشارلمان وقبائل الهون المتهورين بقيادة أتيلا الأسوأ من قودزيلا اللي لعب بأوروبا لعب ومن الطفش غزا فرنسا.

بس بصراحة لو المطورين اشتغلوا بالماب أكثر وحطوا آثار زي مدائن صالح بالحجاز والبتراء يعني زي فكرة الإهرامات بمصر
+ ولو اجتهدوا في إضافة الطابع الثقافي لكل دولة في قلاعها ومدنها بحيث لما تبدأ المعركة تشوف الثقافة الخاصة بهم بمبانيهم وكذا
لكن للأسف تلقى المدن تشبه بعض، اللهم الشغل على روما والقسطنطينية تلقى آثار فيها.

المهم إن اللعبة أنصح بها واللعب أون لاين شيق وممتع.

- Decent diplomacy system.

- Dark and brutal early medieval setting full of intresting factions.
- Makes me feel like a warlord or a King everytime I play it.
- Great land and naval battles.Best in the series for me.
- Probably the most difficult total war out there.

Cons :
- A few minor errors such as descriptions of trait describing a male character while a trait - belong to a female character.
- There are some occasions where AI is being stupid,although it isn't very frequent.
- Sometimes game won't start on first attempt.
- Attila needing to be defeated even as many times as 6 to be finally killed is a little too much.Not a big issue though.

Would recommend.

This game can be great, but is poorly optimized on windows.  GPU and CPU usage is constantly low forcing you to turn down settings to get at least get a stable 60 FPS on 1080p or higher res (I tested bn 12900k, 4090 at 4k, and 9900kf, 3090 on 1440p).  The game struggle in full screen mode and really is only playable on windowed mode which is not for everyone.  Overall, the game itself is not bad, but it runs off an old engine and struggles to keep up with modern hardware.  Cannot recommend in this state.

One of the more underrated series of the Total War franchise which is worth it.

Loved the dark tone which was fitting for the era. It was way more challenging than it's predecessor, I mean enough said when your campaign objective is simply to survive. Beating the Roman campaigns should be on a bucket list for every Total War fan out there :D A lot of mechanics I wish Rome 2 had were added too.

The DLCs were more than decent, Age of Charlemagne felt like a game of its own and less like a DLC so worth it. Also there is an awesome MOD for it which is basically the current Medieval 3 as far as I am concerned and you should try it out after you are done with vanila.
nice.

I have played this over 8000 hours. It is the 3rd TW game i have played extensively. It is the best. I really like the royal family/nobles' families dynamics...it feels more personal to me when I know who the family is, and what is good and bad about each character. I really like the way the game can be played VERY different ways: Starting as a horde vs normal tribe vs desert tribe vs Viking tribe vs Tannukhids fs Roman Empires is very different from one another. ALSO, the wide geographic range of starting locations makes a BIG difference. I like how there are medium, large and grand victories, and I like how religion affects the game and the victory conditions. The graphics are very nice. I like how there are more diplomatic choices, and the various choices of what to do with a zone when you have conquered it. I really like how some territories give you different bonuses, and detriments. I like how there is a scarcity of resources, so you have to plan what nations to own/control.

I would HIGHLY recommend this to:
Any TW veteran
Anyone wanting to try TW for the first time
Anyone who is interested in the Fall of the Roman Empire
Anyone who is interested in the Eastern Roman Empire/Horde civs/Desert vs Viking civs/Mediterranean civs/History buffs from this timeframe/Atilla/The Huns/games like Civilization where you build up your civ.

Total War Attila is a game as vast as an ocean, but as deep as a puddle. For all of the seemingly complex looking stats and data on the map, it all really boils down to having lots of food, having buildings that increase happiness, and having strong cavalry for battles.

Battles are no better either, almost anime-like in how you can hide a few morons in an incredibly sparse forest and suddenly they turn invisible. Cavalry is the most overpowered its ever been in Total War which I'm aware is quite the statement, however, not only can cavalry annihilate an entire unit, they can simply move out and slam themselves in to the next group of hapless melee infantry. This would be fine, if cavalry also wasn't unfairly strong in straight up head-to-head melee. In Total War, one of the few weaknesses cavalry has is its vulnerability in extended melee. Nope, doesn't exist here anymore. 

Battles are won by how has the better units / more cavalry, leaving zero room for actually fun, strategic and tactical gameplay and turning the game in to an, "I have stronger units so fuck you," simulator.

A 4/10 experience.
