Pretentious twaddle passing as a 'serious strategy game'. Boring and extremely punitive, taking away all initiative and creativity and forcing players to only play one way, squirrelling resources and getting shafted over and again and controlled while creeping forward in the game under the delusion of being a 'great strategist'.

There are plenty of units to recruit but don't bother. The cavalry is absolutely unnecessary since overwhelming majority of battles will be fought in the narrow streets of cloned primitive villages. The only battle tactic i could notice was to mass archers and try to shoot the enemy in the back. Matter of fact, archers are the only useful units, even your elite infantry will either get pulverised by two low level archery units or just run in panic. Just get a few mid level heavy infantry units to hold the enemies in place while your archers go around to shoot them in the back. That's it.

Enough has been said about the Huns and their pestilential harassment. Playing a lot of other factions, you're supposed to raid, the wild late antiquity/early middle ages don't you know, but good luck replenishing in the field leading to your only viable option becoming mercs which cost an eye, kidney, liver, lungs and your great grandchildren's inheritance to maintain or going back home to fetch fresh cannon fodder. As a Dane raiding Britain, i had to sail back to Denmark to replenish my troops! And guess what, while you're away, public disorder and ensuing rioting/civil war has prepared a few turns worth of order restoration. By the time you manage to restore order and monetary sanity, the peasants are ready to go again. Very serious and historically accurate game, don't you know. Peasants ruled middle ages!

That's the most hilarious part, you're supposed to be a period accurate feudal despot but can't wage war past a few turns before the 'electorate' start to voice their displeasure of the realm being at war yet again! 
"Bring the boys back home"!!!
Regular updates about the worsening mood while urging you to make peace as soon as possible, The Daily Feudal Bugle i guess, making management of your fiefdom more like an exercise in 21st century paranoid opinion poll driven democracy. 
"All we're saying, is to give peace a chance...."

The overall 'strategy' is very simple, start a minor war, raid a few close by territories, capture or loot, quickly make peace before the 'voters' get pissed off and start a new civil war, wait for things to calm down, squirrel more resources and start a new short round of conflict.........
Rinse and repeat and thou shall enjoy this 'historically accurate and very serious game'. Fun, you won't have. 
BTW, this approach applies to all factions. All of them. 

Just do as your'e told and you'll be fine. 
The old days of Total War when you could be creative and try multiple approaches in finding new novel ways of beating the odds and just let go and have fun are long gone. That is why the strategy genre is all but dead, it's not just Total War.

This is one of the games with potential but CA didn't commit enough love to it.  Vanilla game isn't worth it, but DLC campaign packs and MOSTLY the mods make it the best historical TW.

+MODS, there are plenty of overall mods, The Dawnless days(LOTR), MK 1212 (Medieval 3), Ancient Empires etc. which transforms the game from mediocre to GREAT
+ interesting time period, atmosphere of falling Empires, climate change, feels like survival game (both Roman Empires on Legendary)
+ best siege battles in all TW, top battles in historical TW
+ enjoyable full cavalry Horde gameplay for COOP campaign

+/- lot of interesting campings mechanics, like Slavs, but mostly locked behind DLC

- poor optimization
- bad mechanics, like corruption punishing you for expansion, or development tree
-AI, in battles it has a tendency to create big unit blops... 
  In campaign it's even worse, AI is utterly incompetents, with no sense for survival, existing only to annoy and irritate you by sacking and razing your cities (which takes forever to repair), so you end up chasing enemy armies across your territory, bc AI will avoid your armies and try to disengage or won't attack unless it have 75 % advantage against you
- Ridiculous diplomacy, Alliances are just to drag you to wars, never to help you, even allies with few hundred positive points in reputation, declaring war to you or each other when battle or city is lost,  when you declaring a war, randomly on some turn threshold or just for no reason at all. You will end up with enemies on the other side of the map, or your close ally betraying  you just to sack your city and then sue for peace.

The last great historical Total War experience.

It's dark.  It's gritty.  It's not easy, especially at first.  

EXCELLENT BATTLES
The units have a crunchy weight to them, a sweet spot that neither the older nor the newer Total War games  have seem to have hit.  The physics just feel right, from the smashing impact of a heavy calvary charge to the satisfying thud of javelin striking home.  The animations are solid, and the combat is entertaining to watch.
Sieges become methodical - probing attacks until you find a weakness, then hitting it with combined arms and pushing into the second level.  The AI does an admirable job defending, again, in a way that later games seem to struggle with.
Field battles are dynamic and exciting, with varied terrain and generated maps.

CAMPAIGN
The campaign map is almost exactly the right density.  Enemies range from norse vikings to african tribes, with everything in between.  Buildings typically have negative and positiive attributes, so region and province design forces you to make tradeoffs and find the right balance. The family and political systems are thoughtfully designed and organized, so it is easy to understand what is going on, why, and what your options are.  It invites role playing and gives you a sense of the leaders involved, their personalities, and their strengths.  You feel it when a high ranking general or governor is killed. Technology and pacing is spot on.

OVERALL
The value is here.  With some world class overhaul mods, numerous utility and tuning mods, graphical and unit mods, the re-playability is damn near endless.  Which is good, because CA hasn't delivered a hard core historical strategy game like this since.  I am sure it will be supplanted by one of the upcoming historical TW games, at some point.  But for me, Attila reigns supreme.

Arguably the best historical Total War since Medieval 2. Each faction feels like an entirely new campaign experience and there are quite a few culture types to choose from. Battles, and sieges in particular, are some of the best of the series. The two DLCs, Last Roman and Age of Charlemagne are incredible in their own right. The only downside of the game, in my opinion, was CA's greedy choice to make certain culture types and blood and gore paid DLCs. The game also suffers from being poorly optimized on older GPUs. The mod scene for the game is incredible and some mods like 1212 AD feel like a whole different game entirely. 9/10 Overall.

Taking command of a dying empire that fighting desperately and ferociously with its last breaths, aka playing as Western Roman Empire, is one of the greatest experiences I’ve ever had in a Total War title. Rebels, Saxons, Franks, Vandals, Angles, Longbeards, Jutes, Alamans, Quadians, Garamantia, Mauria, Ebdanians, Picts, Caledonians, Suebians, Goths, and if you managed to survive, Huns... Perfectly describes the Western Roman Empire in that era.

Was hoping CA would have been able to learn from issues Rome 2 had, but apparently not. 

"Oh you have increased the difficulty? Well now you have to deal with single settlement factions throwing two full armies at you when they have a gross income of 400 gold. What's that, you want diplomacy that makes sense? How about a random faction you haven't interacted with declare war on you every 5 turns even though they have no reason to dislike you."

Higher difficulty also seems to make your units suddenly retreat when winning their fight in battles, or cause LIGHT skirmishers to annihilate your HEAVY infantry by magic.

Also nice to see CA still hasn't fixed the bug from Medieval 2 where units will just straight up ignore commands you give them. It's really nice to have a plan thought out, but then I get flanked because 3 units are standing in place out of combat and not rushing to protect a weak spot or something.

Edit:
To better emphasize the stupid bug of units not doing what you tell them to. I had one battle where I was trying to get a couple Onagers to break open some gates. I command them to attack the gates, but they need to move up to be in range. They move up, then move up and move up until they are at the foot of the gates and done even fire on the gate. After repeating the attack order multiple times they did not change course

Gotta say i legit do recommend this game, but the issues it has are hyper frustrating.

 The campaigns are good, as are the sounds and battles, but one thing that almost breaks the game for me is the paint huffing brained AI. 

If you play as a Rome, eastern or western,  it is guaranteed that your other roman faction member will start to kill itself in an instant. I find myself restarting games often because Western Rome loses almost (if not) all of Gaul by 403 along with a lot of Illyria, or Eastern Rome most of Thracia or half of the Levant by the same time. So you may be thinking "well, just send an army to help them bit by bit right?", well, to get rid of the barbarians who took settlements, you have to occupy all of them (or all -1 then subjugate), but then that means you as Eastern Rome will end up owning land in Gaul or wherever your ally is losing, driving up expenses. And that's if your faction partner didn't just leave half of their land completely desolate, something they won't re-take because creating one is somehow more expensive than 2 full armies + a max level building or 2. 
 So you may be then thinking "just subjugate them then?", well, the ones you subjugate will randomly turn hostile out of nowhere unless you leave an army at their capital and do all you can do improve relations, and even still they might turn anyway. Also forget holding Britannia as the west. This leads to a complete cluster that makes it so you basically have no ally, because you just get dragged into a million wars as your ally can't handle diplomacy. 

If you get lucky, though, and your ally doesn't "collapse" in 30 turns, you're in for a great experience. All of this isn't to say the game isn't fun as it is even with the previously mentioned issues - because it is fun. it's kind of pointless to be anticipating Atilla invading the West - when there is no west, or vice versa.
While the games as some problems and bugs it's overall a great game. If you enjoy a difficult campaign then you will enjoy the game.

As someone who loves the historic period that this game takes place. Playing as one of the different cultures (while not as expansive as Rome 2) offers a different strategy depending which culture you pick. An example of this is when you play as either the Western or Eastern Roman Empire as it will test you on your management skills and knowing when to fight or give ground to your enemies. While playing as one of the many migrating tribes will test you on solidifying your position in one of the many land within the Western Roman Empire. In short the game is a great with its challenges and offers players choice to rebuild the Roman Empire or see to the whole world burn. 

The DLC's for this game has its highs and low such as the Empires of Sand and Age of Charlemagne are worth their price and offers a lot of replayability. While DLC's such as Viking Forefathers and Longbeards offers six more germanic tribes and isn't really worth the price for reskinned germanic units.

My experience with this game summarised by thoughts: 

Okay, attack, take this city, politics.

Just like the other decent Total War games.

Then, oh - btw, the huns are coming.

Whatever, I got a huge army, I'm just gonna finish this war.

The Huns are still coming.

Okay I'm going to get one and show them what's what.

Thy HUNS ARE HERE.

OMG... what is going on!? How can you even do anything?

*remembers, Visigoths*

*Asks: "What would the visigoths do?"

Remembers: Right! They fled and encroached on/bargained/negotiated with Rome...

Next turn, advisor: Soooo... it doesn't seem like the Huns are stopping... what say you we let's get out of here? I heard the Romans are a target...

Me: Historically accurate <3

A highly underrated Total War title, Total War: Attila offers a unique gameplay experience that stands alone among total war games. Turning the tables entirely on certain core gameplay mechanics regarding expansion and governance, the player is forced to reconsider their approach toward maintaining or building an empire in an atmosphere that is nigh apocalyptic with the incoming invasion of the Huns. Total War: Attila is definitely worth playing for a unique, challenging Total War experience.

A total war game set in one of the most chaotic and interesting periods of European history, but one that suffers from severe, primarily campaign game related issues which make this the most disappointing entry in the total war franchise. This game does not embody the classic empire building essence or spirit of Rome 1 or Medieval 2. The AI as featured in the campaign is possibly the most inept, directionless and ultimately irritating AI ever to be featured in a total war game. No faction is remotely capable of building a substantial empire and establishing themselves as 'the faction to beat', instead merely marauding and constantly harassing you as the player until they are destroyed by the Huns. Overall, a frustrating and changeless game with regards to the campaign, but with reasonable enjoyable battles and a truly excellent DLC in the way of 'The age of Charlemagne'.

A somewhat hesitant thumbs up. This game really needed a few more patch passes like Rome 2 got to really polish it up, as is the lack of unit variety and sometimes clunky unit mechanics stick out in an otherwise very solid and different from the usual Total War game.

As is, this is the closest thing we'll get to Medieval 3 for a while. The DLC Age of Charlemagne even more so, and the modding scene brings us closer.

Once again, Fuck you Sega for your DLC. Yet more content that used to be in the game as standard cut out to sell us later.

*Edit: There are a few battle changes that make no sense to me, and never appear in other TW games. Why is there no guard mode? Why do I have to babysit all my units to stop them running off? Why have all ranged units forgotten how to fire over my own units? Why have 4 ammo types for archers when you'll only ever use 2? Why does the AI get the automatically set units to loose formation under fire, and I don't? This game is crying out for one last update to fix the combat to the same high standards as all the other games in the series.

I am a 58 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he friended and invited me to join him. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Fun game. Leans more on the difficult side of the Total War series which I appreciate. Unfortunately, there is a major issue with this game. During campaigns, at ~20-100 turns, the game will crash and the save is corrupted. That by itself is already enough of a problem, but where it is truly unacceptable is during Legendary campaigns. Legendary campaigns cannot have saves made for them, instead they simply autosave at the end of a turn or before a battle. This results in the crash completely ruining a campaign, without the ability to loading a previous save and hopefully not experiencing the previous crash. I have had multiple Legendary campaigns completely ruined by this issue. This is not related to mods because I scarcely use mods (<10 mods used during campaigns), and just to be sure I attempted an entirely vanilla Legendary campaign and still experienced the same crashes. I have uninstalled and reinstalled this game, verified integrity, etc and still have this issue. If you plan on playing the campaign of this game, do it only on Very Hard or lower, and save frequently.

This is the previous review I had written for the store page (I literally edited the same comment):

The best Total War game, IMO. Great setting — not quite what we think of as classical ancient Rome, and not quite what we think of as medieval times. It's that weird "in between" times, the migration period, the fall of Rome, the rise of the peoples of northern and continental Europe.  The early dark ages. 

It is both 100% a history game, while also having the themes and ambience of a fantasy game; the darkness of the apocalypse, the end of an age. 

The factions feel different, and have a great variety of units. (If you do care about dlcs, then this game also has probably the best, largest variety to choose from in terms of new factions). 

The map is massive, from central Asia to Spain, from Sweden down to the Sahara. 

It is challenging, but in my opinion it isn't unfair. In single player, the largest empires are struggling just as much as saxon newcomers. 

Factions really are tailored to different types of gameplay, making it a very replayable game. But, in my opinion, on the whole the single player campaign favors caution over aggression, unless you are the Huns or White Huns, which do not "settle" territory, but are nomadic armies with mobile camp-settlements. But even if you are a smaller, migratory faction like the Suebi, the game will encourage you to get going... don't, necessarily. Be cautious, wait, be purposefully slow, think. 

My only real criticism is the naval battles, but it doesn't affect my liking of the game whatsoever. Only Empire and Napoleon did that right. Get this game.

One of the greats in Total War history. I have a bias for Shogun 2, but, put that game aside and this one is actually my favorite. Attila is absolutely one of the most well thought out and most beautiful Total War games. Good strategic options and pretty solid diplomacy, a great sound track and excellent sound design. Battles are fun even in vanilla and I often play without any mods. 
This game holds up fantastically well on its own. There are a huge amount of factions available and a highly detailed and beautiful map, many units and mercenary units to recruit and a ton of overall faction variety.

Please don't skip this one, it is one of the fullest offerings in the entire series, it has great base content and even the DLC is worth it, mostly. This is a buy for any fan of history and really anyone who enjoys a massive campaign with many compelling hours of gameplay.

I really enjoy this title. It had a few bugs at launch but these have mostly been fixed. If you like strategy games then give this a go. It would suit both real time tactical and turn based strategy type players. In the campaign you can auto resolve the battles or fight them yourself which is a good option because you may not have the time to fight every battle.

I'm not a fan of the newer titles; Total War Hammer because it all seems a bit silly. I don't think i'm alone in this regard so many people have been moding Attila to make it better. Some of them have done some amazing work! Check out the Steam Workshop for a mod after you've played the game for a bit.

I rate it 8/10 without mods and 9.5/10 with them.
Edit 25.08.22: This is the second best value for money game I have in my Steam library. Total War Three Kingdoms is far ahead in first place with 2278 hours played for $100 spent.

You can lead your own armies; each one is able to hold up to 3,200 men (Infantry/Missile can hold 160 men in a unit-Cavalry 80 men in a unit- Artillery can hold 40 men in a unit).  You can play as countless different civilizations starting from the year 395 AD (The beginning of the Western Roman Empire Collapse) and change the course of history.  Each Faction has its own traits and technologies (Studying these can give you military, economic, and public order benefits).  You can engage in diplomacy (Trade, war, pact, creating puppets states, etc).  You can control every units placements on the battlefield (Place em on a hill, ambush your enemies like the Germanic barbarian you are (Don't repeat Varus's mistake), or engage the enemy using in fair open battle.  Siege warfare includes battering rams, ladders, and siege towers, and a bit of artillery for fun (watch them walls crumble on the enemy).  Build your empire through fire and blood.  And let your name be the scourge of all other Empires.

Western Roman Empire campaign on a legendary level is very challenging and gives you a lot of fun. I don't recall any other TW campaigns where you have to literally survive for so many turns. At one point I became too confident as I fixed internal problems and got rid of almost every annoying neighbor and it cost me 5 cities in Pannonia and the Balkans as the Huns just wiped out my weak and unprepared legions (I relied on cheap and not updated units for too long as that was enough to win against barbarians) and burned them to the ground.

Highly recommend

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Total War Rome 2 was like a test case for the new generation of TW titles. R2 brought a massively expanded effects scope as well as many new effect types. What it means is your campaigns should be more rich with consideration, however, Rome 2 somewhat failed with the new more complicated character system, it was often counter intuitive and confusing. Too many effects types, can't track them all. But TW Attila on the other hand, succeeded where Rome 2 failed. The User interface managing your characters, your faction politics, and other elements have been updated for ease of use and clarity. Rome 2 was the test case Attila is the success case.

To get straight to the point, this game makes me angry as much as much as it entertains.  
Main reasons is the Huns and Diplomacy.
I Understand the Huns are suppose to be terrifying and Difficult to defeat,but they end up being more annoying then terrifying. Mainly because of the cheats they get , endless spamming full stacks ,made of elites by the mid game and constantly chasing yo around the map no matter where you go, completely stopping replenishment when in your province, and my favorite getting endless money and not having to actually build an economy.

Diplomacy 
Everyone hates you, so no one will trade with you even if its in their favor, non- aggression pacts and allies never last when you need them too, and all of this is because of negative multipliers like being a Great Power, which personally doesn't  make sense to me.

To sum up
I do like many of the features in this game , Horde mode, Religion Changes, climate change. etc.
They bring me back to this game for a short stint, until i inevitably get too annoyed and put it down again.

Ultimately if that is something you can put up with ,then have fun and don't let me stop you.

As all Total War games, in the end, this shit is tedious and boring. And I hate saying this, because on papers these games would be the everything I wish for in a strategy game. I personally think that the problem lies in the concept of the grand campaign itself; they are too long, and as such, you often find yourself in the place in which the novelty wore off but you still "have to play" to win the game. For example, in this game my longest campaign is with the Western Roman Empire, probably the most difficult faction to win with; the first 30-40 turns (around 30 hours of gameplay i would say) were cool af. I had to immediatly retreat to safe regions, and then battle between internal rebellions and external invasions from barbarians, with Attila looming in the distance. That was epic. But once i survived the initial onslaught, the game quickly transformed into "take army, attack city, autoresolve, occupy". Even the BBEG, Attila, at the end of the day was just a "find his army, isolate it, autoresolve, kill" x3. What I was doing at the start of the game was the same thing i was doing in the end, just with bigger armies, bigger distances and bigger enemies. If you win a 20 to 1 battle once, it's epic; if you have to do it 15 times, it's just annoying and boring; same is true for quelling rebellions, rebuilding/optimising cities, reorganising armies and so on.

The game, as all total wars, can't escape the inevitable "sameiness" that imo plagues the series, consequence of the fact that during a campaign you are fundamentally doing the same thing over, and over, without any meaningful variation, but slower and slower. So much so that I started 10 different campaigns and ended them after max 15 turns as i felt no difference to what I was doing in the 150+ turns of the WRE one. Had the game some mini campaigns, short and to the point, I feel this problem wouldn't be felt as much. But as the game basically requires you to do a world conquer, you have to either waste 50 hours engaging in the same gameplay or cut it short, leaving with an unsatisfactory feeling of "uncompleted".

Imo, there are better ways to spend your free time. Not recommended.

I really enjoy the game.  The horde mechanic is really interesting, and I appreciate that it is balanced to be more of an empire management game rather than a paint-the-map game unlike previous Total War games.

Unfortunately, the graphics engine is buggy as heck.  I run a laptop with Intel Xe integrated graphics which has so far been able to handle any other game I've tried albeit at low-res settings.  This game just either crashes or freezes, however.  I'm usually able to squeak in a single turn before it does and manage to play by quick saving continuously.  Gets really frustrating at times, though, especially when it freezes up before I can save after a battle.

You might say that the issue is trying to run it on an integrated graphics card, but again, I've run games like Civilization 6, Two Point Hospital, Cities: Skylines, and Skyrim without issue.  The problem is in the game's engine, not the hardware.  So buyer beware.

I played Rome 2 for a long time, and I think this one has better battles and a cooler scenario, for sure. Cavalry really hits hard and has the sort of effect you'd expect: charging horse vs man = horse wins. Unless, of course, the men are holding 16ft long pikes pointed at the horses' chests. That works as you'd expect too. Overall, the combat feels a lot better. The graphics are much better, albeit a little janky sometimes. It's really cool playing as one of my favorite historical figures: King Alaric of the Visigoths. The mass migration mechanics and the concept of the Huns upsetting everyone in Europe is really fun to experience. This is a really solid game that I hope gets a few performance tweaks and patches to make it perfect.

Attila is Total War's severely underrated and long-lost iteration. In my view, it's because of Attila's challenging or sometimes unbalanced gameplay and different approach from other Total War games that Attila is the best Total War game and one of the best strategy games ever made.

What does Attila do so well? In a sentence: no other strategy game even comes close to the thematic and historical immersion Attila creates. I didn't think it was possible for a strategy game to have serious storytelling and such historical depth. Total War games can either be fun tactical and strategy sandboxes or they can be like Attila and create a thematic and narrative tale that uses the grand strategy genre as a means to an end.

What's incredible is that this immersion is not just achieved by sprinkling some funny-looking UI and a soundtrack on an average Total War game (though Attila's soundtrack is a masterpiece!), far from it, Attila uses all aspects of the game to create immersion. From the main menu to both the strategic and tactical gameplay, Attila highlights its apocalyptic themes and aesthetics all throughout its gameplay. Though many criticize its challenging and decentivizing gameplay where any decision you make has some negative consequences and it's really a matter of making the "least worst decision", I actually think this element adds to the themes and historiticity of Attila as a game. In short, Attila's gameplay, as difficult as it is, is intertwined with its goal of immersion and storytelling.

So if you're looking for a balanced and laid-back Total War game where you paint the map with your samurai, knights, or fantastic dinosaur mages, Attila is not for you. But if you're interested in historical authenticity or want to try out a unique and original grand strategy experience that uses Total War gameplay for storytelling, Attila is perfect.

The historical setting is interesting, with a great deal of religious and military diversity (loved the Sassanids and African factions), and the dynamics of climate change pose a nice challenge for a long campaign. Managing provinces is not made easy by the need to consider squalor as well as food, a nice touch but it requires a great deal of care. Diplomacy is ok, but managing the family tree and the court positions is overly complex, and the accumulation of random negative personal traits tend to become annoying. Battles tend to go too quickly because troops have limited resilience, and naval encounters are usually very destructive  (ramming is great but fire is overpowered). You can easily inflict a massive amount of missile friendly fore damage if you are not careful, the AI in this respect is very stupid. Battles are not as well balanced as in Shogun II, Warhammer or Three kingdoms, but the portrayal of the fall of the Roman empire and the challenge of the Eastern barbarians is very well done (although the huge siege engines of the Huns are unrealistic).

This game is absolute dog drivel.  The AI cheats and rules are applied unevenly for AI vs. players.  For example, I was attacked in Belgium by the Suebi.  I sent a relief army from Britain.  It took me FOUR turns to get even half way to the target, because the army's movement was so restricted.  By then, my army was caught in winter and suffered attrition, and a full Suebian army came and annihilated it.  Coming the other way, the Suebi sent an army to attack me in Londinium.  The AI Suebian army moved across northern Gaul, traversed the English channel, and moved inland to Londinium all within the course of a single turn.  Absolute BS.

I had a town in Germania which the Romans laid siege to.  I had an army occupying the settlement and a garrison from the town structure.  The next turn, a Roman army was at the gates laying siege.  My defensive army was still in place, but when I checked the town card, the town had been destroyed and there was no explanation.  No battle had been fought yet, I simply lost the garrison because of AI capriciousness.  Absolute BS.

I had a rebellion and lost a battle.  My army then suffered severe winter attrition.  However, the rebel army was in the same province, and suffered hardly anything from winter attrition.  The rules are applied unevenly.  Absolute garbage.

It is no wonder to me that they had to put this game on sale for 7 dollars.  I'm just glad I didn't waste any more money than that.  I have been with the total war franchise since the very beginning, and I have seen the quality of their games deteriorate over the years.  Oh, sure they are graphically spectacular and the political mechanics have become very interesting.  But the playability of the game itself has fallen off a cliff.  I am not going to buy any more titles from this franchise until I see their games start to become playable again..

I like Total War Attila for how unique it is to other Total War games. If you're playing as Rome or other Germanic nations then you are just trying to survive the upcoming apocalypse (the arrival of the Huns) . If you are playing the Huns then it is the exact opposite; you seek to make the world burn. Basically, bring Rome to it's knees and help your people thrive. If you are Rome, then you're gonna have to make decisions on what territory you want to give up because all of Roman Empire can't be saved. Siege battles in the game are pretty good in this one I'm not gonna lie. Total War Attila is a step up from Total War Rome 2 in my opinion. I'm giving this one a thumbs up.

Good game, cavalry is a lot more responsive compared to Rome II, which means very fun single-player experience and harder multiplayer experience. The time period is centered around 'End Times' narrative, which some people like the darkness so do not... The game is centered around 'survival' theme which is different from Rome's 'empire building' narrative. The game is solid but it should have been part of Rome II all honestly like Fall of the Samurai for Shogun 2.

There are some mechanics make Attila superior to Rome, but there is also other issues that limits it such as performance and lack of faction / interest in the period. Fertility and sanitation is a lot more serious in Attila, and cultures have been replaced with religions. Although lack of 'cultures' on top of religions does hinder the game. There are also a lot of voice-acting lines from Rome, which also reduces the legitimacy of Attila as a separate title... For examples, Muslims in Age of Charlamagne DLC use the generic Arabian / Eastern voice lines from Rome...

An underrated Total War in my opinion. 

That's not to say it's without problems, on the contrary it has quite a few. Its Campaign AI is programmed solely to irritate, some mechanics don't make sense, there are some bugs mainly regarding pathfinding (as do all Total War games). Diplomacy is sort of broken, people can freely roam and raid your regions without having to declare war. I also don't like how the game in many cases forces you to build every region the same. The (base game's) online community isn't really active. Problems do exist overall.

However I still consider it a good game. I love the setting of it, the references to the Revelation and generally the whole mood/atmosphere. Has some of the best mods in the Total War franchise (kudos to all modding teams) and its campaign expansions do add quite a bit to the experience. The battles are -in most cases- very interesting and fun and they often give you that satisfaction of beating impossible odds through tactics. There is a variety of options when it comes to factions, armies and campaign expansion options. Probably an unpopular opinion but I personally really like the horde mechanic (despite the AI abusing it) as well as the climate change. Every faction offers a different experience which makes it more immersive. Beautiful soundtracks and fun easter eggs here and there are also worth mentioning.

Overall: A good, underrated game with its own problems. An enjoyable, sometimes annoying, immersive experience. Would suggest buying it as well as the campaign expansions on discount.

This is from a relatively inexperienced, but HUGE fan of TW as a whole. I play the vanilla game without mods. I'll say it right off the gate, it's the most unforgiving  total war I have ever played, and i'd be lying if i said I enjoyed the politics. Try to make your provinces or regions self sufficient as soon as possible, and if you have an army to attack, be sure your towns are covered because war in this game is loathed.  80% of the time its the best choice lol, even playing a nomadic faction, but some obviously lean one way or the other. You must be successful if you go all in. Early game decisions will make or obliterate you. Troops will suck your coffers dry. Also, religion and culture is a relatively important thing to consider early game, and agents will save you a rl hemorrhage, so make use.  That being said, I haven't been successful in one campaign yet, but maybe at 100 hours I'll be skilled enough to take another province without completely decimating my faction or take too much land without being prepared enough to manage it. Politics and diplomacy before starting new wars is totally advised. If you have any love for your starting faction leader, be careful where it fights and note you can switch out for another if you have it. Attila as fun as Hell on Earth gets for what it is so far for me, and I've barely even touched playing Huns yet.,  Don't expect any pleasantries, but it's certainly playable, especially if you take an interest in the era's history. Also, naval incorporation into any total war adds an unimaginable level of awesome for me, but that's me. Sea artillery in land battles, git gud at mirco in battle if you don't auto resolve and fun fact, you're units will chatter. It pays to listen. If that sounds like a lot to take in at once, it is.  I say no more. If you play a Roman faction, you will be fighting most of the world. Sass. and eastern factions are fun AF.

Attila as a total war game is great for what it's meant to be. In terms of the quality of the game itself, there are a lot of optimization issues (you probably won't experience this if you have a higher end PC) and the occasional bug, but the game is a massive step up from the older total wars in terms of in-game issues like pathfinding, and crashes are a lot less common. The battles are also much more balanced than older total war games, and unlike newer total war games like Three Kingdoms and Thrones, there is a lot of unit variety that will keep battles interesting.

One of the biggest problems this game faces is the campaign itself. The issues aren't with the mechanics of the campaign, the issue is the factions and their play styles. While the main vanilla campaigns are unique, they play very different to what most total war players are used to. The Western and Eastern Empires start out vastly overstretched, and almost guaranteed to lose a large amount of territory to the many hostile factions, especially on higher difficulties. Because of this, they can be very challenging and require a lot of planning to survive. Other factions, like the Huns and great migrators are hordes, which was not in a total war game since Barbarian Invasion for Rome, and there were some serious changes in mechanics since then. There are some factions, like the Saxons and Franks, that play more like other total war game factions, but they face the issue of having to fight the Romans, who may target you early on and catch a newer player off guard. Most of the factions that have a more typical total war playstyle are locked behind DLC, such as the Celts, Slavs and some Germanic factions. Because the main factions are very unique and typically more challenging than usual factions, and a number of the more traditional total war type factions are unplayable without DLC, it turns a lot of players off from the campaign.

One of the upsides of Attila is that it has one of if not the best modding scenes of any total war game. The number of overhaul mods and total conversion mods for Attila offer a lot of replayability. This is mostly because Attila is the last major historical total war game, (because Thrones, Three Kingdoms and Troy are all smaller and more focused games), so modders have focused on it over the years and created a ton of great mods. The only historical total war games that can claim as good of a workshop are Medieval 2 and Rome, which suffer a lot of the issues that come with the older total war games.

If you like mods and campaigns that will challenge you in unique ways, and more balanced battles, play Attila. But be prepared for some of these campaigns to brutalize you due to the learning curve in their playstyles, and if you want to play more traditional type factions, be prepared to fork up some extra money for DLC's. And if you play on a lower budget PC, be prepared for some performance issues.

Not everyone's cup of tea, and perhaps not as good as the original Rome 1 / Medieval 2 games... but the last good Total War game in my opinion, the last Total War that feels like chess rather than the Warhemorrhoid key mashing bullshit of overpowered heroes and abilities. The campaign is challenging but fun. Its different to those earlier games though as you can't aggressively expand without facing rebellions. As with Napoleon Total War, I would start on hard difficulty or even normal and work your way up as you learn the new mechanics - maybe as one of the barb factions or East Rome if you want to play the Romans right away. Don't rage and blame the game if you started on legendary and got steamrolled. On the highest difficulty, diplomacy is a lot more difficult and factions do not want to make peace. That kind of desperate survival against all the factions can be fun once you get used to the game a bit more. Diplomacy generally is a lot more functional than in Empire or Napoleon, while still not letting the player cheese the game like in the original games and swindle settlements from the AI.

The economy system is not too punishing especially if you use your money deliberately and destroy buildings you don't want or need. If you liked Barbarian Invasion in RTW, this is right up your alley too. Playing the Romans is an experience where you don't have to conquer aggressively to be immersed in the world the game is trying to create. Holding the massive empire you already have is a compelling challenge of its own. Abandoning some areas as the Romans may be necessary, but turtling in one small region is not a fun or advisable experience. Attila innovates here with a somewhat new take on Total War. The Roman campaigns are probably the main course here, but you can also play invader factions if you want some variety. I hate that a good number of factions are locked behind DLC, that would be my main gripe with the game. But there are enough factions to have fun with from the start.

Ive heard a lot of bitching about the mechanics of Attila having three lives... but this mid-late game challenge is part of what makes this game as interesting into the late game. Its what Empire and Napoleon lacked... as in Napoleon, you could dismantle Napoleon's empire in the first ten turns if you wanted to. It was a bit too anti-climactic. The original Rome had the civil war... Attila's invasion is this games version of that. Attila is the boss battle of this game. You are planning your campaign around his arrival and the desperate defense you will have to prepare. I like the story driven elements of this game, they add to the apocalyptic atmosphere without taking away player freedom.

It sucks that the game limits how many armies you can have, but the system is not as bad as its made out to be. The limit to number of armies is based on the size of your empire. I think it does alleviate the unit spam of both player and AI in the late game. Garrisons are separate from armies and they can be somewhat customized from different settlement buildings. The one gripe I have with unit recruitment is that somehow the Romans can't recruit heavy cavalry from the start and instead have to rely on the weak scout cavalry until you get better buildings.

The battles are really fun I've found. The game forces you to play units to their strengths and not just play battles like an arcade click fest. People complain about Roman units being underpowered, but I'm convinced they're just not playing their units to their strengths. Collisions seem way better than in Rome II and formations like testudo work like they should. I haven't encountered any issues with these. Combat is detailed and nice to zoom in and look at. And you'll be fighting plenty of battles, which is good in my books. As Barbarian Invasion enjoyers know, walls are your best friend against overwhelming horde stacks. Walls arent as OP as in the original Rome, but they help a lot on fronts you need to defend.

Complaints of this game being "historically innacurate" are ridiculous. The original RTW and Medieval 2 had many completely ahistorical factions and units, but the gameplay was incredibly fun and that is what still brings players back to those games today. The game gives respect to history but is not about simulating it exactly. This is not a reskin of classic Total War though. It's more of a development of the idea started in Barbarian Invasion just with more factions, settlements, mechanics, and atmosphere. This Russian youtuber makes a lot of good points here in favor of the game: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2MCS_lSbEyM&t=0s

Another solid entry in the Total War series. This game definitely has a different "flavor" than the other total war games with its turbulent number of events for a historical title. But I think it's interesting to note that veteran players might notice the combat feels somewhat comfortably similar to older titles like Rome: Total War. Make sure you have some decent hardware for full enjoyment. 

Some things you may/may not do:

-Kill or be killed by Attila's horde of 9999999999 cavalry units. (Obligatory)
-Think Rome is near defeat and then suddenly find 40 columns of heavily armored infantry at your door step.
-Raze that one pesky rebel region to ash because its not worth garrisoning it with two armies worth of upkeep.

Jokes aside this game is s p o o k y and challenging, probably my favorite total war title to date.

So why did I put so much time into this game? Short answer attention to detail, carefully look at all other Total War games that follow this look at the troops. Notice something odd? They're all clones, same armor, same shields, same faces, CA abandoned this attention to detail with other games. In this game every soldier looks a bit different the fighting is different and more brutal and the animations for combat are different. Everything about this game is what used to make CA the number one strategy turn based game in my opinion. Sadly they've strayed away from attention to detail, now the battles are boring in the new games, the soldiers are all clones, it's just not the same and kills the immersion for me. That's why I have almost 1000hrs in this game and plan to add more.

Edit: To elaborate, this just happens to have my favorite mechanics of the series. The Huns provide a solid, almost environmental-like enemy force which gradually ratchets up the pressure until you address the threat. Setting and narrative are top notch. The vanilla factions have a good variety and are distinct from one another. The micro level of the game in terms of where exactly you place your armies, stance, ambushes, agents open up a lot of interesting options for different strategies. Makes for fun game play with replayability. Graphics are very solid despite being almost 10 years old (all the little guys are distinct and you can see them fighting and everything, runs smooth enough). Probably a solid game for someone with a mid-level to old gaming rig, and will deliver fun for folks with better gear. Five stars.

Last time I played a Total War game was "Medieval 2"  many years ago. With Attila, I'm glad I found a harder game in franchise Even prologue campaign makes you struggle when Huns arrive. 

+Nations (era in general) in this game are more interesting to me than medieval 2 and other TW games. I don't like when settled empires fight against each other. Like Ottoman Empire vs France, Austria vs Spain etc. I want tribes, warlords, barbars. I want blood. I want chaos. I want nations to suffer and this game gives that feeling.(Even losing is fun)

+This game has very dark atmosphere. Can't say depressive but darker than other Total War games. It pictures the chaotic atmosphere of migration period well and I like it. 

-Optimization is really bad for a game came that out in 2015. I didn't have a good PC back then. But now I have. Still getting low fps values.

Creative assembly sells blood dlc for $3. This is nonsense. Unfortunately I bought it just to see better visuals but animations aren't very good. I don't recommend you to buy it. It's not necessary.

+People say AD1212 mod is epic. I only tried the prologue campaign. But after playing the grand campaign a couple of times, I may try it.

-Multiplayer community is almost dead. You see one or two games but most of them are private. 

+You can play the game in Turkish 

+I was trying to decide between this and three kingdoms and glad bought this. Don't know about diplomacy but wars are better in this one. At least there aren't superhuman heroes that can change the tide of war alone. I like these nations more than chinese warlords.  And Attila is way cheaper lol.

Total War Attila is a frustrating game. If you play as a European faction, the Huns will attack and burn down your lands and those of your neighbors for the entirety of the game. They cannot be wiped out until you fight and beat Attila himself three times without auto-resolving the battles. Attila himself doesn't even spawn into the game for the first 70+ turns meaning you must accept that the Huns will be harassing you with overwhelming force all game long. Religious strife and sanitation make it incredibly hard to maintain the public order needed to prevent rebellions. With the exception of the Ostrogoths, when you conquer a city belonging to another culture you must convert that settlement to your culture and religion. In the interim public order will be abysmal, there'll be no real garrison and the AI will be able to generate rebel units that the settlement they spawned from that the human player isn't even capable of recruiting.

This game had the potential to be the best in the series but is dragged down by AI cheating and broken mechanics. The Razing mechanic in combination with the a-historical climate change events every few years make a majority of the map uninhabitable by the midway point. I appreciate what the team tried doing with this game, but many of these new mechanics suck the fun out of the game making it feel as if I'm balancing stats rather than building a kingdom. I can't in good conscience recommend this game to my fellow total war fans especially not at full price of 45 dollars 6 years after release.

Meh. To me this game is like the red-headed step-child of Rome 2, and I know a lot of people hated Rome 2 for a while, but I LOVED it, so take that for what its worth.. Attila has a grittier feel to it and is more of a "survival" strategy game, but the game is horribly unoptimized, especially on the campaign map and I'm running an RX 6700XT with a Ryzen 7 5800X. Can't even get 60 fps on the campaign map. The faction variety is pretty barebones and the battle pacing is crazy fast. Basically, cavalry delete anything they charge directly into, but they also drop like flies. I wanted to like it, but its just not as fun as Rome 2 in my opinion. The building management/economy also make no sense. I know its supposed to be hard, but it seems like every building just crams negative effects, so like why even build them? Very slow campaign as well

This game is excellent. It is probably the most underrated Total War title out there, but I really enjoy it. The setting and atmosphere is dark and oppressive, perfectly fitting the decline of the greatest civilization of the West at the time. The maps are gorgeously done, I love the unit models. I'm a collector of Total War series games, I'm trying to re-play the human history they offer (mostly European history though) : 

Rome 2: Wrath of Sparta (432 BC) 
Rome 1: Alexander (336 BC)
Rome 2: Grand Campaign (272 BC)
Rome 2: Hannibal at the Gates (218 BC) 
Rome 2: Caesar in Gaul (58 BC) 
Rome 2: Imperator Augustus (41 BC) -
Rome 1: Barbarian Invasion (363 AD) 

Attila offers three key points of history: 

Attila: Grand Campaign (395 AD) 
Attila: Last Roman (533 AD) 
Attila: Age of Charlemagne (768 AD)

However the missions playing as the Huns lacks historical direction, missions are not interesting, diplomacy for Huns is useless (while it was not in history), if you get too many women it's impossible to marry them, graphics are weird (I prefer RTW II).  The learning curve is quite pronounce, but after you finally learn the new restrictions (rivalry, difference btwn raze and raiding),  you start to enjoy it, specially the ability to settle the hordes and raze entire cities, which is unique here and historically accurate (not present in Barbarian invasion) . I also like the atmosphere of Rome decadency.
peace was never an option

Visually the game looks gritty and dirty.... not in a good way more in a bad particle effect way.

The overall combat system is pretty standard for total war and make no major departure from Rome 2. Its pretty good.

Number of available factions is pretty good but the actual difference between two factions in the same culture group seems somewhat minimal and lacking in creativity. 

The user interface is probably one of the worst parts of the game. Again everything just looks dirty from text to icons  to your cursor it all just looks like it is covered in grim..... I am guessing this is to show the decay of civilization during the time period but it just comes off as ugly and distraction.

Unit description is woefully inadequate. Rather than give any kind of hard numbers for units, unless you go into the encyclopedia, It just give a few details about their worst or best attributes. Like "Very Poor Piercing Damage" or "Good Charge" but nothing that really goes in more details about the unit. I cant imagine why this was removed.


Overall i feel like the game's issues come from trying to recreate a feel of societal decay in the user interface but instead just creating a bad user interface and visually unappealing campaign map. 

I plan on spending more time with the game and playing a few more factions before i write it off, but initial reaction is something of a let down for a game with 80% positive reviews.

A one hour review on how it runs on modern hardware: I finally have a brand new computer as of December 2021 (Windows 10, Ryzen 9 5900x and Nvidia 3080ti plus everything else is high quality). I was concerned with how this game might run due to an Heir of Carthage video on Youtube of him playing a Western Roman Empire campaign that he uploaded around Dec 30, 2021. He was stating that the game was running like a slideshow. For me, it runs fine. The campaign map framerate is fine, but not as good as Troy. The battle framerate is fine. By fine I mean playable and enjoyable. Now again, I'm only one hour in to the prologue so I don't have the most accurate opinion. If you're looking to pick this game up on sale like I did, I would say it runs fine on modern hardware. I might find out once I get into a much longer campaign something different, but as of one hour of playing the prologue, I've not noticed anything that detracts from the playing experience. Granted, I'm used to playing Shogun 2 on a PC that was new in 2009. From what I remember, the Shogun 2 campaign map on a decade old computer ran a little smoother, but Attila does not yet run poor and is still enjoyable. I will comment on this review if I notice any changes.

By far the best Total War game

I may be biased as this was my first TW game, but Atilla has things that other total war games just lack. The sieges, the wandering factions, and surviving famines make this the most challenging Total War. In no other game will you invade another country just to get some land for food so your people can eat.
I have Warhammer II and although it definitely has more quality overall and diversity in troops(being a fantasy), in terms of actual battles and campaign Atilla triumphs even then.
You'll never get bored playing the interesting factions, especially the extreme campaign of turning the West Roman Empire around from the brink of death. Even playing an easy faction like the Persian Empire could get tricky if you screw up dealing with the white huns.
Only negative I can think of is the army limit in battles. It says the max is 3 armies at once, but really after 2 armies your third will only spawn in the middle of the battle, which takes the fun right out of it. 8000 troops fighting in a battle is pretty OP though as it stands.

Frustrating spawning and cheating by the AI. A lazy development, could have been the crown jewel in their crown too. As others have said, we have to boycott the Total War series until they start making good stuff. Just skins on the older games and total garbage with poor effort. Amazing case study in how to destroy a brand wow.

Everyone knows that the WRE is legendary (literally) in it's difficulty but there's more to this game. You can start as one of the Germanic tribes and have more traditional TW campaign. You can choose whether you want to create a big western European empire and face the climate change (which I did as Longbeards) or whether you migrate south and start anew there. 

And how did I deal with Attila? More like how did Attila deal with me. Once he showed up at my borders his opinion of me was overwhelmingly positive simply due to my murderous rampage around Europe. In fact, I was in middle of razing the entire British Isles and wiping out the Celtic faction after their bright idea of declaring a war at me. I ended up having a defensive alliance with Attila - an alliance that he initiated.

Anyway, love the game. Love the atmosphere. The music is absolutely god-tier, especially in Europe.

I used to enjoy the earlier TW games because the map was easy to read, the development/management aspect was simple to grasp, the battles were dynamic and impactful and the life & progression of your generals was dramatic and memorable. 

Each campaign ended up creating some sort of epic story, and you'd get into it from the very beginning. 

They were very flawed games, often kinda simplistic, but they were also extremely fun and exciting.

When I boot up one of the current era TW games these days I have no idea what's supposed to be going on. There's numbers everywhere, unreadable maps, esoteric systems, subatomic micromanagement of every last obscurely named thing and I have no idea which way is up and, most of all, why I should care.

I'm sure those games have their fans who don't think at all like I do, but I've clearly dropped out of that cart and everytime I try to get back on, I end up despising the franchise more.

So Im up to review this game now that I'm 350ish hours in it. As costume Im gonna split the review in pro's and con's, so let get started:

Pro's:
- Great tactical battle simulator and the units are awesome, you want to play as Romans you can choose beteween Rome and Constantinople, want to be the spear that kills Rome, become a Hun, Goth, Vandal, or any Barbarian civ, or you can also become a Pasha for the Sassanids, its all up to you.
- REvamp your city from a humble settlement to a walled city to the capital of you empire.
- Survive sieges either as the attacker or as the defender.
- Trade valuable resources and use them in diplomacy.
- Diplomacy and sword are great to play, either one is good after all the game's called TOTAL WAR.
- With some practice and skill you can manuver your units on the battlefield.

Cons: 
- It need to have a serious rebalance on many playing civilizations, like the huns and some OP units that just cant be killed.
- Has a long learning curve
- I just hate naval battles

All and all its a great game of the genre, dont miss it

After 120 hours in this game, and numerous hours in other TW games, I can confidently give a thumb down.

This does not mean this is a bad game -- this is a normal game just like any other TW. This review is targeted specifically at the notorious WRE campaign. 

The campaign is hard, but in the worst ways you can imagine. You do not face "strong" opponents that make you feel challenged. On the opposite, every single mechanism feels like CA deliberately cheating in the most utterly lazy ways so that you might have a very shoddy delusion of being challenged.

I am a TW veteran, and sure I can cheese the shit out of it and still win, regardless difficulty. But that is not what I want from a challenging campaign. The hope is I don't cheat, AI doesn't cheat a lot, but not too ridiculously much. But here AI cheats too ridiculously much.

First off, the public order system is out of control. On top of the difficulty penalties, there's a -9 constant immigration penalty since mid-game that refuses to go away. The way "immigration" is named makes you wonder whether less warring, etc. could help reduce it. Nope. It is just another "difficulty penalty" that does not go away, and is just there to make this pathetic game harder, while not one bit more fun. Following this school of thought, I can make any TW campaign "the hardest" by slamming a -100  flat public order penalty, and then give you 5 different PO buildings that you have to spend tons of money building. This is ridiculous and extremely contrived.

Equally bad is the enemies. All barbarians declare close to the beginning, and they are always on a suicide mission. You'd think they'd stop bothering you after the 5th army they sent is destroyed. Nope. They peace out and before the peace expires they declare war again. They care not at all about their own survival, and there's no logic of any sort. They behave not like nations but AI from 1990s. CA may as well remove all strategic and diplomatic elements and just randomly spawn 5 armies near the border every turn. Won't make a difference.

Oh, wait, that is exactly what they did. The Huns are pillaging Italy and you want to kill them? Too bad because after carefully and perfectly orchestrating a coordinated attack using all the legions and destroying all 7 Hun armies in one turn, instead of being wiped out, they just spawn several new armies near the border a few turns later. Congratulations, now you need to keep 3-4 legions forever on the border so that they can deal with Huns that come from utterly nowhere and cannot be killed. It's like a Tower Defense game, only that you need to spend two hours fighting the exact same enemies every few turns, for 100 turns. It is a complete waste of time.

I can cheese and win. Abandoning settlements at the beginning, wait for siege timer to run out, corner camp, etc. etc. But you-cheat-I-cheat is not the challenge I want. This campaign is extremely disappointing, and I do not suggest anyone to try it.

Garbage, unplayable garbage, hordes get massive bonuses, untill of course the AI decides to gang stalk and gang up on you with multiple factions. Don't bother to settle any cities, they cost too much to upkeep and you will never make that much anyways, reason being unlimited armies attacking you from everywhere. I haven't even seen much of a hunic invasion, the european tribes have big enough armies to whipe you out when they gang up on youas it is, and they do. Even if you eradicate scorched earth policy one tribe another will take it's place to eagerly declare war on you and send countless overpowered agents to ruin your day. The AI also seems to have unlimited funds to buy anything it wants. So when you are spawned with countless low level agents killing off high ranking generals or poisoning your cities and impeding movement while more and more armies approach you are basically at zero chance of winning, did I mention making money is hard? And how you need it immensly to survive? Oh, yeah, I thought I'd run around europe burning and pillaging and making a ton of cash then settling, then 10 armies attacked me from all sides in two turns and killed me off ompletely. Yeah, challenging. I bought this at a discount and still feel ripped off.

UPDATE: Still sucks, only thing improved is that there's less infinite agents running around keeping you from actually playing the game. I managed to build a safe haven in Britania. I'm safe now, everything under control. What I fail to understand is why you lose ability to build beneficial buildings the more technology you discover? Food scarcity is also an issue, keeping people happy isn't easy either. If you plan to expand, it won't happen. I keep sinking countless ships filled with armies from all over the place trying to invade Britain. It's fairly easy to do with just one navy if you keep your catapults in the back. But then, I have to wonder, so... what now? Expansion is pointless due to the debuffs you get and the constant invasions. I doubt I could keep the settlements on the mainland if I tried. The troop composition compared to barbarians is just pathetic. barbarians have archers, crossbowmen, artillery and cavalry, but I as rome have... foot soldiers and javelin throwers... yeah... not great for expansion there...

It's a fun transitional title from less event/character drivien Total Wars of the past to the more recent Warhammer and Three Kingdoms titles. I'm actually a fan of the DLC on this one, pretty much across the board (not that there's a ton) which I can't say for all TW titles. I'd say the apocalyptic atmosphere is done particularly well. 

It suffers from all the usual Total War flaws, but it doesn't introduce any new ones. I enjoy dipping into and out of this one and still keep it in rotation years past release.
i do believe that it should be a DLC for Rome 2 not a stand alone game however it very nicely portrays the decay of the roman world.

Attila is Dark Souls, while the rest of total war is God of War.

Attila was my very first experience with the newer Total War games. I will never forget the hours I spent with every faction and the time I lost my anal virginity within the first two turns of a Western Roman Empire campaign.

Attila doesn’t follow the great formula of gameplay of the other TW games. Things are harder in Attila, more frantic and survival-focused, and there is a really steep learning curve to get the balance of settlement management which will entirely make-or-break your campaign. 

I personally loved Attila, but I’m just a psychopath that enjoys painful and frustrating experiences. If you want a REAL challenge, give it a try.

TLDR: Overall, a strong member of the TW franchise that, although the visual atmospherics are far too dark, has otherwise implemented a host of all the cumulative features and mechanics CA is known for in the TW series and so provides a great gaming opportunity.    

For the historically-minded and those who loved CA's roots, like STW I and II, Medieval I and II, RTW I and II,-you get the idea-(so, CA, will there be an Atilla II (or MTW3) to help assuage the historically minded supporters? For the die hards then it is indispensable, but particularly so for those who yearn for the fierce and active cavalry engagements offered in the MTWs.  All that and the updated mechanics found in R2 but with a very satisfying attention to the tactical level.

While I have only scratched the proverbial surface of the game at this point, and that with a dozen or so mods and a couple of DLCs to make it a more complete experience, so far so good.  (If my opinion changes, I will update this review in the future.)  

Atilla hearkens back to the Dark Ages period, if preceding it by a horse's hair, and with a ticking timer (a familiar mechanic but one that still proves appealing) hanging over your head  in the urgent form of a sword of Damocles, or the equine-culture and compound-bow armed hordes of the Hunnic Atilla.

For those who admired the historical iterations, warts and all, and to be clear that means there are no elves, magic, dragons, and so forth, what you have here is generally a reasonably faithful depiction of the overwhelming fear that the Huns and those they dispossessed planted in Europe and beyond between the 4th and the 6th centuries.  You can play them or attempt to survive as one of many European or non-European factions.

For me, it is all about the battles and Atilla has that critical element on target.  Should the realism of blood and gore be a DLC, locked behind a paywall like some archers firing behind a wall of shields?  Of course not.  For the historical games anyway, it must be included in the game as an option in settings, with an intensity slider.  If needs must be, put a parental lock of some sort on it to spare the young armchair lieutenants, but for the grognards at this point it is expected.

Lastly the game is dark, I mean visually too dark.  I get that it was the Dark Ages and there were perhaps other factors contributing to this design choice, but to make a game enjoyable you need to see clearly and this is an area where the historical should not come before the necessary.  Again, have the option in settings if it is something the devs feel is critical, but let the player choose.

Atilla, and particularly the battles, is excellent.  The attention to and the development of the power of the defense is where it really shines, and absolutely makes this a ‘must-have’ for those looking to scratch that RTS historical itch.

One of my favourite Total war games.

It's apparently one of the worst selling and least popular of the Total War series, which is a shame. I have a theory that the narrower focused, smaller timeframe Total War games tend to be better and this is a fine example. It's got a brutally unforgiving combat system, an apocalyptic vibe and factions that genuinely play completely differently in campaign mode (desperately surviving as Rome is a very different experience to looking for a place to settle as the Goths, for instance. Sassanid opportunism is my favourite way to go)

What really sets it apart are the mods, though. I have no idea what drew so many talented and dedicated modders to this one, but it's mind blowing. The number of mods that remix and breathe new life into a game that already has a lot to offer. Medieval Kingdoms is, I know, going to be the gold standard against which a new medieval total war game will be judged and it wouldn't surprise me if the modders out do them. 

Just a small tip, artillery is completely insane in this game, despite attempts to nerf it.

I've been a huge TW fan since Medieval 1, and spent a lot of time in Medieval 2, also Rome and Empire. 
I've been looking forward to a new version in a European setting, because the history aspect is what counts for me. 
However, I'm not having fun with Attila. It's just too cluttered with game mechanics, and a lot of the time, the UI is counter-intuitive for me. Each time you want to finish a turn the game reminds you that you have this and that chore to do. I don't mind complex game mechanics if they serve a purpose, but in Attila, it all feels like it's just there to keep you busy, and wasn't thought through well. Like a skill tree for each general, another skill tree for each army, put all important people (which all have similar faces) into political roles, etc. etc. 
I can't keep track of it all! 

So if you find the other TW games lacking of stuff to do per turn, check this out.

smile

Overpriced trash that lacks logic at every single step and focuses on useless mechanics while flat out ignoring the issues that have been ongoing in every single Total War game since Medieval 2 and has yet to be fixed.

To start out, diplomacy, remember that? Might as well call it fuckyoumacy because the AI will flat out refuse every single offer you make, no matter how reasonable. Got 100+ relations with Eastern Roman Empire who broke their alliance by refusing to join you in a war and want a non-aggression pact? Not happening. 

Have 3 full armies advancing an a secluded barbarian capital and want peace? Not a chance in hell son. It would be better if they just removed the diplomacy mechanic from the game all together so at least they won't be deceiving you into thinking such a thing actually exists.

Next up is siege AI. You have a low 15% chance that the AI won't attack a walled city at all and prefer to sit outside the gates until the timer has run out, this happened on my very first siege battle. 

Then you have a low 50% chance that they'll completely ignore your soldiers and advance to the town square with the same generic Roman colosseum placed in nearly every Roman city. If you are lucky enough to have neither of these happen, they'll willingly throw their cavalry away charging into a deadly wall of spears, again, and again, and again.

Deploying soldiers is a nightmare and you'll constantly have to babysit your soldiers if you attempt any manuevers because pathfinding is laughably bad, nearly Empire-tier. When I order my archers to fire at the enemy within my town square they naturally form a 2 man wide 80 man deep line, then the front will be so stretched that they actually engage the enemy and then the whole unit will follow them into melee combat.

Civilians can be seen during siege battles which is really nice for immersion, but one has to wonder why they spent resources on this instead of actually fixing and testing the fucking game.

If their siege equipment is destroyed they will sit outside the city doing nothing until the timer runs out or you sally forth.

In most cities you can place 1-2 barricades in only the most redundant spots that provide no tactical advantage, but surely after months of siege they could build more than two laughable barricades? Might as well have not included this feature at all.

What's hilarious is the fact that if they bring siege weapons they can set your city ablaze and burn down virtually every building, but CA can't program a functioning AI in a single one of their games.


Onto battles. In real battles the engagements last for hours between days, not in Attila. Naturally the battles shouldn't play out that long in a videogame but here the battles are incredibly short, the average engagement with actual fighting is around 5-9 minutes long, with engagements only reaching 15 due to preparing and marching. 

I can hardly send my cavalry to flank the enemy because within a minute one of the units has already retreated with broken morale, but they'll return to battle 10 seconds later, and repeat this process until they are shattered.

Another particularly, yet minor and tiring annoyance is after winning or losing a battle you have to sit through an animation between 1v1 soldiers fighting to simulate your type of victory or defeat. While interesting at first when playing as the Roman Empires you have to sit through at least 4 of these a turn seeing your pathetic garrisons be defeated. 

And all the animations are meant for sword wielders, so you'll see stupid shit like a barbarian stabbing you in the throat with his axe/club then seeing your head pop off. While it can be funny it really goes to show the lack of effort and laziness of the Creative Assembly.

Everywhere throughout the game you'll see a great lack of effort in design and eventually come to wonder what chuckling idiot could fuck up so many clear concepts.

I could rant forever but I will end this here with a few pointers.


Cons:
-UI
-AI
-Diplomacy
-Battles
-Sieges
-Lazy design decisions
-DLC (Blood and burning pack, really? It's funny because the description for it talks about realism when I just saw a dude's head get cut off with a club)
-Mod unfriendly so people "want" to buy DLC
-Online Encyclopedia for basic information that is down half the time

Pros:
-Graphics
-Improved leader system from Rome II (still subpar)
-Music

After 400 hour edit:

- Skirmishers stay at max range so barely any kills
- Skirmishers get caught 90% of the time
- Pulling out cavalry turns your men into pincushions
- Autoresolve is utterly botched and favors numbers 90% of the time, forcing you to fight every little fucking battle
- Maintaining a garrison is considered too difficult for the average mouthbreather, so CA did away with it. Enjoy *endless* 4 garrison vs 20 stack battles ad nauseum
- Armies move fast so good luck countering an enemy's invasion force in the field
- You can recruit up to EIGHT units in a single turn with bonuses. This makes fielding an army laughably easy and turns what should be heroic victories into endless, inconsequential brawls
- Diplomacy is an utter fucking joke, a potato could design a game better than these inbred brits have
- God I fucking hate this game. I'm serious, this is a quarter-finished product

This is exactly what a Total War game should be like! Armies , cities , hordes , fleets , politics and mods.

Armies: There are a lot of factions and they all have exclusive units. So every nation/faction has its own way of tactics. Spearmen , swordsmen , axemen , cavalry ... and somewhat siege engines (:like the Sassanids have better siege engines , but they're more shock cavalry and armoured elephants-tactics.

Naval battle is quite basic , and there's an annoying bug in naval battles. Sometimes when your ship enters another ship , your marines are jumping into the sea instead of jumping onto the enemy ship. It happens quite a lot. [5/10]
