I am not considering myself a die-hard fan of the Total War series, mainly due to the lack of time. However, this game is a fresh alternative to what strategy fans may be looking for. It's not designed to allow you to win easily. The focus on this title is simple: Ruin. 

A few extra positives to consider is the crispy graphics and well-suited lighting to the game that fits the tone and theme. I was very happy to depart from the standards set by the Rome and Medieval titles, and immerse myself in an interesting take of what the Dark Ages of Europe and beyond would feel like. But, these are for people who are interested in such elements, so i shall not linger on that. The developers corrected almost everything that was wrong with Rome II regarding politics, unit balance and one-turn sieges. Religions have been overhauled and most of the factions can now migrate to avoid any imminent dangers incurred by nature or other factions. All these, coupled with some breathtaking musical instrumentation make the game worth your while.

The downside is that sometimes a faction may seem redundant and identical to another, while the game doesn't offer a wide palette of units for each faction. This was perhaps to showcase the difference in each 
faction's strengths and weaknesses. While many players may like that more "immersive" factor, I personally found it limiting so I enhanced my experience with mods. 

All in all, it's a good game. The released DLCs are also fun and the community works tirelessly bringing mods that make the game even greater.

As a total war player myself who started from the classic Medieval 2, and then heavily invested hundreds of hours on Napoleon, Shogun 2 and Rome 2 and a little bit on WH1, I highly recommend Total War: Attila for it being a unique game compared to other TW titles. It is set during the dawn of the Dark Age on Europe which focuses mainly during the fall of the Roman empire as well as covering parts of Northern Africa and all the way down to the Middle East with the rich dessert kingdoms. What makes this game unique is that it offers some sense of realism in the game and in which it doesn't only focus or rely heavily on conquest which is quite a tradition on every TW titles. Unlike some of the older total war titles, expect that conquest on TW Attila's campaign is riddle with a lot of problems which needs to be dealt with if you are to maintain your newly conquered territories. These problems includes: maintaining a decent sanitation levels across your settlements, if u fail to maintain a decent sanitation expect to have another problem in the form of plague or diseases which heavily affects your public order and will kill hundreds of your men across your armies stationed within the infected areas, politics is also a problem, you'll need to keep an eye on the level of influence on different characters such as the statesmen, your most effective generals, and your governors across every provinces. The higher their influence goes, the lower their loyalty to you will be which may lead to a civil war once they've gone too far ahead of you, and also the main threat of the game which is the Huns, these guys will sack and raze every single settlement they come across with and the game is basically all about surviving against these guys. They can easily wipe out even a full stack because of their vast numbers of Hunnic devil archers which easily crushes every single unit they come across with and then retreat to safety. And there's also the usual public order managements, crushing rebellions, economy management, trades etc which was already part of the older TW tittles. So if u like to play with a much more challenging TW game, then TW: Attila it is and I highly recommend it. Plus, there are tons of greats mods to choose from like the Medieval 1212AD mod which is very famous and could be considered as a Medieval 3, Rise of Morder mod which brings the Lord of the Rings setting on a TW game, and many more.

[h1] TOTAL WAR ATTILA: The underrated TW game[/h1]

I highly recommend TW: Attila, primarily for its survival gameplay. Attila was marketed as a survival RTS, and CA delivered with this underrated title. 

While the gameplay is very enjoyable, the game's performance is a complete MESS, with barely-tolerable framerates in campaign and in battle. Fortunately, players can fix this game's poorly-optimized graphics with some modding, by replacing the game's shaders with the shader assets from Thrones of Britannia (more info on this further below).

However, despite the poor performance, the gameplay and Attila's apocalyptic story kept me playing. 

Attila is far from perfect, but I personally give the game a total score of 8/10. 

[h1]Story: 9/10[/h1]
The game's story presents itself as a tale of the end times. This is not an age of glory, it is a hellish age of decay, where the greatest civilizations of the world are falling apart and the survivors of this apocalypse are left to pick through the scraps of a bleak, and ravaged world. 

In Attila, you are not expected to conquer: you are simply expected to SURVIVE. Usually, most of the world is reduced to a howling wasteland by the end of the game, razed to the ground by the Huns, or utterly destroyed by constant warfare. IF you survive the early and midgame, the endgame is a battle royale of epic proportions between world superpowers.  

Attila's grand campaign is extremely grimdark. It is very thematic and overcoming the insurmountable odds the game threw at me personally gave me a sense of satisfaction that Rome 2 or the TW: Warhammer trilogy could never give me: I survived the apocalypse.

[h1]Gameplay: 8/10[/h1]

[b]Unit Variety and Technology[/b] 
Like previous titles, Attila suffers from one problem: Barbarian cultures often share the same units. To make matters worse, the "cooler" barbarian factions with unique and thematic units are locked behind paid DLC's when they should have been in the game in the first place. 

Another thing that don’t like about the units in this game, are the Roman techtrees. For example, as WRE advances through its tech tree, their units are replaced with exponentially expensive units. Because of this, by the end of the game, you can’t even field a full army of pure Roman units.

[b]Hordes[/b]
The horde mechanic is a breath of fresh air, being able to play as a wandering, marauding tribe that can pillage and raze right under the noses of the greatest empires in the classical antiquity. 

The only downside to the horde mechanic is how annoying hordes can be when playing as a landed culture. Hordes are able to march across your territory unimpeded, sacking, raiding, and razing your empire while your army chases after them, sometimes 1 movement point behind and unable to attack. This can be fixed with mods, but this oversight should have been fixed in the base game. 

[b]Crisis Event[/b]
Similar to Paradox games and TW: WH, the crisis event of this game is Attila's fiery descent upon the world. Some might say the coming of Attila makes the game too hard, or that the Huns get too many cheats.

To that, I simply say: Y E S. This game is a survival RTS, and you are expected to fight against the apocalypse. When Attila takes command of the Hunnic hordes, the Huns get powerful doomstacks that can easily wipe out an unprepared player. Thankfully, when Attila dies (from old age, or battle), the Huns lose their cheats.

Yes, this mechanic is extremely difficult, but it is VERY satisfying to outlast or defeat the Huns. Defeating the Huns almost makes you feel like you've saved the world.

[b]Pacing[/b]
This game is very fast-paced. The lethality of attacks/charges etc are much more pronounced in this game. Units will melt in seconds rather than in minutes when attacked with advantageous or superior units. 

I personally like this pacing, because battles come across as more violent and decisive in Attila.  

[b]Balancing[/b]
Similar to Rome 2, Roman units are some of the most powerful units in the game, but Attila takes place in a time period where the Roman Empire is in a steep decline, and they make easier pickings (in comparison to previous games) for the other rising factions of the game.

Battles in Attila are very dynamic and decisive, as each faction, even the barbarian tribes, have advantages over stronger empires (Celts can vanguard deploy, Nordic units make good marines, Germans have excellent cav, etc). Rome is no longer the invincible god of war it was in Rome 2, and even barbarian tribes can kick them while they’re down, in the campaign, and in battle.

[b]Apocalyptic Battles[/b]
It is sometimes disturbing how brutal, fiery, and bloody these city battles can be, and only Attila has been able to capture this sense of violence that other Total War games could not. 

One thing I miss when playing Total War: Warhammer 2, are the climactic city battles of Rome 2 and Attila. In Attila, you can burn cities to the ground in battles. This burning mechanic reduces the morale of defenders, and gives attackers an advantage. Even a grizzled Roman legionary will tremble at the sight of his people's great cities and monuments burning around him. 

Another thing that is unique to Attila are the way plagues affect armies. Sometimes, you will be forced to fight with or against infected troops, and you'll find that their warriors are visibly diseased - they are sickly and vomiting. It is truly a disturbing sight to see.

This, coupled with the dark colors, shadows, blood and gore, and fire of Attila's brutal battles, gives players a hellish and apocalyptic picture of the end times. 

In summary, Attila's gameplay compliments its apocalyptic story with its brutal, disturbing, and hyper-violent battles. These battles can give players a darker perspective on how grim this time period must have seemed to the people that lived in it. 

[b]Zones of Control[/b]
I figured I'd close this section and transition into the things I don't like about Attila (with graphics being  one of the two things I don't like about this game). 

The OTHER thing I don't like about Attila is armies' lack of zones of control. There is nothing more frustrating than surrounding a Hunnic horde with 5 armies, and attacking it, only for it to retreating THROUGH your armies, across a river, and force march away from you the next turn.

[h1]Graphics: 6/10[/h1]
I played this game for years, and found the game's framerate to be tolerable at best. The reason why this game runs so poorly is because it is a 32bit game that is often played on 64bit operating systems, and because its assets are poorly-optimized. 

Even with lower settings, this game's performance is still terrible. However, this optimization can be fixed with a little modding. By replacing the game's shader data with assets data from Thrones of Brittania, players can enjoy a smoother and acceptable framerate, even on mid-range computers. 

Instructions on how to to do this are below:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1581603370

Personally, I really don't like how CA practically abandoned this game, while still providing updates to the much older Rome 2. In fact, before I replaced Attila's shaders with TOB's, Rome 2 ran more smoothly on my computer than Attila did, which is really sad, because Rome 2 came out 7 years ago.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
Although Total War Attila suffers from insufferable graphics and performance, its brutal gameplay and its thematic, apocalyptic story kept me playing. 

If you really enjoy fighting against or outlasting overwhelming odds, then you will enjoy this game. All in all, despite its graphical shortcomings, and its lack of TLC from Creative Assembly, this underrated game is an 8/10 in my book. 

Having played Rome 2 and the WH:TW games, I offer this perspective on Attila: only TW: Attila can make you feel like you've survived, or saved the world from the apocalypse.

This game might actually be enjoyable if it weren't for the completely botched difficulty system which ranges from Easy and Normal where the ai is mostly incompetent and gets crushed easily to Hard and above where you'll get punished for not winning every single battle because if you don't crush their army in one turn they'll use their highly historical cloning machines to shit out a new whole ass stack of dudes to shit on you with.

Not to mention the lack of faction roster diversity where several factions will share 99% of the same exact units.  The overpriced DLC is also a turn off as you have to pay to unlock factions which is lame as hell and takes away the incentive to destroy factions (in prior games you could unlock by destroying).

It seems CA didn't bother trying to make a difficulty system where the AI gets increasingly smarter as that would actually be fun and challenging; no instead they allow the AI to complete bypass certain mechanics almost entirely which is not fun at all and feels more like you're playing a rigged game rather than a challenging one.  If I'm going to lose I want it to be because the AI outplayed me, not because they can make entire armies appear out of thin air in a single turn, or because they don't have to worry about managing money, etc.

Deepest Total War game to date. 

Campaign map is deep with public order, sanitation, fertility, and all the factors that effect them.  Economy is deeper than other Total Wars since Agricultural, culture, commerce, and industry can become a real balancing act while trying to manage public order and sanitation. 

Battles are gritty.  There is more cohesion among units, battle lines are held, there is a battle order, Cavalry is super powerful but also super fragile which I really like.  

The soundtrack is severely underrated, and the atmosphere of the game is the best in the series.  

my gripes with the game include; optimisation even with a solid system getting a steady FPS can be a struggle, also Settlement battles when more than one full stack is attacking can become boring and a waiting game.  

All in All.  It's probably my favourite Total War game and in my opinion the best of the more modern games.

Be just advised on :
- the ingame performance : the game does not run as smoothly as Rome 2 or Shogun 2 and may even crash from time to time
- dealing with revolts is a nightmare
- it's really important to find a balance with food at your province and empire level, since you will get public order malus if your province balance is negative and you will suffer from starvation if it happens at your empire level

Regarding DLC, I only purchased Empire of Sands and playing with Himyar was a blast through difficult on the campaign map (religion, revolts...).
A better job could have been done on balance regarding rebel armies, which often spawn with top tiers units, and with the whold food system which does not make sense.

A final word on the 1212AD mod, a overhaul set in middle age, under development.

Possibly the most underrated historical Total War game (I tried playing warhammer... but it just sucks in my opinion! I'm also loving ToB inspite what everyonr says, so if you find that disturbing, swipe to another review...)
Attila has made vast improvements to the gameplay such as: siege decay, spreading fires, hoard factions etc... Also, it possibly has the best total war family tree (if you don't consider rome 2 after the improvements\3k character system) giving characters much sway to shine as they progress through the different offices (also, you can murder your own faction leader, which might make a fun takeover scenario, which I did one time)
Also, the campaign dlc are really worth you time! Telling compeling stories about the dark ages\early medieval period. The Age of Charlamagne dlc even makes a welcome return to era inspired art, such as unit cards, buildings etc... (Though they didn't give the characters any special treatment unfortunately...) Another dlc I would recommend is the desert kingdoms one: each faction there plays with unique story missions, for example: the Tanukhids conquer and liberate story, where at the end you could decide whether to incorporate those liberated factions into your own after completing a set of missions, or continue to liberate many peoples as an unrelenting hoard.
Where Attila really shines though is its many overhaul mods, perhaps the best mods since Medieval 2 (did I say that there's also a well designed overhaul mod which sets the game during the medieval period?! which is constantly being updated with vast game-changing mechanics and more?!) 
There are a plethera of game overhauls, from one which brings rome 2 campaign into the game (plus some neat tidbits not avalble not present in rome 2) through the early renaissance, and also fantasy mods such as GoT and LOTR.
All in all, get the game! It's a wonderful experience to the new and old fans alike!

Complex campaign, challenging difficulty level. Different factions really play differently. Worth playing many times. Love it! Battles are fun and engaging. You can win against bigger armies with skill and by using the right units against the right targets. Cheesing also quite possible.
The diplomacy is straight-up stupid, though. Factions will not make a peace deal even if you're 10x bigger and about to crush them. Neutral factions won't trade with you, no matter the offer etc.

The AI will fuck you in harder difficulties but the siege battles in this game are super fun to both defend and attack. Playing as Western Rome will make you question your existence in this world as the Huns decimate your entire empire. Naval battles are super cool and actually engaging and naval sieges are OP as your archers on boats have an ability to replenish ammo that can be used infinitely.

My all-time favourite Total War game and entirely undeserving of its ‘Rome II DLC’ complaints. Not only is the dark and apocalyptic setting seriously fun and challenging, but also the new mechanics such as hordes and settlement razing bring a real survival game feel which I personally love. You can go straight for the Western or Eastern Roman Empire (for a new player I’d suggest the East as the West tends to get hammered very easily if you don’t have a plan in place) which is a great fun, albeit long and challenging campaign. Expect to grit your teeth with frustration as ‘barbarian’ factions decide to raze yet another of your settlements to the ground, or a pretender state decides to set up their own annoying little empire in Gaul or Spain, which makes the revenge you enact on them so much sweeter as you perhaps catch their two main armies in a mountain pass in northern Italy for a cataclysmic (and often hideously violent) battle. 
Or, an equally fun option, you can gun straight for a so-called barbarian faction, which is what I did when I started. The epic exodus of the Goths, Vandals, Suebi and Alans has a fantastic appeal, and you really feel the horses of the various steppe hordes breathing down your neck as you flee into Roman territory. These guys are a pretty fun way to start out as if you want to play it safe you can flee to the hills of Spain or coast of Africa and hide from your nomadic pursuers. 
The Huns do bring genuine terror to the game. The new voice acting, the entirely new units, new war horns, everything about them is new to Total War and I love it. The start is a bit precarious as you muscle your way through other competing steppe rivals and angry Slavic warlords, but once you have subjugated these peoples the fun really begins. There’s a lot of fun to be had razing Rome to the ground, as your enemies heavily-armoured infantry and cavalry simply can’t catch your hordes of mounted archers. 
All theatrics aside, this game is a masterpiece in my eyes. Of course it has its faults; too many units on the field tends to cause some stuttering; public order, food and squalor penalties are fairly hardcore (part of the survival element) and some of the Germanic factions tend to be a bit repetitive in their units, but with the wealth of mods out there some unit diversity is only a few clicks away. 
It’s just a very satisfying game that has provided me more fun campaigns than any other Total War. The DLCs are well worth it as they are a massive step up from the lacklustre DLC of Rome II.
TL;DR: cannot recommend highly enough. Epic storylines just waiting for you to create. Sandbox Total War with more fire.

This is probably the only survival-style Total War game that purposely goes out of its way to make life incredibly difficult and annoying as hell for you no matter what faction you play. That being said, the challenge of just staying alive on the harder difficulties can be intense and enjoyable if you seriously want to use your brain and test your long term chess-like planning along with your tactician skills in battle. The game is actually fairly balanced from the get go and a couple of mods from the workshop tweak things so you can balance out some of the more "excessive" mechanics to your liking. The main campaign will take a VERY long time but the DLC offers a more targeted experience some may find more enjoyable. The learning curve for a new player will seem overwhelming and will take a while to master (maybe start with Rome II first), but one will find the historical accuracy and atmosphere of the game some of the best in the franchise.

For those of you who have played Rome: Total War - Barbarian Invasion (and/or remastered), this is a more in-depth look at the 'dark ages', where the Huns are sweeping in from Asia and destroying all in their path, barbarian tribes are forced to migrate and find new lands, and the Roman empire, now split into the Eastern and Western empires, are starting to crumble. Gameplay wise, the campaign follows a different path for all, if you're the Western Roman empire, be prepared to loose a lot of territory on your first go, Eastern Roman empire flourishes in the east, rivalling the Sassanid Empire, like Rome Total War: Barbarian Invasion, some tribes can migrate, leaving their settlements and moving on somewhere new. A good game depicting the darkest of times in the Eastern deserts and Western parts of Europe.

After over 900 hours playtime I am still coming back to restore the Roman glory and giving some light and hope to the turbulent years of the Migration Period.

As I almost always play as Western Roman Empire (WRE) or Eastern Roman Empire (ERE) on the legendary difficult settings I am mostly be commenting about them. 

*Strategy spoiler warning*

The gameplay mechanics for TW-veterans are familiar and for the new players they are quite challenging. Playing either WRE or ERE the sheer size of manageable empire is likely too much for the beginner. Starting the game again for the 10th time because the empire is collapsing again is not a failure but a good practice. Because the first 20-30 turns as WRE is stressful and sometimes pure agony even for the experienced players. The first few years you are mostly retreating from Britannia, Northern Gallia, Pannonia and Dalmatia because it generally necessary and gives you time to rebuild your army and finances and the same time you are trying to keep your people from revolting and your African neighbors’ in peace. It’s quite overwhelming. After that it’s just re-conquest and punitive missions against barbarians. The first 20-30 turns as ERE is similarly stressful and pure agony. After beating the Visigoths on the first 1-2 turns you need to dance and bribe to avoid war with everyone at all cost to buy time to (re-)build your strong Empire. Especially when you try to utilize the 5 % interest bonus ERE has. The money is always on the short side at the beginning. After that it’s just keeping the status quo in the west and Total War in the east.

The downside is always the late game. It’s way too easy especially when you compare it to the beginning.

The late game in WRE and ERE are quite similar. After turn 30-40 you are unbeatable and it’s like you have Julius Caesar at the helm. Even if you lose multiple battles or whole armies in a row you can easily rebuild them with your unlimited money. At this point the game starts to get boring but you still go on. Even killing Attila is quite easy and especially after that the late game is just for waiting for the years to pass and conquering some weak opponents.

Even though the game is called Total War Attila I have not played as Attila more than 5 hours. I just do not like the moving city mechanics and raids. Playing as northern barbarians is taxing and slow and playing as Sassanids is way too easy even though you need to keep your allies in check. That’s why SPQR.

Overall I give it 9/10

tl;dr: If I wasn't a masochist bent on getting my money's worth out of this game, I'd stop playing. No, sunk costs don't exist.

Longer tl;dr: the game is extremely buggy and poorly optimized, the AI is stupid and they attempt to fix this with heavy handed buffs that are explicit and (more annoyingly) hidden, the gameplay can be random and meaningless, and the endgame is boring.

Laundry list below:

0) AI -- Hidden Cheats
I was going to put this at the end, but since this peeves me so much, I decided to put it at the beginning. Look, if I play on a higher difficulty, I accept there will be cheats like increased income, public order, etc. Sure, sometimes it is annoying to see a one settlement faction field two full stacks, but that's just part of playing on harder difficulties. What I really hate are the hidden buffs like increased battle speeds, the ability to fire at targets just at the edges of their range immediately (it takes my archers 3-5 seconds just to form up, let alone start their firing animations), increased accuracy, melee attack / defence, etc. JUST TELL ME THEY ARE THERE.

1) Crashes
The game has crashed from the start menu after pressing either the play or continue campaign buttons a least a few dozen times. It also crashes while playing the game infrequently, although at a rate much higher than any other game I've played. This occurs both without and with mods.

2) Optimization
The game's FPS drops significantly during battles to levels I've only previously encountered when my wifi disconnects during a multiplayer game. AI turn times at the start take a moderate amount of time, which is worsened to absurd degrees during the endgame. I'm playing Attila with a new-ish computer that can play tons of other high-quality graphic games no problem, and am running a second fan underneath my laptop.

3) Bugs
Endless. For example, the Ollam Ri generated character disappeared from my nobles list (not after marriage). Puppet states randomly end up at war with each other, which is especially annoying when playing the Lakhmids or Sassanids. One time, I had to restart a campaign after my only horde army got stuck within a city's zone of control in encampment stance and for some reason, was not able to change stances to attack. Bugs extend to battles as well; cavalry will slow walk when given the order to attack enemies (yes, they're supposed to be "running"), units will reorient themselves for no reason, and positioning with right clicks sometimes drags the units into different formations.

4) Gameplay -- Traits and Ancillaries
Trait gaining is extremely random when recruiting new characters (seriously, my new agents are thin skulled, in the family, or have some other major debuff trait at least a third of the time) and remains so throughout the campaign. For example, testing the loot trait using the infinite sack ability, getting down the trait line for a general can take anywhere from 10-40 times. This for a campaign where 4 turns is a year, generals are recruited around ages 25-35, and characters die usually 50+. Both ancillaries and traits are often opaque in terms of how one achieves / gains them.

5) Gameplay -- Tech and Traditions
Minor critique: most tech upgrades are really only about unlocking new buildings / units. I don't understand the random +3% cultural income boosts. Bigger gripe: army traditions take an inordinate amount of time to level through, and a lot of them are useless (wow, +3 morale against Romans!).

6) Gameplay -- Endgame
Incredibly boring, made especially so because of lack of optimization and lag. Before Attila even becomes leader of the Huns, I'm usually in a good position and not too worried about this supposedly existential threat.

7) AI -- Strategy
The AI manages to be both incredibly incompetent and endlessly frustrating, as well as just plain boring at times. There's no joy in going up against Roman spear stack spams, or in seeing war targets being "mobilized" against (spoiler: they're not). In addition, the AI only marginally follows the diplomacy descriptions of reliable / unreliable, etc. The AI will sack an enemy settlement, return to their own, and proceed to let the enemy rebuild a full stack in a few turns (just why). I understand AI at current levels will never be able to play like a real player, but surely the AI can be better than Attila's current one.

First thing you need to know, this is quite a bit different from previous total war games. If you go into this game thinking you are going to steadily build up your cities, expand your territory and fight other factions doing the same things you are going to be disappointed. This is set in the Migration era, agricultural conditions are worsening, hordes assembling and the huns are coming, shit is about to go down. When you start a campaign you need to have this in mind and some knowledge of the real history might actually be useful. You need to be aware of where you are on the campaign map, don't stay put! If you play the romans, priorities! A lot of territory needs to be abandoned initially, you start very overstretched. If you start as a migrator tribe, well, it's in the name, migrate. Think about where you could find decent, fertile land that you might be able to defend and before you get there, sack cities, a lot of cities. If you chose to play he huns think like this - you are the schoolyard bully, beat everyone up an make them pay tribute.

 If you embrace the setting and the chaos, uncertainty and destruction it brings you will have a much better time with this game. As hinted at before, reading up a little bit on the history of the time period and role play somewhat according to it, might help a great deal in enjoying the game, at least thats how I play and I'm having a lot of fun.

Another masterpiece from CA. As a longtime fan of all of the Total war games, I must say that this is a fine, polished successor to the previous games. good

It feels like this game was designed by the AI to cause as much harm to the player as possible.

I have played many more hours on my brothers account previously and I wanted to give this another chance on my account but after an extremely frustrating defensive coastal siege within which the AI glitched out a couple of boats that were stuck with regenerating ammunition (something I had never ever seen before), pelting my men and refusing to leave the field despite army losses, I felt like it was the straw that broke the camels back. This game is filled to the brim with stupid glitches and bollocks like this, half finished systems and overall feels like a construction site. There is a good game somewhere under all the chaff but the real question is whether you're prepared to put up with the bullshit of a game which has been effectively abandoned by it's developer and not updated since 2016. Another thing to keep in mind is that diplomacy is garbage in this. It's an absolute dumpster fire. Vassals will betray you for no reason, rando factions on the other side of the map will declare war on you, uproot themselves, let their empire fall to bits so they can do a bit of raiding in your territory or sniff out an undefended settlement like a pig searching for truffles. An example of this was Palmyra declaring war on me when I was playing the Saxons. Palmyra lost all their territory just so they could get one or two scraggly ass armies from Syria all the way up to the coast of France to raid 50 pennies before being absolutely annihilated by my angry and bemused Saxons.

I think the intention of this game was to be more of a survival game as apposed to a game centred around empire building but man did they miss the mark. It just boils down to having a map filled with rabid glitchy dumb AI that will find any excuse to declare war on the player no matter how bizarre or nonsensical the situation is. 

I love most of the other titles in the series (Warhammer 2, Rome 2, Shogun 2 etc) but this is probably my least favourite title, I could rant about it for hours. What a dogs dinner.

As of 2021, having bought it on first release, Or more so 2 weeks after its  release, this is still my favourite Total War since Rome 2 for Myself , I thought deserved a review . I would say its better for Rome 2 For extensive List of reasons that would bloat my review into a essay, best summarised: It does what rome 2 does but expands or balances it.
For those who played Rome 2 players/fans, it plays Like Later date Empire divided but More unit variation.  It suffers from serious lack of Optimsation , On GTX 1080 i get around 30-50 fps ultra, On 2080's with I7's builds (7000k onwards) This still gets roughly 60-70FPS average, just a forewarning, And turn times, Can be *UP TO 3 MINS*,But if you dont mind that there great game to be found here.

The whole game has Dark ages within the  Fall of Rome Apocalyptic feel, Everything from half ruined cities to Skinny gaunt looking civilians roaming the streets..Life in tough during Apocalyptic age Of migration . Cities are Shells of there former glory. Caked in a layer in mud and Mould. Rome the Once great capital is in disrepair , Part of the walls Have been repaired with Wooden Palisades, Improved barricades. Rome looks alot Worse for wear, The aqueducts that once brung fresh water Into the city are all but falling apart. A depressing sight. Winters are now harsh and cold. Food shortages and famine are serious issue now.causing crippling public order penalties and army attrition longterm. This likely to time period there was Unsustainable Population size in Age of migration That rome had caused with its Mass scale farming, Trade network of global food trade . that sustained  Millions. When rome fell, So did the Food production market, And farmers were not as needed as A man with sword and spear in his hand. This time is Rife with Banditry, betrayal and Minor nations carving a Name for oneself. . As the climate shifts, land becomes less fertile, forcing you to rejig your production buildings as the game goes on. Agents are hard to come by, but can be absolutely terrifying, even instigating civil wars. Batlles are hugely cinematic  and better and gorier than rome 2's. the Sound design is God tier, Civilains who run out of there homes on fire, Or civilians who fight back with whatever tools they have, and take few numbers out of your weaker auxiliary units / This game is So good for all its new mechanics, Yet many people dont 'click' with it, Due its Hard learning Curve. This is NOT a game you can steamroll. Every Nation is in shambles, Or opportunistic  Raiders and conquers of those Empires that fall. This isnt a time period of Large epic legionaries columns marching through Gaulish Lands In Huge numbers dominating  the field of war. No. this Is a time of petty factions crushing Thy Neighbour Over famines. Emergent factions Reclaiming there lost Pre romano  heritage,culture and Reverting back to the Old ways (Religion revert-ism ,Aka Brits becoming Pagans, or Better and more accurately put The Men of the North who had Landed on England Sands.

It's Total War Game but debatly Hardest one of them all. Due to Survival mechanics and Famines, Plagues and Ruined civilisations falling apart around you. Even conquered land is Shambles. And as story prgoress's you see The once mighty Roman empire all but Crumble to foreigners  and those within the walls of Roman heartland ,This is the 'Dark souls' Of Total war, I would rarely recommend this but Play your first campaign on Easy Difficulty, Fore warning: the game has scripted events, that May cause the death of your whole civilisation and Empire within a few hours in .This is a total war game, But its Hardcore, and Quite Historically Accurate, Its worth Looking up Online about Age of migration What this time period is set in. Honestly Besides it being Un-Optimised . 

Conclusion : This Game is 9.5. AOC/TLR/BAB are only 3 dlc i would recommend, The rest are Unit packs for Multiplayer or Single player Sub nations you may want to play,Ive tried Celts But you can tell they were Not meant to be played On European Stage. as Mid game they too weak, Militia like

My first Total War game was Fall of the Samurai.  I was in high school then, but my parents were not fan of video games that weren't Pokemon, Lego, Animal Crossing or Zoo Tycoon.  I still dearly love those game series, but by the summer before my Freshman year in high school I dearly wanted to play a "grown up" series.  Eventually I discovered FoTS through youtube and somehow convinced my father to buy it for me "Strategy is fine, but I don't want you going anywhere near those shooter games, understand?"  

I fell in love with FotS, but about a month after it released Rome II launched.  I was a stupid noob when it comes to pc games so I was enamored by it, launch "issues" notwithstanding.  I must confess I was so excited I even switched my language at the school from Spanish to Latin.  However, I never owned Rome II.  To this day it is not in my account.  Not enough money and nervous parents stopped that from happening.  Then Attila was announced, and I actually had money from my own job and I bought it myself.  And to this day it is among my favorite games I own.

It is set during the 5th century, or "Late Antiquity" during the terminal decline of Western Rome and the appearance and rise of the Huns.  Thematically, it has the best mood of all TW, being focused on survival not mindless conquest, and the mildew and decay in the UI is great.  WRE is by far the best TW campaign I have played, it is so different from the expansion of other starts, as you must decide what you are what you are willing to lose, not what you want to conquer.  Charlemagne and Belisaurius expansions are pretty meh, but the base game is worth the price on sale for the WRE expansion alone.

I definitely recommend this game. It does have some very strange performance issues. I can run the game on ultra with 60+ FPS at all times, but the game constantly stutters for 10+ seconds. I cannot figure out what exactly triggers it, but it happens no matter what settings it is set to. I even tried tweaking the .ini files to allow it to use all my CPU's threads - to no avail.

Other than that though, this game is pretty awesome. I only bought it because of the Total War sale right now, as I had avoided it because people said it was problematic. But the DLC and campaigns are really enjoyable. The Last Roman and Age of Charlemagne are super fun, and add new mechanics that are fun to work through. The base campaign also has constant changes/story events occurring so you never get "too comfortable" with your empire.

Also, the workshop has probably one of the best mods I have ever played with. Look up Medieval Kingdoms 1212. Realistically, you don't have to look far. It is the top mod on the workshop - and has the same quality and quantity of content that it could be marketed as it's own standalone game.

I would recommend this game just to play MK1212 on it's own - but the base game and DLC are great too. So it is win win.

Pick it up for sure, and the 66% discount right now is an added bonus.

1345 hours... and counting.
One of the most intriguing Total War games because the setting is so fluid, and there are macro events occurring that prevent you from playing a set-piece expansion strategy.  Sometimes the best strategy is to up-root your culture and move them to the other side of the map... just like what happened in history.  As Western or Eastern Roman empires you have to play defensively - including trading land or riches to buy off enemies or redirect them.  
Took me a while to totally understand what was going on, since the game is so different from others, and was initially frustrated by the ramp up in difficulty.  But sublimely rewarding once you get used to it.

Really enjoyed the variety of goals and playstyles that each faction has to offer even if some of the smaller ones lack in building and unit options. Specifically enjoyed the initially daunting yet exciting challenge of clinging onto to crumbling WRE, only to emerge later to crush your enemies. Requires both finesse in long-term strategy but also battle tactics.

Having said that, there a few things which could have been improved; diplomacy whilst useful, is lacking in certain options, military allies and vassals can frustrate you, and forcing you to conquer settlements in their groups of threes can be quite hard to navigate once you start to expand.

Still, overcoming the challenges faced by each faction makes the purchase more than worth it.

This is my first Total War game and my first REAL strategy game (not like Polytopia or anything like that), and I'm hooked and impressed. As of writing this review I am pretty new to PC gaming as a whole, and this was the first ever PC game that I bought on Steam. It's a good start to my collection.

First of all, the graphics are great, and while not perfect, still good enough to provide a good experience for any player. Learning the mechanics and gameplay is certainly an uphill battle as there are many stats to keep track of, but after playing for a while (and having more experienced friends), the game becomes fun and can be challenging for newcomers and experienced veterans alike.
 
The co-op mode is, well, okay. Playing this game with a friend isn't the most fun experience, mostly because you both have to be on at the same time at all times while doing turns, which can get boring. I haven't played Head on Head as of right now but I am assuming that it has similar gameplay as co-op. This game is certainly the most fun when playing single player.

There are so many factions and tribes to play as that it would be very difficult to actually finish everything in this game, which is good if you wanna play this game for a long time. The DLC adds many new great stories outside of the Grand Campaign, creating a more finished and better game as a whole.

To conclude, if you are a Roman lover or just a strategy game fanatic, Total War: Atilla is a well made, complicated, and fun strategy game that can keep you playing for hours and even days in your campaigns. I may not be the biggest total war fan or strategy game fan, but this game is certainly good if you're looking for some strategy.

Alright i am going to say I like the game. I have played all of the TW series up to the more recent releases of Warhammer and Troy. I`ve not loved every one of them (mainly disappointed in Troy), so I wont say there aren`t any issues with this game, but it is very good. 

Here`s a quick and simple review

Overall 7/10 I love this era of history so a quarter personal point there. But its good overall and its playable, its not very diverse when it comes to units [Nordic Levy and germanic levy.... my god] but the horde mechanic is nice, with a few modifications to the politics as opposed to Rome II.
 
Graphics 6/10 slight changes from Rome 2 with a gritty look

Gameplay 8/10 playing as a horde is my favorite part and the family tree is great but could be better with a little more customization. It does what it promises as a total war game, and there`s many mods that add new layers to them.

UI 7/10 I like the unit cards and the placement of everything, there is more of the screen that can be seen which is great. but there`s some little tweaks that a few mods fix, notably the zoom distance. 

AI 6/10 Its good but not its greatest strength it just depends on what difficulty your on like on legendary is VERY difficult but on normal its WAY to easy if you want to be challenged play on hard or up. There`s a few mods that have helped here as well.

Sound 7/10 They`re using the same sound files in the same places from Rome 2. Which is ok, but dissapointing. The music is nice though I really like the musical sound track as compared to Rome 2, especially the nomadic peoples throat singing is amazing.

Game: 10/10

My Experience: 

Dear God this is one of the hardest total wars I've ever played. Finally... finally beat the game as the Anteans. Took forever. 

First started out near the northeast like all the Slavic Tribes. Then built up my economy and armies for nearly 40-50 turns, whilst doing what I can to stay on the Huns good side. Used mercenaries to high heaven, and eventually started spreading outward. The Huns had decided I was too boring and went South, and I stole one of their women for my generals to force them into being somewhat nice to me. I then took up the Hun's historical job of pillaging and razing and pillaging and razing the barbarian factions, while also keeping up friendly banter with Eastern/Western Rome.

Eventually I had near 30 or so provinces... but decided to give all of it up, as trying to build the Wolf Totem (the way to achieve even a minor victory as the Anteans), was virtually impossible due to how many damn cities/towns/villages were not adopting Slavic Paganism as their religion. Realized that I had basically turned into the Roman empire, and so as to learn from the past and stop the future, I migrated, razing all of my settlements and invaded England before the Vandals or Ostrogoths could really get to me. 

Eventually, after what I dubbed "The Great Migration, as I pretty much traveled all the way across the sea, I invaded and took over England and Ireland. Fought a civil war along the way, again because of over-expanding like the Roman empire and migrating every army. Some men didn't really like that and decided to leave me to try to reclaim old Antean land. They didn't succeed. Didn't even really have to fight them too much. Most of my allies did that for me. 

But yeah, took over England because it had a source of timber and iron, with bonus lead... These were all the resources I needed for the Wolf Totem. Not to mention it was far easier to manage and bring up the Slavic religion due to my much smaller, yet far more defensible position in Engy. 

But yeah long story short, I got strong, fought disease after disease, over-expanded, decided to leave, The Great Migration, Civil War, Invasion of England, Changed Religion of England and Wolf Totem. Time for a well deserved break.

This is a good game that is mired by unfortunate and persistent issues (AI, pathfinding issues, odd mix of units [some factions have a ton of variety, others are mostly cookie cutter units], among other issues). 

I had this feeling that the game was somewhat barebones in some ways that was not overwhelming/bad enough to steer me away from it, but was noticeable and annoying.

One major issue that plagued the experience was the seemingly useless/unnecessary variety of units that had identical stats. In other words, the "variety" was merely superficial, as units looked different/had different names, but were either identical or functionally were about the same.

Also, a huge annoyance was the seeming futility of ranged units. This really weakened the experience and made the use of ranged units unsatisfying/useless. Removing a core component like this was especially upsetting when so many factions are range-focused (i.e.the Huns). They removed a core part of the game mechanics that has been around since the first Total War game I ever played (Shogun 1, circa 2000-2001)

However, the mod community has done a terrific job of building on the game and incorporating much needed features and tweaks. Age of Charlemagne campaign was MUCH better than the original game, particularly when modded (namely, Radious, cinematic combat, Olympic camera, etc.). 

Overall, I would recommend this (with mods, of course) to fans of the series, ONLY if it is: on sale for $30 or less, OR you are a big fan of the series and have not played this one yet. I am very pleased with my purchase and enjoyed the game very much. However, this is partially because I paid less than half the retail price of $60 for the original, and maybe another $10 for AoC and the Desert Factions DLC.

This review is less about the mechanics and more about the experience.

      First off, I love this game dearly. A six year relationship I was in ended just about as bad as it possibly could. She ran off with a family friend and it left me devastated. Without the lady around I was able to throw myself into this game (and drink way too much). I didn't care about work or any responsibilities at that time, so I was able to completely immerse myself into this game.

     I played as the Caledonians with a few mods to make the game longer. Divico was my faction leader. Pretty quickly off the bat his son was killed in battle against the Western Roman Empire. We took a city the Romans were hunkered down in (it was a brutal battle) and Divico killed the general responsible for his son's death in one on one combat. They were friends a few years prior. (Man I felt that betrayal and it was satisfying to watch Divico run that sword through him.)

     Years passed afterwards. Divico was infertile and could not have another child (this game has so many cool traits for the characters and infertility is one of them), so I raised a massive army. We navigated the dangerous seas and did a beach landing somewhere in Northern Africa. After establishing a foot hold there, we invaded Italy. It was FREAKING AWESOME. We took Rome and named it after Divico's dead son. That was not enough though. Now it was time to move forward and conquer the known world before Divico's death.

     After conquering 3/4s of the map, Divico realized there was nothing that would ever fill the void within him. So many years had passed with so many dead. His empire was spread thin and so was the loyalty of some of his men. In a brave charge, he sacrificed himself on the battlefield to hold off the enemy while his soldiers could withdrawal in a crushing defeat. Every major engagement in battle had him on the front lines with his men. Right after Divico's death, Attila invaded. My empire crumbled without a true leader and splintered.

      This was the best Total War experience I've ever had. A part of me could relate to Divico's loss and not finding something to fill that void. I learned a lot about myself throughout this grand adventure. Divico's death was symbolic to me and I still think about that character from time to time now years later and everything he represented to me. For that alone, this game will always hold a special place in my heart.

      I highly recommend this game and I hope you have a great experience with it.

A must game.  The best of Creative Assembly.

The good:
The game absolutely sells the hopeless atmosphere of late antiquity. Winters gradually become longer, lands less fertile and enemies become more aggressive. It also has an interesting faction dynamic, where massive empires like the WRE start out big, but in absolute shambles, while other kingdoms or migrators start small and build their way up. In that way factions can play out quite differently, as the Romans you're expected to survive, leave territories that you aren't worth defending in the short term behind until you can stabilize and then take them back. On the other hand with kingdoms you start small and just start expanding, while with migrators you look for a good place to settle in the beginning and on the way sack and plunder settlements until you get there, then use your ill-gotten riches to start your kingdom.

The meh:
While there is a diversity of the way you're supposed to play the game as certain factions, there isn't too much diversity in rosters. There's just way too many factions that are just the same Germanic stuff, but with a few unique units. It would be better if some of them had more identity, like how the Saxons and Vikings have Nordic rosters or how they fixed the Alans from just being yet another Germanic faction into being a cavalry-based faction. The battle AI isn't really too bad, it is aggressive which keeps you on your toes but it has one fatal flaw. It makes the general hang back with no reserves to keep him safe. That makes it easy to snipe him if you have cavalry units. After he's gone the rest of the enemy army suffers a massive morale debuff, so as a result some battles become a bit too easy even if you're outnumbered. Finally, the Huns rampaging after Attila is born is a cool concept that goes into the theme of the game, but it devolves into the same old stack spam where if you kill an army a new one just respawns out of thin air. It was tiresome in Shogun 2 where in one turn clans would just shit out full 20 unit samurai-tier stacks after you defeated their last one and it's tiresome here.

The bad:
Some things seem designed to trap the player into making a mistake. Certain technologies seem tailor made for that. Similarly, some building chains seem not even worth it because they just give too many penalties for too little gain. If they had a niche use I'd understand, but they don't, they are just bad. The game is also poorly optimized.

Should I buy it?
Yes, most of my complaints are about the vanilla singleplayer campaign, but there are some excellent mods that I recommend, in particular 1212AD which is what Medieval 3 should be, if they ever make it. The other is Ancient Empires if you prefer playing from an earlier era of Classical history and don't like Rome 2.

I very much enjoyed this game. Battles are engaging and the campaign for the different factions you can play as are thought provoking. Although not everything in the game is 100% historically accurate, I feel the different historical facets of the game were adequately researched and implemented accordingly. I was satisfied with the graphical options and settings however I did run into a problem a few times while playing in which some of my game's save files were corrupted. Normally I would brush this off but this happened more than occasionally which was very frustrating because I had to go back a few turns when this happened. Reluctantly, I learned to save after every turn, a minor inconvenience but noteworthy nontheless. This problem seemed to have gotten worse with each subsequent DLC campaign that I played, until the Age of Charlemange DLC was almost unplayable. Don't get me wrong, I love this game and I think anyone interested in this period in late Roman history, and anyone who really enjoys Total War should try this game. But I feel the developers could have put more effort in the coding side of things so as to make this game more playable. Another thing I should mention is that I think all of the factions in this game should be playable, but for some reason aren't (and for some reason seems to be prevalent in all Total War games i've come accross). But of course there are mods so you can go down that route. I found the naval battles to be a little glitchy and in need of more work as well. Overall though I would recommend you give this game a try, especially if it is on sale.

Attila: Total War is basically a huge expansion pack for Rome 2.

It brings much needed improvements to the family tree, research tree, politics and city building management which makes Attila the definitive Total War game out of the two.
Great game. I advice buying the DLC as it enhances the experience.

PROS
+Playing as the WRE feels like you're two steps from collapse and ruin
+Combat is hyperlethal compared to more grindy games like Total Warhammer
+World becomes more chaotic as campaign goes on with the remaining factions being hardened from their experiences (They're still AI)
+Religious chaos is great and hilarious as you see groups take crazy turns sometimes (WRE tends to go pagan when AI because of all their starting buildings)
CONS
-Many of quality of life changes from later games are lacking here, and it hurts (mods can fix some of these)
-Food mechanics make no sense (Province 1 has surplus, but Province 2 next door is in the negatives because no one shares)
-Sanitation was cool idea, but there's a reason later games don't have it.
-Cavalry is horribly overpowered (From my casual experience) 
-Attila is broken when he's an AI (Have to kill him multiple times, insta-spawns multiple doomstacks,)
My time played says it all.

 Я как олд помню еще первый сегун, но б** изменений с той поры все через одно место. Многие механики не работают так как нужно, а игра сплошная боль. Экономика через Ж***, управление на глабальной карте через Ж***, система восстаний просто АД, казалось бы битвы, конек всей игры и к тем много вопросов. Венцом идиотии это когда ты полностью выиграл битву, на твоей стороне перевес, но случайная смерть генерала вызывает бегтсво твоих солдат, от убегающего врага, и в целом глядя на ИИ в этой игре я могу быть спокойным за будущее человечества, никакой Скайнет нам не грозит. Помимо этого игра просто устарела морально и вместо симулятора правителя и больше похожа на монополию с солдатиками. Олды кто соскучлся за старыми ощущениями, не тратьти деньги, пройдите на ютубе.

If you're an experienced strategy gamer, then this game is for you. However, I wouldn't recommend it to everyone, the campaign is pretty unforgiving, especially when you play as the Western Roman Empire.
My Favorite

Overall a good game, this is my first total war game since Napoleon and a lot has changed, most of it for the better!

there is  a TL:DR at the end

[b]Campaign[/b]

The campaign is much more in depth and I appreciate the extra complexity in faction and unit management. Now you can control your court and help maintain the balance of power, it is not as complicated as other games but in TW I don't think this matters too much. I really like the food supply and the trading. I like the diplomacy more, now in negotiations you can see why they either like or dislike you, and you can manipulate this to your advantage, but sometimes it can be a bit random.

You can recruit generals, which is a really nice feature, I remember in other total war games the chronic general shortage. You can appoint Governors who are province wide and are not the same as Generals, no more ai auto-manage. I also like the Province system, settlements are organised into provinces, all settlements in a province can be controlled from one screen simultaneously, settlements in a province share things like food, public order and recruitment.

Public order is much better. It is on a scale from +100/-100. When it hits -100 you have a rebellion. Much more predictable and controllable than with previous public order which often seemed completely random. There are other features too like corruption which I like.

Armies crossing the sea, a nice feature now it that armies can cross the sea without having to faff about building and moving a navy to a certain position, you just right click and your army goes in boats by themselves. HOWEVER it does feel this feature is overused, for some factions it does seem a bit stupid. For Saxons, Danes, Jutes.. i.e. raiders I guess it makes sense, but for WRE... not so much. 

Raiding settlements, at least there are a lot of game mechanics for it. However as there are only 3 settlements (or so) per province, and no minor villages to raid a settlement you basically need an army, and once you have an army you may as well conquer the place. This feature could have been nice if they'd thrown a few fishing villages and things in, like the farms or towns in Napoleon, but there aren't any, so raiding is a bit pointless. Because of this Britain falls within the first 3 turns... so no more raiding :( .

Religious differences now have much less effect on the campaign than in Barbarian Invasion, I am a bit lukewarm about this change. It does make it a bit too easy just to steamroll whole regions and not really incur many religious/cultural penalties. I remember in Barbarian Invasion I thought it would be fun to see what converting your religion was on turn 1 would do, constant rebellion, uprisings and circa 2 million denari (thank goodness for cheats) later and I had gone from Pagan to Christian. But now if your Germanic Pagans conquer Latin Christians, there don't seem to really be any penalties, this is further made piss easy by Stonehenge which limits religious problems by 20%.

They have gone for the newer historiography when it comes to fall of Rome, and gone for corruption/food shortage/migratory crisis narrative, I like this change and it is well represented in game.

Compared to the 'original' (Rome: Barbarian Invasion) I think it is an overall improvement. Much more in depth, much more historically accurate (in the way the campaign mechanics work, food, 'invasion' more migration than war). The campaign is much more interesting and engaging  (although this may be because I have decided to fight every battle on map to prevent full stack armies being defeated by 1/4 stack enemies...)

[b]Battles[/b] (Campaign)

The battles are quite good, however there are some unit collission issues still, when a mass of infantry is engaged you do sort of end up with a soup, shield walls do not actually form shield walls (they have gaps), and they fight 1v1, so a lone enemy in your  [strike]formation[/strike]  soup could still take ages to die. The controls are like any of TW game. General skills are nice, however they are a bit tanky verging on OP.

Pikemen are completely OP, hmm I see you have a top level legionary unit... well I have tier 1 pikemen so f*** you.

The auto-resolve feature can sometimes be completely stupid, I wouldn't really recommend using it unless the odds are at least 75% in your favour, or crazy things can happen.

[b]Atmosphere[/b]

The music and visuals of this game are very good, many times it does feel bleak which is very appropriate. They seem to have upped their game on the music front too, it is now much more atmospheric, you can really imagine your Empire is crumbline around you, or that you are a newly established kingdom trying to assert its dominance in a turbulent world. The original Rome had the best music, but I feel that this soundtrack for this game was the best choice. 


[b]Glitches/Crashes/Technical Issues[/b]

I have encounted only one crash so far, apart from that it has been plain sailing.
game can be a bit resource demanding, I would have liked a simplified campaign map.


[b]Conclusion[/b]

I would recommend buying, however it is important to acknowledge the game has flaws, however they are not nearly as bad as the problems other titles had and still have in some cases (Empire, Rome II). Everything seems pretty decent so [b]7/10[/b].

I reviewed this game back when I had less than 60 hours in it, Rome II was still a pile of hot garbage, and I had no idea what I was doing in either. It's been five years, I've gradually climbed up to 250+ hours (mostly recently), and I can safely say that this game is a mess. The mess it was meant to be. Sure, there are a lot of issues in the campaign with the AI and the intent vs realization, but it's a game that really does do its job. Playing as one of the Roman factions I told my friend it was like a horror game, and every press of the end turn button was like Russian roulette where all six chambers are loaded with different bullets. It intends to abuse you, and does so brilliantly. 

The pace of this game is much slower than other TW titles, intentionally so, and that really adds to the pressure and also makes you think much more carefully about decisions, as they will haunt you for a much longer period of time. Everything you do must be intentional, and it even on the easier difficulties the game is challenging. 

One downside to the game is that it depends on you to play it properly. There is a right way to play the game, and there is the correct way to play the game. As you scale up the difficulty the difference between the two becomes painfully clear. Especially as the Empire factions such as the Romans and the Sassanids. At the lower difficulties you can, with some challenge, attempt to hold the empires together, manage your economy, and protect the borders as some sort of casual balancing act that is still rewarding for the struggle it puts you through. At the harder difficulties you feel like you really have to make the hard choices leaders of that day and age could not. Abandoning settlements as the Western Roman Empire so that you have less borders to defend, or demolishing all the churches to limit the strain on your coffers. Reviving paganism for the public order bonus. It kind of does a great job showing that if you attempt to play this game with historical accuracy, you're doomed from the start.

That, is why this game is so great. It gives you a historical scenario, and the ability to change it. Through excellent strategizing, brilliant tactics, and cunning policy, you can rewrite the outcome of moments which decided centuries of history.

The most annoying thing about this game, and there are quite a few things, is the ability of the AI to know exactly where you are weak AT ALL TIMES NO MATTER WHAT. They will send units from the other side of the world and attack the one developing city with no defense, without ever sending units or scouts or anything to that area. It's damn annoying. 

Second most annoying thing, and this annoys me about Total War games generally, is the inability to engage an army that wants to run from you if you don't have a hero capable of slowing them down. At least give us the ability to attack while in the forced march stance at a penalty. Anything is better than endlessly chasing an enemy army that has been fucking with you for the last 10 turns. 

Third most annoying thing is the random AI migrations. After spending a lot of time building up reputation and finally getting a faction to ally and trade with you, they will suddenly, for no damn reason, decide to migrate, abandoning its city, and therefore abandoning the trade agreements you spend dozens of turns trying to secure. 

Finally, if you play this game, whatever you do, don't accept marriage proposals from other factions. Generals and governors and other characters will suddenly become inaccessible to you. Their loyalty will drop, but they will have vanished from your family tree, and therefore there is nothing you can do to stop them from rebelling (and they WILL rebel).

This game is a mixed bag. The gameplay is complicated, between additions to the campaign economy and to the political system; battles have more special abilities than is realistic or fun for me. There's too much micromanagement, and battles feel like a click-fest rather than giving a few basic orders and watching what happens.

This game has the most poorly taught campaign I've seen in the series. I'm a Total War veteran at this point, and it was so unapproachable I put it down for a few years. On top of that, there's no "standard" starting faction. The most famous factions are the Romans and Huns. The Roman Empires come pre-built but falling apart, so you have to manage 20+ provinces under pressure from the start. The Huns don't settlements, so their game mechanics are completely different from the other factions. The Sassanid Persians are easier, but are politically complex with the large number of satrapies. Once you choose a faction, you have to manage your budget, your food, your trade networks, your diplomatic relations, your research, your risk of bandits spawning, your people's happiness, your risk of disease outbreak...and none of the AI factions have to deal with any of these things. It just keeps building armies and units regardless of money, never has settlements rebel, etc.

But there are also some unique features that make Attila appealing. The theme is terrific. Attila's Huns invading the Roman Empire signal the decline of Classical Civilization. The destruction is apparent from the opening cutscene. Nearly everything is dark, and what isn't dark is on fire. The music hits the right notes, and sets the stakes at hand and the trajectory of the Western world. When you choose a faction, start with the Saxons or Franks. They are smaller factions with normal gameplay, and you can learn the systems under pressure from fewer directions. When you start playing, go to diplomacy first, sue for peace with all factions, trade with all factions that will do so, and make a non-aggression pact with any nearby trustworthy factions you don't plan on invading soon.

Then build buildings that will balance food, happiness, and sanitation. Once those are safe, THEN you can make money. Then invade at the first good opportunity.

That's all the strategy you need to start. It took me forever to figure out, and I only found the Franks and Saxons at a YTer's recommendation.

Also, the Charlemagne DLC is worth buying, and it's probably better than the main campaign. You might even start with that before attempting the main campaign.

TL;DR:

In summary, it's good. It's a bit over-complicated and completely inaccessible, but if you go in with a guide and choose the right faction, it's fun. Maybe try Charlemagne DLC first because it's simpler and more streamlined.

I bought this game based on other reviews.  I have every Total War franchise and have always loved them.  I WOULD NOT recommend this game to previous owners of the series.  

Don't get me wrong, it's a good game, but seeing as this is the 20-21-22 version of the original, it just really lacks.  The lack of variety of units has been a disappointing for a couple of versions to come out.  

Total War Shogun 1 & 2// Rome // Empire are probably the best IMO.  Warhammer I believe stands on its own because it's a completely separate story, units and so on...  However, MANY of the games are at best a DLC.  Three Kingdoms is "good" but again, I feel they keep short changing the consumer.  Shogun 2 is the only one that felt like there was extra creating your character.

The rest don't buy until they're in the $15/$10 and under price point.  

Attila suffers from a poor research and development to better buildings and units.  It's boring and so are any of the units you do upgrade to.  There isn't really any original design to any of the units.  Different factions have some variations but nothing is really any stark difference.  The AI is pretty stupid and predictable and no matter how well you control the Huns, they continuously spawn 3 sets of armies.  No real point in creating peace as they eventually swarm to zerg something.  So it's a constant battle of attrition.  The lack of information in game to bring you out to a browser of whatever wikipedia style information tab is annoying.  Maybe that was developed to save on the bloat of the game, but definitely seems cheap to hover over something and then wait for a window to pop up.  The buildings have absolute musts and I never felt I needed to have "naval force".  The limited number of generals kind of just there to inhibit you enough for the AI to be annoying.  The senate/influence/family seemed really optional when in fact it could have been pretty amazing.  Perhaps to have great generals have amazing offspring to conquer later on...  So much more development is potentially there but never takes advantage.  Cities always have a real horrible defense without a general that you have no way of influencing.  I think if I was going to buy a new Total War game, there would have to be some love and care into many of these features and more.  It shouldn't feel like "skins" and I would like the world to evovle throughout time to experience a true world history and your ability to influence that story based upon how well or bad you do in history.  If it could only be more dynamic...  Just feels like since 2000, there have been little innovations and as time has gone on there are a handful of noticeable differences. 

Game is really missing some customization, world impact/influence and dynamic play.  I love the series, don't get me wrong, but as a gamer, being objective, I can't say this was a good version of the game.  Found myself really ignoring most of the features and just rolling end term to get to the next upgrade or city siege.

I am saddened to say that after spending nearly two weeks on this game that I would not recommend purchasing it. For the first time in a while I was really enjoying a total war game, I have purchased and played nearly every total war game since the original shogun and rome total war. I believe there is only two that I have not played. All of them have been fun in their own ways, but this one was really fun and refreshing. The game itself is awesome, varying challenging to play and almost impossible at time regardless of the difficulty setting but that made it all the better. For once it felt realistic and super challenging. After two weeks though right about the time I was set to win the victory conditions for the game it just crashes... No matter what I do the game just crashes right before I get the victory screen. I have tried everything from reinstalling to updating drivers and software, I even made sure the overclock was running smooth as I thought it was a power issue. After looking online this seems to a constant problem with many players saying that it will eventually happen on what ever play through you have, whether that is 5 hours of play in or 60 hours it is the game itself will just stop being playable. If it wasn't for that I would say this game is one of the best in total war series, but because of that it has sank to the absolute worse.

This game looks slightly worse than Rome 2, but somehow manages to run even worse.  The 55-60 FPS you managed to get in Rome 2?  Yea, reduce that by about half if you're lucky.  I was able to just get by with running it on average at 1920 x 1080 resolution and get 28 FPS with a 1050 ti and an i5 6400.  That should not happen.  To make matters worse, for some reason, when you launch it through the Rome 2 launch app, it gives a 6-7 increase in average FPS.

Add on top of this the identical gameplay of Rome 2, and you see very little has changed in terms of battle-level tactics or strategy, save for the over-powered BS of crossbows, along with the broken siege AI (when they were defending, the AI managed to seal themselves all off in the harbor with a wall...a wall facing them, so when I took the city, I merely lined up my crossbowmen along it and slowly but surely killed every single unit....), and the unnecessarily long turn times and you have a game that's a step back in both design and execution than the previous one.

[h1]OVERALL SCORE[/h1]
Extremely not recommended

[h1]REPLAY VALUE[/h1]
Extremely high

i fixed the game breaking bug and now that its playable i like it. unlike rome 2 you actually have more choices in campaign and that makes a huge difference to me. Also depending on who you play as the difficulty changes which is also refreshing. i think the variety of troop types and the way they upgrade as you research and build is great. the political system starts off kinda complicated to learn and in some ways it stays difficult but in other ways its easy once you learn some tricks. 

i give the base game itself a 7 out of 10. if i didint have to do my own fixes i would have given it an 8. 

some tips with possibly minor spoilers

tip one it will be very hard to fight against the huns so unless you are being the huns or very experienced stay very north or very west. 

tip two, the huns burn down a ton of settlements on their path to rome, save your money and take advantage you can hold the line build your wealth and forces keep spies on them and then rapidly expand. (unless your looking for more of a challenge of course.)

tip three the auto resolve battles are not as easy as in rome 2 they are more like the previous games before that and can unexpectedly sway in a good or bad outcome so if its close or even match its best to just do it yourself.

One heck of a game. 
This may just be the best historic total war ever. 

Nothing screams survival RTS, like a norse faction having to get in their boats, sack Londinum for "gas" money, and resettle in Africa. I did cause someone to do that BTW. A shame people back then didn't have Greta Thurnberg to warn them of the climate-change, otherwise people wouldn't have to pitch up horde-camps in my fertile southern provinces. 

Oh and it has fantastic mod support so everything can be customized to ur liking: the pace of battles, faction and unit balancing etc.

when i first bought the game i wasn;t sure if i was going to like the game as everyone at that time said that it's either broken or not worth the money. Now granted i bought the whole game at a steam winter sale (incl all dlc's) for like 20 bucks and haven't regretted buying one bit. This game despite its age, holds up really well along wth Rome 2. Although this game has something that Rome 2 doesn't. The Medieval 1212 mod :P Jokes aside, this game has some advantages, first of all its graphics are still top notch compared to other historical!! total war titles. Its in game engine along with a fully fleshed out family tree makes you care for your characters. Ifound myself playing as the WRE actually struggling to keep some of my family members alive for marriages or for their abilities. Also another big thing, marriages are ever present. Trying to find a suitable bride/groom for your family to marry into was quite a challenge because more often than not, i would find this excellent bride that had the positive traits that i was looking for only to realise that she belonged to an enemy faction. So i would shape my playgame accordingly as to please my sworn enemy into marrying her. Another big thing was the climate change that they introduced. Ok, i would be a liar if i say that i haven't used any mods for this thing, because in vanilla after some turns it gets ridicullous, but the whole concept of that is so interesting that with the right kind of mods it is actually really fun. Some of the problems that Attila has, are some of the lifelong problems of CA. Some factions may feel like a copy/paste of other larger ones and generally not offering anything new to the game. Most faction other than WRE or ERE have a similar playstyle. I would love for CA to make a dlc offering some new units replacing some of the stock units for every faction giving some of them a unique flavour. There are many things that CA can add to this game, drawing inspiration from the unique playstyles and units they introduced in warhammer series that i believe one or two dlc offering new units to replace some and adding some challenges to each faction would really skyrocket the game, especially now that it has come int spotight again. To sum it up, with a few mods to make up for any little inconviniences this game has me coming back and enjoying every campaign that i choose to play.
