Recommended with a number of caveats. 

I'm a longstanding total war fan and started playing Attila just recently because I found myself captivated with the Late Roman Imperial period. It's a time of turmoil and tragedy for the Romans. A dying of the light, as darkness comes from both within and without. Fighting back against the darkness and halting the Roman collapse is what interested me here, and if you share that interest then this game may be for you.

As for the actual mechanics and content, it is very much Rome II with some interesting additions and some further polish. Compared to other total war games, the quality and variety of the battles is enjoyable. The siege battles are very interesting and cool, and it's certainly also nice to be able to play naval battles and have them connect to land battles. The characters system is also quite well fleshed out, and there are plenty of ways to get attached to your favorite characters with all their positive and negative traits.

The main issues I have with the game come in two categories. Firstly the AI issues and secondly the "Modern Total War" issues.

AI problems are easy to describe, basically this refers to the strange and stupid ways in which the AI will behave. In field battles this is less pronounced as the AI generally employs quite competent and aggressive tactics. The AI generally also defends settlements very well, but as an attacker it generally performs very poorly, getting its generals killed and armies routed. The campaign map AI is the worst failure in this category. In diplomacy and army movement it seems more interested in infuriating and annoying the player faction rather than building its own power, such as when factions refuse to trade or surprise attack you to sack one settlement only to then be crushed by your much more powerful armies. The only way to play is to treat every faction as a potential enemy and never leave a frontier unguarded. All of the AI's nonsensical campaign plays are facilitated by the bonuses that the AI gets to its finances and empire maintenance. It feels incredibly frustrating to be the victim of unfair AI strategies that would get the player killed if they attempted them.

Lastly we have a bunch of issues that irritate me as a fan of total war classics like medieval 2. In no particular order, these are: Building slot restrictions, army stack limits, shared province wide resources and public order, the politics system, the recruitment system and the technology tree. Some of these mechanics impose artificial and annoying restrictions, while others attempt to add depth to the campaign while only making it more tedious and time sink like. In my mind the game suffers from these issues to a degree, but thankfully not enough to prevent me from enjoying it.

So if you like the time period and are able to overlook the issues, enjoy this fun and expansive Late Imperial Roman sandbox.

Always loved Total war, one of my favorite games I have ever played since I was little but Total War: Attila is for sure one of the best total war games I have brought and played.

[h1] Disappointments [/h1]

[list]

[*] MP Campaign doesn't work with mods anymore.

[/list]
"Gods of the afterlife, spare my A R S E! Why do you trouble my digestion today?"

I honestly think this would be one of the best Total War games out there if CA hadn't botched the game's optimization. The vanilla campaign can be very challenging. Mechanics like governorship and a more in-depth internal policy makes this more immersive than Rome 2, if you ask me. Siege battles are great, especially due to the well made custom/specific settlements (Yes, you can defend/siege the Theodosian walls of Constantinople). 

Overall, if you exclude the optimisation issue and the time setting, this is what Rome 2 should have been. It's a shame that CA didn't give this game the same post-launch attention it gave Rome 2, especially in terms of optimization.  

Lastly, the mod support is great! Two especially good mods are Medieval Kingdoms 1212 and Ancient Empires, which are set in the medieval period and the 2nd Punic War, respectively. 

The game has its flaws, like the previously mentioned bad optimization. Additionally, there are some strange design choices in terms of modability, like hardcoded music and non-modifiable settlement location. However, I would still recommend this game if you are a total war fan (especially if you prefer the historical titles).

One of my favorite games in the Total War franchise thus far, and a huge improvement on its predecessor, Total War Rome II. Attila takes essentially the same engine and incorporates a new set of mechanics and flavor that perfectly suit the transition from early to late antiquity. The doomsday vibe of the game's sparse narrative helps to ground its sandbox in the psychological space of its setting: the end of the Roman world and the beginning of a new era. This game is essentially a spiritual sequel to Total War Rome: Barbarian Invasion, with the migratory tribes and the Huns stealing the show in both aesthetics and mechanics.

If you played the Nomadic Tribes DLC for Rome II, you might have been disappointed at the lack of "Barbarian Invasion" style nomad mechanics, leaving them with the same city-based gameplay as sedentary civilizations. Attila makes up for this in droves, with a massively expanded nomad migration system that's tremendously fun to play compared to settled states. This is why the Great Migrators (think Goths, Franks, Alans, and Vandals) are at the center of the game, with the formidable Huns driving them westward into the ill-defended Roman territory. All these factions have no cities at the start, but instead carry their cities with them as mobile army encampments that can be packed up and moved on the fly (with construction pausing while the army is on the move and resuming when they encamp). Unlike the Huns, though, the migrators are not locked into staying nomadic: their goal is to raid their way into settled territory until they find a good place to settle down and create their own kingdom. This gives an otherwise sandboxy game a firm sense of goal and direction, whether you want to recreate the historical path of your tribe's rise to power, or change history and make them outlast their real-life counterparts.

The player who wants to face a near-impossible challenge also has the option of playing as the Western Roman Empire and trying to prevent its fall, but as they have a massive amount of territory to defend, they will have to pick and choose what parts of the empire are most important to hold onto. Eastern Rome (aka the Byzantines) is a more realistic challenge for players who aren't quite so masochistic, as for them one merely has to recreate their historical survival, though against they won't be likely to come out with their empire intact.

As for the tactical battles, Attila rebalanced the system of Total War Rome II to better fit the time period and make for more dynamic gameplay. Unit morale is much more of a factor, as all but the best trained units will rout under sufficient pressure from the enemy (or if you accidentally throw them into friendly fire), though they may also regroup and return to the battle if their casualties aren't too severe. There are more dramatic differences between factions as well, so for example migrating nomads cannot capture buildings, only destroy them. Overall, the battles in Attila feel more fluid than previous titles, and it's much more possible to snatch victory from the jaws of defeat, or vice versa...

Both battle and campaign maps are rendered in gorgeous detail even on medium settings. As the fifth century goes on, the map will actually change over time. The onset of climate change, which rendered the northern regions inhospitable during this time period, is reflected in the reduction of regional fertility and increasingly barren land. Speaking of which, the land is also likely to suffer from invaders razing settlements, which not only wipes them off the map but also burns and desolates the entire region with a glorious animation sequence that leaves the trees burned and the territory uninhabited.

Major political features have fleshed out the campaign as well. You can now assign governorships to your leaders (a feature appallingly absent from Rome II's unwieldy and unfinished politics system), and you can distribute other offices to worthy characters in your employ, so long as keep an eye on their loyalty to make sure they don't become too ambitious for their own good. Religion is also a part of the game's mechanics for the first time as well, replacing the culture spread from Rome II, and dynamically changing over time as you construct religious buildings and proclaim edicts. This opens up the possibility for the player to create their own goal of spreading their faction's religion across the entire map, or perhaps preserving a historically embattled religion from this period, like Arianism or one of several Pagan faiths. Tying into this, faction and unit voice callouts will often reference their faction's religion, which adds to the flavor of an era in which religious motivations played a large role in military morale.

There's definitely a lot more I want to explore in this game, but already it stands out to me as one of the most interesting titles in this series to date, and one that has aged relatively well compared to its predecessor. It's a shame there's only two DLC campaigns, compared to the massive number of interesting scenarios available for Rome II, but there are some excellent total conversion mods available on the Steam Workshop that help scratch that itch for more historical content. I would argue that Attila is the gold standard of comparison for future TW titles and fans of the series should definitely consider picking it up.

[b]Flawed masterpiece still worth playing for its innovative & challenging campaign mechanics[/b]

First, the elephant in the room: ‘Attila’ is poorly optimized, to the extent that it runs worse than its predecessor Rome 2 (or at least, worse than Rome 2 in its current, final, ‘Emperor Edition’ state).

We’re talking half the frame rate of R2 with equivalent graphics settings - and the Attila engine is evidently unable to take advantage of the brute power of modern graphics cards to get itself out of trouble - so don’t think that this warning doesn’t apply to you just because you have a modern GPU. 

At best, your Nvidia 2060 will allow you to add 8x AA and x16AF, SSAO, DoF and maybe distortion effects (i.e. aspects of rendering internal to the GPU) while the game waits for your CPU to compute shadows, unit detail, trees, grass, terrain i.e. whatever game assets are hardcoded to be handled by the processor only.

Having said that, ‘poorly optimized’ does not mean ‘broken’: the game is stable to the extent that I can’t recall any crashes. So it’s a question of what you as a player are prepared to put up with: this is a game that struggles to run its own internal benchmark - a short scenario featuring less than twenty units - satisfactorily on maximum settings; so it’s really no wonder that siege battles featuring four full stacks degenerate into slide-shows. 

As a result, I have found myself autoresolving multi-army siege battles that I would otherwise have enjoyed - a sad thing to say about a game in which epic confrontations should be the highpoints of a playthrough, not an ordeal to be sidestepped.

Ok, on to the game itself:

Attila was the first recent TW game to reintroduce the horde mechanic, whereby some factions don’t have any settlements but instead camp wherever the hell they like, a mechanic which increases scope for creative playstyles. Moreover it adds a new dimension even if you don’t play as a horde yourself, since dealing with hordes is a new challenge for settled factions too; and if you lose your last settlement, you may find yourself playing as a horde after all!

The new ability to 'raze' (obliterate) captured settlements also adds creativity, since the player (and the AI too) now has the option to delete entire cities from the map rather than overextend their empire by capturing them, or risk having to return at some point after merely 'sacking' them - now there is a more permanent solution available. 

This can be used to create buffer zones of inhospitable wasteland around your core provinces; or (Attila allows you to abandon i.e. raze your OWN settlements) in desperate circumstances you can employ a 'scorched earth' policy to deny an advancing enemy the benefit of the region they are about to capture.

The option to 'recolonise' abandoned/razed settlements, though costly in men and gold, provides a means for players with the necessary funds to snap up some of the devastated real estate left in the Huns' wake (providing, that is, you are confident they are really gone...).

And if you are playing as a horde and you capture a prosperous, fertile or easily-defensible settlement, you have the dilemma of whether it might not be a good moment to settle after all.

Food is now on a per-province basis so no subsidising your hungrier provinces from more productive ones.

Climate change may sound like it’s been shoe-horned in by politically correct developers but is actually a really solid game mechanic since it adds incentive for factions to migrate south to more fertile lands (as well as west, to escape the Huns).

The Huns represent a fascinating dilemma for the player: do you evade or confront them? Indeed the mid-game can feel more like survival horror than strategy if you find yourself isolated against multiple hordes: there's no doomstack like a Hun doomstack...

A raiding horde also 'steals' food from the host province, thus decreasing public order and preventing resident units from replenishing so 'hoping they just go away' is not a foolproof response.

Army integrity feels like it should always have been a feature of Total War games, particularly when combined with attrition when marching in snowy or desert regions (a mechanic missing from, say, Rome 2).

Army traditions were already in R2 but are even more valuable now, because you can spec your army to be, say, resistant to snow attrition.

Customizing your generals/governors (and indeed spies etc) is an interesting challenge but gets a bit tiresome late on when you have numerous agents and armies.

The politics system manages not to be obnoxious for once, not least because here, civil war is not ‘scripted’ (i.e. inevitable at some point). However the key mechanic (of striving for a balance between authoritarianism and lack of control) is somewhat counter-intuitive so perusing a community guide or two is highly recommended. 

I also like the crucial role that female characters play here behind the scenes, rather than appearing on the battlefield as they did in Rome 2. The versatility of influential noblewomen as 'fixers' (providing everything from loyalty boosts for wavering generals to outright assassinations) means that careful attention to the diplomatic marriage market can be even more valuable here than in other TW games. 

Diplomacy seems to work better than average, with factions for the most part seeming to act in their plausible self-interest.

Steam achievements are well integrated and comprehensive although the absence of specific recognition for completing a campaign on 'hard' or 'very hard' feels like a slight to non-legendary players.

The usual several victory conditions strike a good balance between challenge and fairness (at least, in my experience) and I particularly appreciate the absence of arbitrary time limits. Rewards for simply surviving until certain dates feel earned and the optional goals for each 'chapter' provide some ideas about what direction you might want to take with your faction whilst representing no great loss if you choose to ignore them and go your own way.

The tech tree is set out more logically than in R2 and allows the player to 'customize' their faction in a variety of directions e.g. do you go for elite spearmen before swordsmen? Or is sanitation (or eking a bit more food out of the increasingly barren soil) the better priority? Conceivably you could experience two very different playthroughs with the same faction as a result.

Faction variety is excellent, to the extent that playthroughs with, say, the Sassanids, the seafaring Danes or the snow-resistant Slavs provide very different challenges.

Unit variety is also very good and provides a particular incentive to recruiting exotic mercenaries when marching far from home. 

Attila also offers for purchase some of the best DLC expansions in the Total War series, namely 'Age of Charlemagne' and 'The Last Roman'.

Minor annoyances:

Why can’t I look at the initial post-battle screen for as long as I want? 

Why can’t I target an enemy siege tower directly, rather than only being allowed to fire at the enemy unit that is pushing it? Are siege towers protected by some Geneva Convention I don’t know about??

The sheer awkwardness of placing units on certain types of terrain (typically, ‘farmland’-style landscapes, frequently encountered around settlements) suggests that the CA ‘terrain-scaping’ team never actually played any battles themselves.

End turn times are long compared to later games e.g. TWWH. Here, you literally have time to go make a cup of tea.

[b]TLDR:[/b]

DON’T BUY IT if you are just looking for a graphically-improved Rome 2 that will run as smoothly as Rome 2 does these days;
DON’T BUY IT if you would actually prefer to play Total War Warhammer, Thrones of Britannia or Three Kingdoms but assume that an OLDER title will run better on your pc (it won’t);

DO BUY IT if interesting campaign mechanics are more important to you than game engine optimization.

DO NOT GET THIS GAME IF YOU WANT MULTIPLAYER GAMEPLAY.

I think Total War: Attila is a good game, it's by no means my favorite but a good game. I prefer over Rome II for it's time period, I've always liked it more. The default factions are great in this game. I also love the ability to burns down entire cities. I also love campaign co-op, I think they should expand upon it in future Total War games and even allow more players, also make it where you can be allies or if you want wage war, not forcing one or the other.

Now for the problems...

I love the factions, but Sega got scummy with selling so many factions in little DLC packs. They're already in the game, you're just paying for the ability to play them.

Sometimes I feel like the lighting looks a little off in the game, maybe that's just me, I don't know.

Unlike Rome II, changing the main city center culture is overly expensive for no reason. In fact I never liked the changing building culture system at all. It makes no sense. They're just dumb founded on expanding buildings because they look different? Very dumb.

Population get's angry way too easily, no matter how much you suck them off sometimes. This would be less of an issue if you could take soldiers away from generals, which leads me to my last issue with this one and all the recent games...

The general system is awful, only being allowed to have so many generals until upgrades, not being able to split your men from their general, all makes no sense and is a bad system. They should go back to Medieval II/Empire.

There is no ability to gift cities, which makes co-op a nightmare.

Overall it's a good game though, maybe I'm just a little bit of an old fashion Total War fan.

I enjoyed the most first Rome, Medieval 2 and Shogun 2. I also played first Medieval and Napoleon, avoided Empire and Rome 2 becouse of terrible AI and annoying mechanics. I thought that Attila will be better, and I was disappointed.

When I first bought the game I thought I will be enjoying a huge, interesting and difficult campaign. That I will be carefully planning my moves and military campaigns thanks to various and detailed maps, that I will be fighting in exciting and huge battles, protect cities, street after street, falling back to inner walls and barricades, that I will burn the cities and raze them to the ground, that I will enjoy great graphics, and overall gameplay. Oh boy, was I wrong.

In the campaign, I didnt have to plan anything. There was no military campaign that seemed hard and challenging enough to waste time on checking the maps and planning moves. The AI will not protect its territories and will do just random, sensless things. Did you want to have a nice historical experience of the campaign? Then you will not find it here, becouse, starting before 400AD, Rome will not hold for next 20 turns and will fall like a century before it historically did, it starts as theoretically biggest military power but thanks to incapable AI, Roman armies are always nowhere to be seen. You will see tribes wich in history did not do much to do a lot, and those that mattered in history to not matter at all in this game. Playing as Saxons I expected nice fights in British scenery with the Celtic tribes but little of that occured. The Celts were bothered with conquering Galia and Hispania, leaving their British territories defenceless, and the Scandinavians, who should also target Britain, did the same thing as the Celts. And this happens always, all the time.  Mainland barbarian tribes are doing nothing.  They do not care about their historical targets and territories they should want. If most of Roman territory is conquered, barbarians will not fight each other for it. When Galia was conquered by the Ebdani and Jutes, Franks, who still had one province, instead of fighting other barbarians for the nearest territory, seemed it fit to just try to invade Roman territories in Spain. Leaving their homeland defenceless, of course. I just steamrolled everything and everyone, even on hardest difficulties, and my skills had nothing to it. You will need no skills. You will just autoresolve most of the battles becouse situations when the chances are equal will be very rare - the AI will not bother to have any strategic advantage over you. And when that rare opportunity to have a big battle occurs there will be yet another disappointment. You will not enjoy any good graphics becouse optimization in this game is a joke. The game is just a slideshow without specific mods improving this matter. And after you get rid of terrbile optimization you will be disappointed once more. The AI will not bother with commanding units in a smoewhat organised and intelligent way. There will be no battle in which the AI will be a threat to you. There will be no interesting sieges too - the AI will just throw all of its units into a single alley and you will easily surround them and cut them down. And the public order system is as annoying as useless. It is almost impossible to keep your people happy, but after some time I realised that there was no point in it. The rebels that spawn when your people are angry have only some units on the first turn and are theoretically supposed to get more over time, but it never happens. The rebel AI, instead of gathering forces, attacks nearest settlement on the first turn, and gets smashed by the garrison.

In overall: The AI is terrible. On the maps I cannot look anymore becouse of bordergore. Battles are easy and disappointing.  Diplomacy is senseless and disappointing. Campaigns are easy, boring, and disappointing. The game is not worth its price. But the modders community is. If you want to play the mods - then buy this game.

TL;DR version - my reccomendation as a empire building turn-based/RTS fan and Total War series fan. + 2x IF's below.

If you have not played a Total War series game before, consider this title suited for more experienced Total War series fans or those that enjoy more challenge. This review will be aimed to give an idea to those that played at least one Total War title before.
If you played Total War series before and you liked the empire building aspect but felt that you could use more challnege - this one is fr you. Especially if you consider 2-3 mods (see below).

Diplomacy - decent, for a Total War series game, but it isn't as good as in Three Kingdoms(the only one I have not played) nor does it have as much options as Napoleon/Empire.

Battle AI - aparat from the joint land/naval battles, where it's pretty clueless, it's decent for Total War game. It managed to beat me few times whlie I was only slightly overpowered. Note I am not a big cheese fan.

Campaign AI - active, far more than in Rome 2, at times I would compare it to Warhammer 2 AI. It frequently punished me for not taking precautions. The two biggest drag's/con's is that a lot of regions become unpopulated quite quick, and they stay like that throught the game and the fact that most of the AI factions do not work to achieve their goals(become an empire), maybe except for the Huns - but I leave them for last.

Faction/government mangement - quite obscure to start with, but ok, when you get a hold of it. The amount of options is about right. All of those available are usable (unlike some of those in Rome 2). Although I find it quite easy to avoid civil wars, unlike in Rome 2. Keeping all your armies loyal is a bit more of a challenge. It presents you with options that in most cases are meaningful gamewise. (eg. provincional edicts based on your state religion)

Empire/province management - this is the area that it almost shines, if you like a challenge. Optimalization of your kigdom is very difficult. You need to think about happines, squalor/sanitation & food. There are contributing factors, like fertility, religion and to extent culture. This game punishes you if you build what you want, where you want yet it doesnot forbid you from doing it. You can assign governnors directly, which gives you direct bonuses to a particular province and unlocks edicts there (improvement over Rome 2 and Warhammer 2 - empire faction). You can even see a governor in the battle if the province capital would be assaulted.

Other points:
- hun invasion. So it's done in quite a harsh way, where even Attilla respawns once. It's wery annoying to deal with and seems very unclear on how to deal with it. It is reminiscent of Chaos invasion in Warhammer 1 & 2, but more annoying if you are in the wrong place on the map.
-Climate change is implemented (increases the challenge).
-Every year has 4 seasons, that impact the gameplay (eg. snow attrittion) and give you time to know your characters. This decreases the role of children though.
-I suggest considering the following mods(even before first playthrough): 
--Hun Invasion related, to tune it to a level that you would like (requires a bit of reading or possibly a youtube video).
--AI resettling related - so that the unpopulate areas (be it due to hun invasion or other actions) will be a t least partially populated by the AI over time
--Fertility related mod, that gives small buff to the region fertility through sanitation buildings. It does not really decrease the challenge but increases the player options(replan the economy or invest more in sanitation).
--Few bugs remain, so consider community patch/fix bundle.

Hope this will help some of you guys, considering if you should buy this.

Hands down my favorite TW game. Its much more brutal, but actually poses a strong AI and forces you to think very critically of empire management. Should you let your guard down to save money on maintenance and build up your infrastructure? How is fertility going to impact you in 10 turns? Is it better to subjugate and build a coalition, or build up your own internal strength? All these questions with the impending doom of Atilla arriving makes for an amazing survivalist campaign.

Total war: Attila is easily the hardest of the total war games. You have to subvert your expectations of how you usually play a Total war game. Its much more about surviving than thriving. The horde mechanics change the game in many ways, and you have to be much more careful due to the roaming bands of nomadic tribes that you will undoubtedly encounter during the playtime. Playing as one of the horde factions makes for an interesting play through since you have to raid and pillage until you find a suitable place to settle. Its also unsettling since the game revolves around Attilla and his campaign of destruction, and subjugation. Once you see his warbands approach your borders you better hope you have prepared enough to fight him off but dont expect too not have some losses he usually approaches you with up to 4 - 5 warbands that can easily beat your best troops. Other than that the music is wonderful, and the expansion age of Charlemagne is a worthy investment, but it is alot easier than the base game. I recommend that you try this out if you enjoy total war games and have some experience however if your a newcomer I recommend that you start with Shogun 2 which is an excellent starting place for newcommers.

I saw potential in this title but the lack of long term support has left this something of an unoptimised mess, which is a real shame because the period/setting is interesting and rarely touched upon.  It feels like this was the game where they tried out the new engine and then abandoned it to work on more popular titles like Rome 2 and Warhammer.  There's the framework of a good enough game in here though but you'll really need mods to unlock the potential.

As it stands it's something I couldn't recommend, perhaps with a heavy discount you'll find an enjoyable experience where I could not.

It's worth noting that CA went through a period of locking dissenting threads on Steam, marked negative reviews as "abusive", told their consumers not to buy their games and had a period of installing Red Shell spyware with their games without telling you.  Not the greatest PR.

Total War: Rome 3, or at least that's what is should be called.

Other factions are cool, for a while. 

Hordes and migrating factions have cool mechanics and start off super fun but get old after a bit. You don't empire build as a horde, you just raze settlements and extract resources from factions until they eventually turn on you and you have to burn them down anyway. Migratory factions play the same as a horde except they have to inevitably settle down, meaning every turn you stay migrating is another turn you'll lose out on empire building for the hell that comes mid-late game.

The other settled factions vary. The Sassanid Persians are very strong and very isolated, making them by far the easiest faction, but they have enough diversity to make them interesting until you get too powerful to have any reprecautions for your actions and lose interest. The Celts/Norse/Germanic factions are all basically the same, with very minor differences in unit rosters, buildings, technologies, and locations/allies/enemies. The tend to be absolutely screwed mid-late game as the harsher climate starves them to the point they either cant afford to feed their armies or pay for the higher tier units. The Slavs are doomed from the start.

 Some of the desert factions are cool though. The Garamantians can start carving up Rome from get-go while the empire is distracted elsewhere. Himyar is the most unique faction in the game, with a unique religion, diverse and powerful units, buildings, and starting location. The Tanukhids are basically a migratory faction like the Germanic ones, except they have eastern units, bonuses, different horde mechanics, and can pick better locations to settle. Lakhmids and Axum are "meh", but still more interesting than the europeans.

This all might sound a bit negative, but none of what I said above matters. The heart of this game is about the Fall of Rome. One of the most important events in the history of the world is at stake, and the game wants you to feel it. Rome is divided, there's the rich East which would later survive for over 1000 years and become the "Byzantine Empire", and then there's the imploding West, perhaps the single most influential state that has ever existed, and its fucked in every embarrassing way you could imagine.

This game is meant to be played as the Western Roman Empire, saving it from impending destruction and rising above every problem thrown at you. 
*Every germanic, celtic, nordic, african, gothic, and nomad faction around you declares war on you one after another
*The Huns are traveling across the world explicitly to burn your civilization to the ground while its weak
*Public order is gone, and 30 or so provinces are on the verge of revolting from the first few turns.
*Nothing is prosperous anymore save a few areas in Italy
*Some are starving and wont even be able to feed your troops
*Religious differences tear you apart
*You have a pathetically small army compared to your neighbors with much less quality
*Corruption is robbing you of your taxes
*Plague and disease will break out unless you dump tons of money into sanitation
*Your Emperor is the most pathetic leader around. 

Turning this around and painting the map with a prosperous and powerful Roman Eagle is literally the most rewarding gameplay experience I've had quite possibly ever. Kudos to CA for making a game so polarizingly difficult and stressful that it ACTUALLY gives it turbulent historical setting some real justice. This game is not easy, its not relaxing, but it can be incredibly rewarding and immersive, so it gets a big thumbs up.

I've played around 160 hours of Attila so far. I understand that's not much by some standards, but I still think it's about time for me to write a review of this game.

This review will be very long. For those of you who prefer shorter reviews, you might want to find a different one.

Total War: Rome 2, contrary to popular opinion, added some very good ideas to the series. For example, it introduced a set of factors which you had to balance within your settlements (food, income, and public order). This meant you had to manage your settlements to a greater degree, which had two main effects:

1. It meant you had to ensure your owned settlements are stable before having your armies leave them to conquer other lands.

2. It added a city management aspect to the game.

Rome 2 also fleshed out agents, giving them their own stats and more options when upgrading them. Rome 2 introduced army traditions, giving your armies more meaning and a greater sense of history.

Why am I bringing up Rome 2 in an Attila review? Because Attila took all those ideas, and refined them. See, Rome 2's ideas were very good, but were often awkwardly executed. Attila was a fresh chance to take the community's criticism and put it into action.

There are a few Total War games I have not played. Namely, the original Shogun and Medieval and the games from Warhammer on. But even still, I consider Total War: Attila to be one of the greatest Total War titles ever (yes, right up there with the original Rome: Total War and Shogun 2: Fall of the Samurai). There are several reasons for this:

1. As mentioned before, Attila took the good but poorly executed ideas of Rome 2 and enacted them as they should have been.

2. There are a wide diversity of cultures to play, each with their own advantages and disadvantages in terms of both soldiers and buildings.

3. Attila introduced the horde system, adding a completely new style of play.

4. Related to 2, the differences between factions are deeply meaningful, especially in terms of units. This is something that cannot be said, for example, about Shogun 2.

5. The game is fairly well-balanced, and the AI is a little better than most other Total War games.

That said, there are several weaknesses to this game:

1. While the AI is significantly better than in previous games, it still isn't the best. The Total War series is not known for its stellar AI.

2, While the game is pretty well-balanced, there are still some over-powered and under-powered units. Huscarls, for example, are pretty hard to counter, while elephants, while useful under the right circumstances, are a lot easier to counter than in previous games.

3. Related to 1, the AI seems to decide whether or not to make peace with you based on how much they dislike you. This means that if you raze even 1 city, they will practically never make peace with you, meaning you have to actually HUNT DOWN EVERY SINGLE SETTLEMENT AND ARMY THEY OWN in order to 'make peace' with them.

4. The Huns are very difficult to play. You should be able to play the faction the game is named after without a whole lot of difficulty.

5. Again related to 1, increasing the difficulty basically gives the AI a whole list of cheats. I understand that it is difficult to craft an AI without doing so, but let me illustrate with an example:

With about 6 settlements, you should be able to field 2 to 3 full armies. On hard, an AI faction with only one settlement will be able to raise just as many armies as you, often even more. This is because the AI gets huge discounts to unit upkeep as the difficulty increases. This makes starting out very hard, and factions difficult to fight at almost any level of development.

If you're ok with that, then that's fine, but I and I assume other players are not.

6, Also like its predecessor Rome 2 the game is split up into several DLCs. You can't play the Nordic factions, the desert factions, or the Slavic factions without paying $27 in DLCs. This is a bad practice that EA is unfortunately in the habit of. 

So should you get this game? Yes. I would wait for a sale, but it is more than worth it even at full price. This is, in my honest opinion, one of the greatest Total War games of all time. If you are a total beginner to the Total War series, I would consider buying the original Rome 1 instead, so that you can see if Total War interests you and so that you can start off with a simpler game in the series. But this game still can appeal to all Total War players of all skill levels and experiences.

The base game is not too bad if you have never played total war before, or if you are just looking for a couple of campaigns in a different setting. But as you play the game more, the more apparent problems become. Siege battles have like 3 maps for each culture and are super repetitive. Units are completely imbalanced. By researching technology you often lock yourself out of cheaper more useful units. The diplomacy doesnt work too well. The bordergore is horrendous.  The turn times are super long. The AI makes the most random decisions on when to take or sack provinces. I remember Eastern roman empire losing constantinople and never occupying it back, even though it was in the middle of its land. The aremies would just stand around it sacking it every other turn!

Now Age of Charlemagne Campaign DLC fixes many of these problems, and is generally very enjoyable to play as any faction. But this just makes the base game looks worse by comparison.

Have you ever had an itch to be constantly invaded by barbarians from the lands of eternal chaos, deal with unhappy military leadership, be in a constant state of economic struggle, be on figurative and literal fire, but also maybe RP as Aurelian and restore the world? Then the Western Roman Empire experience is for you.

I recommend this game as a real challenge for Total War fans, especially playing as either East or West Rome. It can be a real struggle sometimes, as due to constant immigration, every other faction hating you, a religion that handicaps you and a near Immortal Atilla. The chances of snowballing like in Rome II are slim. This game does have its problems, Atilla and his death stacks can be a real pain, but also the Roman civ tech tree, as it kills your ability to build useful concrete structures in favor of a big church and palace.

Overall really fun game i'd rate it Three Hunnic Death Stacks out of two German chaos invasions.

I love the Total War series. In fact, Napoleon and Empire are probably my favorite strategy games ever developed. And after 40 hours of Attila, I can definitively say that this is the worst game in the series. I think this is mainly due to the fact that they changed many of the games characteristics to fit more authentically within the time period. The problem with that is that during this time in history life was incredibly difficult and things took a long time to do.

Total War as a series is already strenuous concerning how long it takes to accomplish conquest. This game takes that concept and ramps it up tenfold. This may be what some Total War fans enjoy about the series but as for me it feels like I am moving along much to slow even while playing strategically correct. That is unless of course you play as a like the Huns, in which your not conquering land but rather raiding or just down right destroying it. And this is where the main flaw lies with Attila. The purpose of a strategy game, to myself, has always been to creatively think your way out of a problem. In this game you feel like you are being forced to play a certain way to make any progress at a reasonable rate. I mean what the hell! I wanna conquer land when I play these games! Is that too much to ask for?

There are other reasons why this game is flawed and I why I am giving this a down-vote, however that is the main one. Don't waste your money on this title. There are better Total War games out there. Not to mention they are cheaper.

Well, I was big fan of Total war strategies, but this remake of Rome 2 is... well... a game that makes you angry all the time:
-Diplomacy: You want to trade with somebody? Well, good luck. They might like you, they might have profit too, but they will not trade with you, because they just don't want... You missed random war declarations from Medieval 2? You are lucky, because it's back in Attila TW... You defeated you opponent, razed all his cities and left him just with one unit of general. No problem they will gladdly fight you for another 150 turns till you make them disappear.
-Strategy Map: All generals have same range of movement, so 90% of time you will be chasing enemy army, that will raid you cities in front of you and then run away withou chance of catching them... Then you realize that there are other 3 armies on other side of your realm.
-Battle: have you ever tried to shoot the bow? Great if yes your are better that all archers in Attila TW, If they don't miss, they hit your own with poision arrow. Just on f**** poison arrow and you own units starts to die. Those f***** arches killed more own people than enemy. 
-Music: After hour of listening of throat singing you'll turn music off before your head explodes. It's much worse than in Rome 2... 
-AI cheating: Yes, that is daily bread in TW games, but in Attila it's... well... Have you ever wonder how can a country with one city have 2 full armies when you, with 5 cities has only 1 and half?

A goddam* buggy mess, Total War Attila is yet another step in the wrong direction. It strips out the best elements of previous Total Wars like Napoleon - epic empire-building, fair balancing, fantastic music, slick GUI, and lengthy battles - and decides to replace them all with s#itty concepts. Yeah, the AI was bad, but guess what? It STILL is.

Why do I need a specific general to move my units? Why is Attila unstoppable unless you kill him 4 times? Why are there more bugs than even Shogun 2 had? Why are battles fast-paced and instantaneous like an arcade game? Why does it take so long to gain any traction on the campaign map, thereby boring the player to death? Why is there so much overpriced garbage DLC? And so on and so on...

Skip this junk, folks; there are far better Total Wars out there.
